DOC.HEAD: Tyson Says He Didn't Rough Up Woman at Club
DOC.TEXT: Mike Tyson took off his jacket and stepped into the witness box Tuesday to deny allegations that he assaulted a woman at a Manhattan dance club where, he said, boxing fans mobbed him all night like ``an army of ants.'' In a $4.5 million civil lawsuit, Sandra Miller, a 26-year-old Brooklyn woman, alleges that the former heavyweight champion ``forcibly fondled'' and cursed at her after she refused his advances at Bentley's Disco early Dec. 10, 1988. In a soft, assured voice, Tyson disputed all her allegations and said he didn't even recognize Miller. ``Did you grab her buttock?'' asked his attorney, Robert Hirth. ``No I did not,'' Tyson testified. He gave the same answer when Hirth asked him about Miller's other charges that Tyson grabbed her arm, breasts and threatened to punch her. ``The only thing I know is that I didn't touch this lady,'' Tyson said. Tyson, who described himself as a frequent patron of Bentley's, said he went to the club with two men who work for him and was mobbed by fans and friends from his old neighborhood in Brooklyn. The boxer said he bought several bottles of champagne for people at the bar and drank one toast with them. Tyson said he buys drinks for people who approach him at clubs as a way to get rid of them. ``They gang up on you like an army of ants,'' he said. Lawyers were expected to present closing arguments on Wednesday in the jury trial in U.S. District Court. On Monday, Miller's attorney, Alan Clark, told jurors that the incident began at a downstairs bar when Tyson grabbed Miller's arm and pulled her. He quoted Miller as saying, ``I'm a lady and treat me like a lady. Furthermore I have a man.'' Clark said she walked away after Tyson angrily asked her whether she knew who he was. A short time later, Clark alleged that Tyson again approached Miller and grabbed her buttock and then her breast, cursing at her and yelling, ``Don't you know I'm the world heavyweight champion?'' A third encounter occurred later that night in an upstairs lounge, where Tyson again cursed at her and shoved her, Clark said.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Army Engineer Called Scapegoat for Helicopter Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for grafs 7-8 pvs, ``Missile systems ...' to UPDATE with timing of interview, include details of charges and court hearing scheduled. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Army officials ...'
DOC.TEXT: A civilian Army employee who was handcuffed and removed from his office for threatening to go public says many Army helicopters lack equipment that would protect them from Iraqi heat-seeking missiles. A colleague says the man was a scapegoat in a cover-up of problems in Army aircraft safety. Army officials said they suspected Calvin J. Weber of the Army Aviation Systems Command here had planned to disclose sensitive information about equipment vulnerability. Weber said many of the approximately 95 Vietnam-era Huey helicopters used by American forces in Operation Desert Shield lack modern equipment designed to fool heat-seeking missles. He said he suspected that only about a third of the more modern Blackhawk helicopters had up-to-date anti-missile gear and some Cobra attack helicopters also lack the equipment. It would cost about $40,000 to add the anti-missile device to each Huey, Weber said. The devices either disperse the exhaust of the helicopter's engine - making detection by a heat-seeking missile more difficult - or provide a decoy heat source that confuses a missile's guidance system, he said. ``Missile systems have advanced, but the Army has trodded and plodded, and was lax in taking care of equipment with the latest protection available,'' Weber told a reporter for the St. Louis Post-Dispatch last week. He said he began warning Defense Department officials of the potential danger two years ago. Weber, 48, was handcuffed and carried from his job at the Army Aviation Systems Command when he refused to leave, and was charged with disorderly conduct and two other misdemeanors. He faces a court date Nov. 16. The Army said the veteran of 16 years working for the Army was to be fired as of Wednesday after colleagues removed his personal belongings from his desk. Army officials, citing privacy regulations, have refused to discuss details of Weber's case. Dick Mooy, a senior engineer with the aviation command who is helping Weber in an effort to keep his job, said the command is ``despotic'' and ``interested only in itself.'' Mooy said he had worked for the Army as a civilian for 22 years, working mostly with Army helicopters and other aircraft. He said he had known Weber for years and described him as an expert on helicopter survivability. Mooy said he agreed with Weber's contention that many of the Army helicopters sent to Saudi Arabia in Operation Desert Shield lacked the full range of equipment needed to thwart heat-seeking missiles. Both engineers said the Army had accused Weber of keeping $1,500 worth of Army helicopter screws at his house. Mooy said a supervisor had not objected to Weber's having them. Mooy added that Army Mohawk surveillance airplanes, including some in Saudi Arabia, might be a danger to themselves. He said an infrared suppressor for that aircraft was prone to come apart and damage the plane's rudder. ``I call this, as an engineer, a big cover-up in the Army,'' Mooy said. ``Cal tried for years to go through channels, but it came to a dead end.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Louisiana Desegregation Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday dismissed a 16-year-old lawsuit on desegregation of Louisiana colleges and universities, siding with the state over the U.S. Justice Department. The judge cited a recent appeals court ruling that colleges in Mississippi were not intentionally segregated. He said that ruling was ``binding and controlling'' in the Louisiana case. The Justice Department, which filed the Louisiana lawsuit in 1974, was the only party still contending the state is running a segregated higher education system. Amy Casner, a Justice Department spokeswoman, said agency officials would have to review the ruling before commenting on whether they will appeal. In the Mississippi case, a three-judge panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last month that Mississippi, which has an open admissions policy, offered ``real freedom of choice'' for students to pick their schools and no longer was intentionally running a desegregated system. Louisiana also has an open admissions policy, but enrollment at historically black Southern University and Grambling State University remain almost all black. Blacks are in the minority at Louisiana State and seven other of the state's 17 colleges and universities. U.S. District Judge Charles Schwartz, in a two-paragraph order said the appeals court ruling in the Mississippi case left him with ``no disputed material facts left ... to resolve.'' State and federal authorities thought they had settled the case in 1981 with a consent decree in which the state agreed to pour hundreds of millions of dollars into Grambling and Southern to improve buildings, equipment and programs and to make the two schools more attractive to whites. By 1988, black leaders and the Justice Department concluded the consent decree had failed. A three-judge panel led by Schwartz agreed the system was still segregated and issued its own sweeping desegregation plan. That plan called for a single governing board to replace four boards that oversee the Louisiana schools. Gov. Buddy Roemer had long embraced the single-board idea, but his administration appealed the plan on grounds that Louisiana's colleges and universities are not segregated. Those appeals were pending when Schwartz dismissed the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Was Target of Other Investigations, Former Chief Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 4-7: ``In other,'' remarks of judge in case
DOC.TEXT: Former District of Columbia Police Chief Maurice Turner said Tuesday that Mayor Marion Barry was the target of several undercover drug operations when Turner was police chief. Up to now, only one investigation of Barry, the one that led to his arrest, conviction and six-months prison sentence, had been revealed. ``I was aware of the rumors and innuendos surrounding the mayor,'' Turner, now a Republican mayoral candidate, said during a campaign forum on WJLA-TV. ``There were several aggressive grand juries that were seated, and there were stings that didn't materialize.'' In other news about Barry's case, the judge at his trial was quoted as telling a law school audience in Cambridge, Mass. he thought the case against Barry was ``overwhelming'' on 10 of the 14 counts, and believed that four jurors were determined to acquit Barry, no matter what the evidence. Those four ``obviously did not tell the truth'' when they said they would approach the case without bias, said U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in a speech at Harvard Law School, according to a dispatch from Cambridge in Wednesday editions of The Washington Post. ``I am quite sure that neither race nor politics played any part'' in the case, said Jackson. Many of the mayor's supporters have accused government prosecutors of targeting black officials like Barry in corruption investigations. Barry and Turner are black; Jackson is white. Turner declined to provide details on the sting operations against Barry, which he first mentioned in response to a question about whether he would have approved such a tactic against his then-boss. ``The stings were field operations, and I don't want to go into it,'' Turner said. ``I do approve of sting operations, though.'' Turner, who served 32 years on the police force with the last eight as chief, added that he would not have ``sacrificed my career for someone using drugs.'' The former chief declined to say whether the operations were coordinated with federal officials or whether his department was acting alone. The federal investigation that led to Barry's arrest, in cooperation with city police, began in December 1988 when officials started looking into why city police called off an undercover drug purchase at a hotel after discovering that Barry was in the suspect's room. Turner was police chief then. A hotel manager testified later that he, the manager, blocked the undercover purchase because he feared the publicity that would result if the mayor were involved. Barry was arrested Jan. 18 this year after FBI agents made a secret videotape of him smoking crack cocaine in the hotel room of one of Barry's former girlfriends, who had cooperated with investigators. The mayor was convicted of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, and acquitted of another after a two-month trial this summer. The jury failed to agree on a dozen other charges, including the possession charge stemming from Barry's arrest. Last Friday, Barry was sentenced to six months in prison. Turner, a former Democrat, is considered a long shot to win next Tuesday's mayoral election against Democrat Sharon Pratt Dixon. Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 9-1 margin in the nation's capital.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Leak-Free, Cleared for Flight
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in five months, all three of NASA's space shuttles have been cleared for flight, with Atlantis due to lift off next week and Columbia in December. Columbia was found to be free of dangerous hydrogen leaks during an elaborate fueling test Tuesday. The spaceship has been grounded since May. ``Obviously, we have had some problems we've had to work,'' said shuttle director Bob Crippen. ``That perhaps took us longer than some people thought it would, but it was a tough set of problems we were working.'' Atlantis, also crippled by hydrogen leaks over the summer, passed a fueling test last week. The shuttle is scheduled to lift off Nov. 9 with a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq. The tests gave a lift to NASA, which has sent up only one shuttle, Discovery, since April. Discovery earlier this month sent a probe on a mission to explore the sun. ``Launching space shuttles and reputation, they are tied together,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. ``Safely and successfully carrying out these missions, which is our goal, is only going to help the reputation and our cause to keep the program going.'' During Tuesday's three-hour test, Columbia's external tank was filled with more than 385,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen. A small amount of hydrogen escaped into the engine compartment but was well within allowable limits. It was NASA's most extensive fueling test of a shuttle. Ten TV cameras and 17 sensors were mounted in Columbia's engine compartment to detect leaks. NASA had tried four times to launch Columbia with the $150 million Astro observatory. Fuel lines and other parts were replaced and numerous joints tightened. Officials believe workers accidentally damaged components in Columbia while searching for contamination after the shuttle's last flight, in January. Columbia could be launched in early December if Atlantis goes up on time, Crippen said. That will allow NASA to finish the year with six shuttle missions, three fewer than planned.

DOC.HEAD: Smith, as Attorney General, Helped Guide Sharp Change in Federal Policy
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS penultimate graf to correct to University of California at Berkeley; picks up last graf
DOC.TEXT: William French Smith helped guide Ronald Reagan from Hollywood to the White House and then drastically revised federal policy on crime, civil rights and corporate mergers during his tenure as attorney general. Born Aug. 26, 1917, in Wilton, N.H., to an aristocratic Yankee family, Smith pursued an impeccable establishment career in corporate law, deviating from his heritage only in his adoption of Los Angeles as his home. He died of cancer Monday in Los Angeles. He was 73. Indeed, there was little in his background, personality and early public appearances to foreshadow the sweeping changes he would make when he took office as the nation's 74th attorney general in January 1981. A specialist in corporate relations with labor, Smith was managing partner of the prestigious Los Angeles law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher when Reagan named him attorney general. Smith had been with the firm since he began his career in 1946. During that time he had become Reagan's personal attorney and helped guide the investments that turned the actor into a millionaire. He also had become a key behind-the-scenes political adviser as Reagan sought first the California governorship and then the presidency. He served as the informal chairman of a group of California millionaires, known as the ``Kitchen Cabinet,'' who saw Reagan socially, boosted his political fortunes and helped pick his first Cabinet. But at his confirmation hearings, the publicity-shy Smith responded to virtually every question by saying he would have to study the matter. Early in his tenure, he confided that it was not until shortly before taking office that he realized the Immigration and Naturalization Service was part of the Department of Justice. He noticed it on the INS seal as he crossed the border when returning from a short trip to Mexico. And a magazine story early in his tenure at Justice quoted an administration official as calling him a ``somnambulist,'' or sleepwalker, a description that rankled him. But if he started slower than his predecessors, Smith altered more department policies more sharply than any attorney general in a generation. Among the changes in which he played a key role were: -The appointment of the first woman, Sandra Day O'Connor, to the Supreme Court. -Bringing the FBI for the first time into drug enforcement, a move previous administrations had considered but shield away from. -Legislation overturning a 100-year-old ban on military aid to civilian law enforcement. He brought the military into tracking planes and ships smuggling cocaine and marijuana from South America. -Advocating the most extensive immigration law revisions in three decades; though he left office before Congress finished acting on them. -The relaxation of rules against corporate mergers, which had not been changed in 15 years. This helped set off a wave of mergers. -A halt to the Justice Department's advocacy of mandatory busing to desegregate schools and of hiring and promotion goals to remedy job discrimination. In this, he changed policies advocated by four previous administrations of both parties, but was unable to convince the Supreme Court to overturn the legal precedents supporting those remedies. A presidential order instituted unprecedented lifetime censorship for the writings and speeches of former government officials with access to the most sensitive intelligence and a major broadening of the use of the polygraph machine in leak investigations. Congress, however, stepped in to block immediate implementation of the order. The merger policies of his antitrust division infuriated consumers and liberal Democrats. Black groups and women's organizations were outraged over his civil rights policies. They prevailed in Congress over his opposition to toughening the Voting Rights Act and in court over his unprecedented effort to give tax exemptions to racially discriminatory private schools. He also drew a mixture of praise and criticism for being the first attorney general to view his job as an international one. He took four major foreign trips to 14 countries, including an unprecedented round-the-world tour, to encourage foreign officials to help stop drug-smuggling. Drug enforcement officials hailed these efforts. But the round-the-world jaunt, with his wife, Jean, along at government expense, cost more than $600,000 and was criticized as extravagant. His later trips used smaller planes and a reduced entourage, although his wife still accompanied him. Smith's personal finances and patrician style also drew attacks. Career department attorneys, many of them opposed to his policies, jeered his establishment of a second private dining room at the Justice Department and his regular appearances on the Washington social circuit. In 1982, Democrats, including Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, criticized his investment in two oil and gas tax shelters and his acceptance of a $50,000 severance payment when he left the board of directors of the Earle M. Jorgensen Steel Co. to become attorney general. Smith defused that controversy by agreeing to return the $50,000 and limit his tax deductions in the two ventures to the amount of his cash investment. Smith seemed surprised at these criticisms, for he was unaccustomed to public scrutiny of his personal life. He was born into wealth. His father, who died when Smith was 6 years old, owned the Mexican telephone and telegraph company and battled the revolutionary Pancho Villa. One ancestor arrived in this country aboard the Mayflower; another, Uriah Oakes, was the fourth president of Harvard, which has educated a Smith in every generation. He graduated with highest honors from the University of California at Berkeley in 1939, received his law degree from Harvard in 1942 and spent four years as a Navy lieutenant during World War II. He then joined Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. It was to that firm and private life that he returned when he announced his surprise resignation in January 1984. Asserting that he had completed much of what he wanted to do, Smith said he also wanted to resume his behind-the-scenes work on behalf of Reagan, who was then seeking re-election to the presidency.

DOC.HEAD: Congresswoman Under Fire as NRA Advocate
DOC.TEXT: Republicans marked Democratic Rep. Jolene Unsoeld for defeat as soon as she squeaked into Congress in the closest U.S. House race of 1988. Now, Unsoeld's political future appears tied to an issue that didn't even exist two years ago. Unsoeld was a staunch supporter of gun control as a state legislator, but as a freshman member of Congress she's championed the views of the National Rifle Association. The apparent about-face has become the hottest campaign issue in her race against conservative Republican Bob Williams, a longtime advocate of gun owners' rights. ``She has managed to raise the whole issue of integrity and what's wrong with Congress,'' Williams says. ``They go back there and suddenly they become different people. They're not one of us.'' Sarah Brady, chairwoman of the Handgun Control Inc. lobby group in Washington, D.C., said Unsoeld ``sold her political soul to the assault-weapons lobby in the hope it will get her re-elected.'' Unsoeld, who won her seat by 618 votes in the closest House race i 1988, stoutly defends her pro-NRA position, calling gun ownership a constitutional issue. In the Legislature, she says, she viewed it as a crime issue. ``I am extremely outraged at my opponent's deliberate misrepresentation of my position and suggestion that my views or actions can be influenced by money or threats,'' Unsoeld has said. ``Because some people thought they knew what my position was on gun control, they found it painful to discover otherwise.'' The most scathing attacks have come from her longtime allies - liberal Democrats, the Common Cause citizens lobby, gun-control groups and the media. One political cartoonist drew Unsoeld as a machine gun-toting Rambo and The Seattle Times editorialized against her ``unconscionable sellout.'' Her high-profile switch touched off an ad war between the NRA and Brady's group: The former portrays her as an American heroine, the latter as a defender of the arsenals used by crack dealers, mass murderers and hate groups. State Democratic leaders admit the change in position will hurt Unsoeld. ``What it's going to cost her, I don't know,'' said state party chairwoman Karen Marchioro. Even before the gun-control question heated up, Unsoeld was under fire from timber industry advocates who objected to her support for protecting the old-growth forest habitat of the endangered spotted owl. An Oct. 24-25 poll conducted for the National Republican Congressional Committee showed the race a dead heat, with Unsoeld favored by 36 percent of those surveyed and Williams by 40 percent and 25 percent undecided. The survey had a 5.7 percentage point margin of error. The gun-control issue surfaced this fall when Unsoeld championed an amendment protecting the domestic manufacture of assault weapons similar to the foreign-made Uzi and AK-47. The amendment, considered the major gun vote of the year, passed the House, 257-172, earlier this month. The crime bill to which it was attached passed a day later. A transcript of the House Rules Committee shows that Unsoeld requested permission Sept. 12 for a vote on the amendment. According to a letter on file with the Federal Election Commission, she received a $4,950 contribution from the NRA the same day. ``The timing was extraordinarily bad,'' says Democratic state Sen. Phil Talmadge. Unsoeld is swamping Williams in finances. Her contributions, including those from political action committees, come to about $825,000, compared with about $472,000 for Williams. Williams, an accountant, has been endorsed by Gun Owners of America, which says it represents ``100,000 of the most pro-gun households in the nation.'' That group says it's ``not impressed with Mrs. Unsoeld's support for a minor amendment.''

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine-Alcohol Combination Produces Third Drug in Body, Scientists Say
DOC.TEXT: Drinking alcohol while using cocaine makes the body produce a third substance that may yield a greater high but may also raise the risk of death by overdose, scientists say. The research, together with a preliminary finding that drinking boosts the risk of a fatal cocaine overdose about 20-fold in people with severe coronary heart disease, may help explain the puzzling overdose deaths in people with surprisingly little of the drug in their blood at autopsy. New studies show that this third substance, manufactured in the liver from cocaine and alcohol, can mimic some actions of cocaine in the brain. Drinking is frequently combined with cocaine use, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse. Researchers spoke in telephone interviews about studies that were presented Monday at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in St. Louis. The substance is a close chemical cousin of cocaine called cocaethylene. Further studies of it may give leads for medications to treat cocaine addiction by blocking cocaine's effects, said study co-author Deborah Mash, a neuropharmacologist at the University of Miami School of Medicine. Scientists found that cocaethylene affects a brain-cell communication system thought to produce the euphoria that leads to cocaine addiction, she said. Prior research suggests that cocaine produces its high by intervening in this system, in which brain cells signal each other with a chemical called dopamine. After a dose of dopamine reaches its target cell, it is supposed to be brought back to its original home by molecules called transporters. But cocaine blocks this mechanism by binding to transporters, keeping the signal turned ``on'' and producing a sense of pleasure, scientists say. The new work shows that cocaethylene also binds to the transporters, suggesting it may boost cocaine's effect, Mash said. In addition, she said, it appears less able than cocaine to moderate the euphoria through a second brain communication system. Another possible role of cocaethylene deals with cocaine overdose deaths in people with severe coronary artery disease. The overdose study found no elevated risk for people with moderate or mild coronary disease, said co-author Dr. James Ruttenber of the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. The study included about 240 cases of fatal cocaine overdose and a comparable number of deaths from other causes in people who had taken cocaine, Ruttenber said. Mash said cocaethylene might play a role in the elevated risk because it can cling to brain cell sites that are supposed to attract a brain-communication substance called acetylcholine. This may interfere with the brain's control of the heart pumping rhythm, she said. If the heart is already affected by heart disease, the result could be sudden death, she suggested. Ruttenber said that less than 20 percent of overdose deaths in the study involved severe heart disease and that it is not clear whether cocaethylene contributed to the elevated risk. But if it did, he said, it may also play a role in the more common puzzle of overdose deaths in people with surprisingly little cocaine in their blood. About 40 percent of overdose deaths in the study fit that category, and it has been noticed before, he said. For cocaine users, he said, such cases suggests that ``even if they are careful about the quantities of cocaine they use, they still may not be able to ward off a fatal overdose.'' Michael Kuhar, a NIDA neuroscientist who did not participate in the studies, said the suggested roles for cocaethylene are plausible. It is ``a new entity we don't know much about,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hindus Break through Police Lines, Storm toward Disputed Shrine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Hindu fundamentalists breaking through police barricades and battling police. Picks up 19th pvs, `In New ...' ^LaserPhoto AYO3
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Hindu holy men and their followers broke through police barricades Tuesday and stormed toward the Moslem mosque they want to replace with a Hindu temple. Many were beaten back by police who fired tear gas and lashed out with iron-tipped bamboo canes. Dozens were injured. Hindu holy men screamed obscenities from rooftops and pelted the police with stones. About 200 people overran police lines in the narrow lanes and were halted at the foot of the hill just 600 feet from the mosque. The religious dispute has made the name of this Hindu holy town a battle cry in Moslem-Hindu riots that have left more than 100 dead across India in the past week. The dispute threatens to topple the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. A right-wing Hindu party withdrew its support for Singh last week when his government tried to deter plans to build new Hindu temple where the mosque now stands. Ayodhya had been under around-the-clock curfew since Friday in an effort to keep Hindu fundamentalists from carrying out their vow to begin construction of the temple Tuesday. Roads leading to the 16th century mosque were blocked, but about 5,000 people emerged from hiding places in fields around Ayodhya before sunrise and stormed a bridge leading into the town. Police arrested between 100 and 200 people and rained blows with their bamboo canes on fallen members of the crowd. The 600 policemen on the mile-long bridge eventually turned back the crowd. Inside Ayodhya, a town of about 40,000 people, reporters saw some members of the state police force lift barricades and let Hindu holy men run into the lanes leading to the mosque. The infiltrators were halted short of the mosque by federal paramilitary police. On Monday, a group of about 80 Hindu holy men in Ayodhya threw stones at police and set a bus on fire when authorities attempted to arrest a local Hindu priest, a police inspector said. The inspector, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was an isolated incident and did not cause any lasting tension. But within an hour of the skirmish, authorities banned entry into Ayodhya and canceled passes issued to reporters. Despite the efforts to deter them and the presence of 20,000 police and paramilitary troops in town, the Hindu fundamentalists vowed to start the temple construction program as scheduled. In New Delhi on Monday, the World Hindu Council had claimed 10,000 supporters had slipped through police cordons and roadblocks around Ayodhya. The exact time for the start of construction has not been announced. In New Delhi, Prime Minister Singh offered to resign if the Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which supports the temple construction program, would accept a legal verdict on the dispute. Singh's National Front coalition was relegated to a minority in Parliament last week after Bharatiya Janata withdrew its support to the government. Singh has maintained he still holds a parliamentary majority and is scheduled to seek a vote of confidence on Nov. 7. The government has vowed to block the temple construction and said a court of law should decide who the site belongs to. The fundamentalists claim the mosque stands atop the very spot where Rama, one of the most worshipped Hindu gods, was born and therefore is a religious matter, not a legal one. Moslems, a minority in officially secular but predominantly Hindu India, fear the displacement of one mosque could jeopardize hundreds of other Islamic sites across the country. On Friday the government of Uttar Pradesh state imposed an around-the-clock curfew in Ayodhya in an effort to keep temple advocates from reaching the disputed hilltop. Trains to the area were halted and roads blocked by police and paramilitary troops. Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, of whom 82 percent are Hindu. In Uttar Pradesh state, where the government is allied with Singh, Moslems account for about 30 percent of the 120 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Skinny-Dipping, Philandering Claims Top String of Minnesota Scandals
DOC.TEXT: Forget that picture of clean-cut Minnesota politics. This year it's alleged skinny-dipping with teen-age girls and financial impropriety. The troubles of Republicans Jon Grunseth, Rep. Arlan Stangeland and Sen. Dave Durenberger have turned the state's Lake Wobegon-like image into Minnesota mud. Political sleaze has found a new home. ``The tragedies of this year would be extraordinary in any age, but they're a culmination of what I see as a general level of conduct which is not nearly as good as we think it is,'' former St. Paul Mayor George Latimer said Monday. ``I think it will be followed by a lot of serious reappraisal.'' Grunseth quit the governor's race Sunday amid allegations he swam nude with teen-age girls nine years ago and had an extramarital affair during both of his marriages. Stangeland used his congressional credit card to pay for more than 400 long-distance telephone calls to and from a woman's home and office. And the Senate in July found that Durenberger had engaged in unethical financial conduct. That's not all. There have been: -Sexual harassment allegations against Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich's former chief of staff. -The indictment of a close Perpich political associate in connection with an S&L's failure. -The resignation of a popular state representative as head of the powerful Minnesota House Appropriations Committee after pleading guilty to charges stemming from his solicitation of males for sex. -Accusations that another state representative diverted about $93,000 of clients' money to his own use while acting as their financial planner. He resigned and pleaded guilty to four counts of felony theft. Grunseth denied the nude-swimming allegations, the former Perpich aide maintains his innocence and the S&L case has yet to be resolved. Stangeland says even the late-night phone calls were business-related. But the good-government image of Minnesota is gone. The scandals and the negative tone of the 1990 governor's race will lead to greater scrutiny of potential candidates, predicts D.J. Leary, a Democratic political analyst. ``Parties will be extraordinarily careful about doing the fingernail test in future elections,'' Leary said. ``They (candidates) may have to bring some proven credentials in some other field, if not in government, where both the public and private self has been under scrutiny for a number of years.'' Even before the nude-swimming allegations against Grunseth, Minnesota voters were complaining about the negative tone of the 1990 governor's race. Perpich had traveled the state distributing court documents pertaining to Grunseth's divorce disputes with his first wife and Perpich surrogates had criticized Grunseth for some tardy property tax payments. Grunseth accused Perpich of orchestrating the skinny-dipping allegations and called the governor ``the supreme liar,'' although he offered no proof to back his claim. ``I keep hoping that we've hit bottom, but I don't see any signs of it,'' said Latimer. ``Negative campaigning works, and it works in Minnesota. The question becomes, how effective can negativism be and not bring the wrath of voters against a candidate who uses them.'' Observers of the Minnesota political scene disagree about what it the year's events mean. ``I think Minnesota is still the kind of state it has been, and the fact there was such an outpouring of objection to Grunseth is an indication of the virtue of the state, rather than the opposite,'' said former Republican Gov. Elmer L. Andersen. Minnesota voters expect honesty and dedication from their public servants and they ``react pretty vigorously to any departure from it,'' Andersen said. ``I don't think Minnesota is changing much. Unfortunately, there have been a number of incidents.'' Latimer, a Democrat, looks at it differently. Minnesota residents ``have been living off our past reputation, and increasingly the evidence does not support that reputation,'' he said. There's been a tendency to overstate Minnesota as a good-government state with innocent, hard-working, not-too-sophisticated people who are honest, loyal and brave, Latimer said. ``It's a little smug to say we are so good we're still shocked by the bad,'' he said. ``For years we've been saying that, but the simple fact is, what happened to Dave Durenberger is not just extraordinary for the state of Minnesota, it's extraordinary in the U.S. Senate. ``We are not as good as we pretend to be, as we should be, as we ought to be in our level of public conduct,'' Latimer said.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit-Reduction Bill Expands Benefits in Medicaid, Medicare
With PM-Tummy Tuck Taxes Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for the poor are hailing a series of new benefits in Medicaid and other programs that Congress included with the tax increases and spending cuts in the deficit-reduction bill. Thousands of families will be aided by the expanded programs, under which the government will foot doctors' bills for more low-income families and for mammograms performed on older women. Large portions of the billions of dollars of new spending will be spent on families who work but who remain needy. ``The common theme that connects a lot of this is that it is aimed at low-and moderate-income families,'' said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington-based advocacy group for the poor. One of the most dramatic increases is for Medicaid, which helps low-income Americans pay their medical expenses. It will allow the program for the first time to cover all children below age 19 whose families are below the poverty level. Currently, poor children younger than age 6 are covered. Most of those covered above that age belong to families on welfare, leaving out those in families who earn just enough not to qualify for welfare. The change would be phased in gradually, initially adding only 7-year-olds to the program and progressing to children one year older each year. The eventual effect is expected to be enormous. Officials believe 704,000 additional children will receive Medicaid benefits by 1995, costing the government $560 million during the next five years. ``It's a terrific step forward,'' said Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund. Lawmakers also decided to expand Medicaid's coverage of the elderly poor. The government will spend $580 million over the next five years to help senior citizens receive care in their own homes, adult day-care centers or group homes. It will also put up $387 million to pay the monthly Medicare premium for doctors' expenses - an out-of-pocket cost for most Medicare recipients - for many of the poorest elderly. In a separate $100 million effort, the government will provide at-home care for retarded people. Overall, the deficit-reduction bill envisions additional Medicaid spending of $2.3 billion through 1995. But since the bill also contains savings of $2.9 billion over the next five years, there would be a net reduction in Medicaid of $600 million. The savings come largely from requiring drug companies to lower their prices for Medicaid recipients and by savings on insurance costs. The deficit-reduction bill also included: -A $22 billion child-care package containing tax credits and grants, with most of the money directed to the working poor. -New restrictions on private firms that sell health insurance policies to the elderly, an industry that has been accused of frequent abuses. -$2.1 billion in new spending under Medicare, which provides money for medical costs of elderly and handicapped. The chief new help for them allows coverage for mammograms, or breast X-rays. Until now, the program only provided reimbursements for women having mammograms if disease was suspected. Overall, the growth of Medicare is being reduced by $44 billion. -$740 million in new Social Security spending. A major change is the easing of the conditions under which a widow or widower can receive disability benefits. Cuts in other parts of Social Security yield a net savings in the program of $85 million.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Belief High in Eastern Europe Despite Years of Repression
DOC.TEXT: Religious faith in Eastern Europe remains strong despite years of official repression under communist regimes, according to polling data gathered by the Gallup organization. Gordon Heald, the London-based director of Gallup's international arm, told The Associated Press his studies indicate that religious belief in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and the Soviet republic of Lithuania closely parallels that of Western Europe and the Nordic countries. Fewer people go to church in the former communist countries, where religious activity was often punished, than attend services in Western Europe. But the percentage of people who describe themselves as religious is quite comparable, Heald said. In a continuing study of people's values, the pollster reported, he has found a striking difference between East and West in the trust that citizens place in various institutions. Personal interviews with 1,000 randomly selected Lithuanians showed they place their highest confidence in the church, the Lithuanian legislature that has led a drive for independence from Soviet rule and in the Lithuanian news media. In Hungary, where the press and broadcasters are perceived as having taken a leading role in bringing down the communist regime, the media hold the highest confidence rating of all institutions checked, Heald said. The church, with 67 percent of respondents giving it their vote of confidence, ranked 5 percentage points below the media but 5 points above the government. The army, parliament, police and Communist Party lagged behind the government. The courts, police, military and the KGB secret police rank with the Soviet Communist Party and private cooperative businesses at the bottom of the confidence scale in Lithuania, Heald reported. Previous Gallup studies have shown that the armed forces, police and the legal system are among the most highly respected institutions in the United States, Canada and Europe. The polling specialist presented his findings about the status of religion in Eastern Europe to a symposium last week at Georgetown University. In an interview with The Associated Press, he explained the samples taken so far show that 45 percent of ethnic Lithuanians, 49 percent of Czechoslovaks and 56 percent of Hungarians still consider themselves religious. The predominant religion in all three areas is Roman Catholicism. Heald's tables show 62 percent of Western Europeans but only 46 percent of Scandinavians consider themselves religious. Surveys in the United States show 81 percent of Americans consider themselves religious. Although the number of self-described non-religious people was somewhat higher in the formerly communist countries of Hungary and Czechoslovakia than in Western Europe, the number of ``convinced atheists'' in Lithuania was between 2 and 4 percent, compared to 5 percent in all of Western Europe and 10 percent in France alone, Heald found. Public opinion polling is still relatively new to the Soviet Union, and findings often are unscientific. Heald said he has had particular difficulty gathering reliable data in the Russian republic but that his Lithuanian polling operation has worked well. Marxist doctrine denounced religion as an ``opiate of the masses,'' and thousands of clergy were executed or imprisoned during the Stalin years. Proselytizing was officially forbidden, and churchgoers were subject to intimidation by secret police. In the Soviet Union and several Soviet bloc countries, thousands of churches were destroyed or converted to other uses and are only now being returned to church authorities. Although the Russian Orthodox Church continued to operate at severely reduced levels, Roman Catholic clergy in Lithuania, Czechoslovakia and elsewhere went underground to continue practicing their religion clandestinely. The Rev. Michael J. Lavelle, president of John Carroll University and a frequent traveler to Czechoslovakia, told the symposium that the underground church, cut off from mainstream theology for 40 years, has emerged from the communist period with outdated theology and ``a very avant garde religious practice.'' ``Masses have been said on dining room tables with the priest wearing no vestment,'' the Jesuit priest said. ``Lay people have been bringing the sacraments to other people'' in direct violation of canon law. ``People did what they had to do,'' he said, but he added tensions are likely to arise now, as those who preserved their religion in secret confront new ideas and the obligations imposed by the official church hierarchy. Lavelle acknowledged that most people in Czechoslovakia have been baptized as Christians, but he called them ``de facto atheists.'' ``They know little about the religion into which they were baptized,'' he said. ``The major task of the church now is to evangelize the vast majority of people who have not received any type of religious instruction since 1950.''

DOC.HEAD: Computer-Controlled Fertilizing System Gets Government Look
DOC.TEXT: Farmers complain about the rising cost of fertilizers and pesticides, and say they'd like the government to do more research to reduce their need. At the same time, however, they're reluctant to give up the chemicals that have done so much to increase crop yields, despite the warnings of long-term environmental damage. Enter John Colburn of Houston, and his Soil Doctor. Colburn's ``prescription application'' computerized equipment is being eyed by experts at the Environmental Protection Agency as a good way to reduce ground water pollution caused by excessive fertilization. The 1990 farm bill requires the Agriculture Department to teach farmers and agrichemical dealers how to use chemicals in ``prudent, economical and environmentally sound'' ways. Dr. Lloyd Murdock, a soil specialist at the University of Kentucky who works as an extension agent for USDA, said Colburn's instrument ``looked pretty good'' for conserving chemical fertilizers. Murdock conducted a one-year test using the instrument on a farmer's corn field near the university. Colburn, president of Crop Technology Inc., said his idea originally was to save farmers money, but his equipment ``addresses environmental issues, too.'' The machinery costs about $13,000, but it can pay for itself in two years through the $20 to $25 an acre a farmer saves in fertilizers, he said. The problem has been with farmers who apply fertilizer in quantities large enough to account for runoff from heavy rains. Since not every part of a farmer's land is equally productive, the grower also usually measures his chemicals for the least productive areas without accounting for any residual nitrates still there from the last planting. These practices can lead to a lot of unnecessary nitrates in the soil and eventually into groundwater. The EPA says 10 micrograms of nitrate per liter of water is considered the limit for the most vulnerable humans - babies, for example. Meanwhile, some crops grow best with 22 to 24 micrograms of nitrates per liter. Colburn's equipment, which he calls the Soil Doctor, uses two computers to regulate the amount of fertilizer applied. It can be installed on the farmer's existing equipment. Simply put, a prober on the front of the tractor tests the soil as the farmer drives along, telling a computer in the cab how much fertilizer to release out the back of the vehicle. Colburn said his system has been under development since 1984 and tested extensively in the Midwest. About 40 have been sold for use this year, he said. It's being used exclusively for corn at this time because corn is the highest nitrate-consuming crop, Colburn said. Farmers don't always like computers, he said, ``but this is fairly well appreciated once a farmer gets behind the wheel.'' Terry Behymer, of Sterling, Ill., said he has saved money and increased corn yield with the invention. Last year, he won state honors for corn growing with 209.5 bushels per acre, and this year is doing even better with 249.5 bushels an acre. Behymer's 700-acre farm grows corn, wheat, soybeans and alfalfa. He said Colburn's equipment is suitable only for the corn, but it has enabled him to measure the amount of nitrate appropriate for each area in his field. He said the nitrates in the soil vary depending on which crop was grown last on the particular acreage. Behymer said he wanted something that would tell him how much nitrate already as in the soil before he applied more. Murdock said the nitrate level detected by the Soil Doctor compared favorably with more conventional testing. He said he was optimistic about the equipment's value to agriculture.

DOC.HEAD: Moon, Mars Missions Lose to Budget Cutters
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's most ambitious space proposal - colonizing the moon and sending a manned expedition to Mars - are casualties to the deficit-cutting bill approved by Congress. Lawmakers were sympathetic to the goals in the 30-year project as it eliminated the $37 million that the administration had asked for early studies. ``It is implicit in the conduct of the nation's civil space program that such human exploration of our solar system is inevitable,'' the budget cutters said. They added that consideration of the plan was deferred ``due to budget constraints.'' In its budget bill, Congress also trimmed more than a half-billion dollars from the space station program, even as it increased the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's total budget by 13 percent over last year. Instead of the $2.4 billion that Bush sought, the station program will get $1.9 billion. Overall, the president had proposed spending $15.1 billion for NASA, an increase of 24 percent over last year. Congress cut that amount to $13.8 billion, still considerably more than the $12.2 billion of 1990. The legislators cautioned that NASA won't continue to get such increases in the future and ordered the agency to develop the station ``in useful phases'' or risk losing the $38 billion project altogether. ``The committees on appropriations have warned since the outset of this program that future budget costraints would render it virtually impossible to design, test and build the space station envisioned in 1984,'' said a report accompanying the budget bill. The station was proposed by then-President Reagan, who estimated its cost to completion at $8 billion. ``It is essential that the agency recognize that the budget crisis is only beginning,'' the report said. In the future, it said, NASA can expect annual spending growth of only 8 or 10 percent, and the amount spent on the space station should not rise above that. NASA had envisioned using 30 or so shuttle flights to assemble the station in orbit, beginning midway in the decade, but Congress said that is unrealistic given the low launch rate of recent years. Lawmakers also cut $210 million from research and technology, leaving $285 million, the same as last year. It trimmed $24 million from the $119 million requested for the National Aerospace Plane - the four-hours-to-Tokyo craft promised by Reagan - and $40 million from science projects. NASA's request for $53.9 million to design the next generation of rockets was cut by $30 million. Congress earmarked $10.5 million of the remainder for ``shuttle-C'' - in which a cargo carrier would be launched in the same manner as the shuttle is now. Congress deleted all $15 million requested to build a huge water tank in which astronauts would practice assembling the space station and cut $125 million from the $4.4 billion requested for space shuttle operations. An additional $25 million was cut from life sciences research, but Congress specifically set aside $12.1 million for ``the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.'' NASA maintains huge listening posts to detect radio signals from outer space. There was one significant addition. Congress tacked another $30 million to the $294 million Bush had requested for operating and upgrading the Hubble Space Telescope. The president had made his budget proposals early in the year, before the telescope was launched. Since then, however, the $1.5 billion instrument has proved to be fuzzy-eyed, due to a mistake in construction. The new money will provide corrective lenses on a replacement instrument that will be attached to the telescope in 1993 by astronauts.

DOC.HEAD: Ramos Jogs to the Presidency
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: At a military camp in this Mindanao island town, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos exhorted troops to defend the government against coups. But troops had another question: ``Is he campaigning for president?'' It is a question increasingly asked as the end of President Corazon Aquino's term in office, June 1992, draws nearer. Regardless of whether he is seeking the office, Ramos has emerged in public opinion surveys as a leading choice to succeed Mrs. Aquino, whom he has kept in office through seven military uprisings in four years. At this camp overlooking the Pacific, soldiers pulled aside reporters traveling with Ramos to ask: ``Is he really running?'' The 60-year-old West Point graduate avoids committing himself when asked about his possible presidential aspirations. ``Let me do my job as secretary of defense as long as I can until we have stability,'' Ramos told a local official in this seaside provincial capital 640 miles southeast of Manila. ``After that, it's up to the people.'' But Ramos' almost weekly trips to military camps throughout this archipelago nation and meetings with local officials have been widely interpreted as subtle, early campaigning. Unlike most of the nearly 10 political figures believed to have presidential ambitions, Ramos has no political party to back him. But his position as defense chief enables him to travel nationwide using government resources and to gain access to the news media whenever he wants. During his visits to the provinces, Ramos carefully avoids any criticism of the Aquino administration, which he served as military chief of staff before becoming defense secretary in January 1988. But his declarations of support contain an equally subtle message: that Mrs. Aquino - and by extension Philippine democracy - survive politically thanks to Ramos. ``I assure you that the president will be able to serve up to the last day of her term in June 1992,'' Ramos told officials here. ``I still come out with a record for the (Defense) Department she can be proud of.'' Ramos has carefully cultivated an image as the savior of democracy since he derailed an alleged coup plot by then Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile in November 1986. Critics in the military claim Ramos, son of a former foreign minister and cousin of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, was part of the conspiracy to topple Mrs. Aquino and then switched sides at the last minute. Ramos denies the charge. It is unclear where Ramos stands on a range of national issues apart from defense and security. During provincial visits, Ramos, a parachutist, scuba diver and inveterate jogger, projects an image of a vigorous leader in contrast to an incumbent president who is increasingly seen as passive and indecisive. During a recent 36-hour tour of five southern cities, Ramos attended nine public functions in three cities during the first day. The last function ended at midnight. Five hours later, Ramos was jogging with troops at Davao's Camp Catitipan. Later, he visited two more provincial cities before returning to Manila, where he addressed a civic group in the evening. Ramos also promotes an image as a strong anti-Communist and staunch opponent of those seen as sympathetic to the left. ``Sen. (Wigberto) Tanada and all these leftists should see this,'' Ramos said as he left a wake in Davao for two militiamen slain by Communist rebels. Tanada is a prominent human rights lawyer. In Dumaguete, local officials told Ramos that a court there had recently handed down the first conviction of a major Communist official on rebellion charges since Mrs. Aquino took office. ``That's very good,'' Ramos beamed. ``What's the name of the judge?'' During his stops, Ramos is warmly received by local officials, many of whom rarely see national leaders. When he arrived in Dumaguete, 400 miles southeast of Manila, Ramos was welcomed by mayor Agustin Perdices and Negros Oriental Gov. Emilio Macias who wore T-shirts saying ``Negros is for Ramos.'' But local reporters said that the day before, the same two officials were wearing T-shirts supporting presidential aspirant Eduardo Cojuangco when his brother came to town.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of Immediate Funds Will Boost Cost of S&L Bailout, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Taxpayers will have to spend millions - or even billions - of dollars more on savings and loan bailouts because Congress adjourned without providing more money for the cleanup, analysts and officials say. By the time legislators return in January the borrowing authority of the bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., could be exhausted. Even then, approval of more money is far from certain. Congress' refusal to act is ``going to cost us additional money. We're going to have to slow up the resolution of failed thrifts,'' RTC Chairman L. William Seidman said in a telephone interview Monday. But Congress did triple the amount of money for Justice Department investigations and prosecutions of S&L fraud. The crime bill passed last weekend included $160 million for Justice Department S&L investigations in this fiscal year, more than three times the $50 million allocated last year. The RTC already has postponed seeking acquirers for 18 large S&Ls, said agency spokesman Steven Katsanos. The agency has spent or committed to spend $43 billion of the $50 billion authorized in last year's S&L bailout, he said. That means the 18 institutions and more than 300 other insolvent or near-insolvent S&Ls likely will continue to run losses, funding themselves with high-interest deposits. That in turn weakens healthy competitors by forcing them to raise their deposit rates, raising the specter of additional failures. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had asked Congress for $40 billion more to cover losses through September 1991. A measure to provide $10 billion, enough to cover S&L losses through February, died in a procedural snarl early Sunday morning. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said Speaker Thomas Foley and other House leaders sought to avoid a roll call vote on the issue. In the end, because of House rules, a single objection from Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., was enough to block action. Seidman estimated the cost of a three-month delay at $250 million to $300 million. The Congressional Budget Office put it at $300 million to $400 million, while Bert Ely, a private analyst in Alexandria, Va., estimated it at $2 billion to $2.5 billion. The added cost, although spread over the life of the bailout program, will make it even harder for the government to meet the $500 billion deficit-reduction goal in the five-year program adopted over the weekend. The Sunday morning snafu left Bush administration officials and Democrats blaming each other for the expected consequences. Gonzalez said Brady's refusal to testify in support of the administration's request ``created an unfortunate atmosphere'' for approval of more money. But Desiree Tucker-Sorini, deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury, said, ``The need for action and the consequences for failing to act were spelled out in great detail over a period of months by the (Treasury) secretary and others.'' Gonzalez pledged speedy action by his committee when Congress returns. The amount of money available for S&L fraud investigations has been the subject of bitter partisan wrangling. Congress authorized $75 million last fiscal year but only appropriated $50 million when the Bush administration turned down an extra $25 million. Since 1988, federal prosecutors have obtained 338 convictions in major S&L fraud cases. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has predicted it could take another five years to clean up the growing caseload of fraud left in the wake of the widespread collapse of S&Ls. The crime bill approved by Congress contains a number of provisions to help S&L prosecutors. One would offer rewards of up to $50,000 for information leading to the prosecution of S&L fraud. Whistleblowers also would shre in a percentage of any embezzled S&L money that was recovered as a result of information they provided to help trade the funds. The crime bill also authorizes court-approved wiretaps of suspected S&L crooks and expands the number of crimes for which the Justice Department can seek forfeiture of assets in civil actions.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker Ken Burns, creator of PBS' acclaimed documentary ``The Civil War,'' blasted American television for offering ``nearly the same thing everywhere ... on dozens of clonelike channels.'' Burns told the National Press Club on Monday that ``a kind of cultural peerage'' has been conferred on a small group of TV commentators. ``Issues and ideas are merely pushed around the plate, never digested, by the same people,'' he said. ``In the worst of our television, we are addicted to personality, to the breathless embrace of celebrity, ensuring as we go a tyranny of the televised over the great mass of the un-televised.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actors Dennis Weaver and Valerie Harper have put together some of rock music's biggest names to make an album and video so they can feed more homeless. ``The sad part is, there is a need for that growth because the hungry part of our population just keeps growing,'' Weaver said Monday. Since the two actors founded Love is Feeding Everyone in 1983, LIFE has increased its number of meals in Dallas and Los Angeles from 400 per week to about 104,000. Some 26 performers, including rapper M.C. Hammer, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Little Richard plan to sing on the album's feature track, ``Raise the World.'' Weaver said he and Miss Harper hope to expand the private relief organization to other cities and raise enough to create an endowment. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Francis Ford Coppola, the meticulous director of the ``Godfather'' movies, says the much-awaited third installment about the Corleone family has finally passed muster. Paramount Pictures said Monday ``The Godfather III'' will be released on Dec. 25. Studio executives viewed an unfinished print of the film, expected to cost $50 million, over the weekend. ``After one of the most intensive production schedules in my career, I am deeply satisfied that `The Godfather Part III' has come together in a way that gives me great pride,'' Coppola said in a statement. The last chapter in Coppola's trilogy was to open Thanksgiving, but production delays forced its postponement. The first two films won nine Academy Awards and grossed $800 million. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Mary Martin, the star of such Broadway shows as ``Peter Pan,'' ``The Sound of Music'' and ``South Pacific,'' is reported to be undergoing tests at a hospital. Richard Grant, a spokesman for Miss Martin's son, actor Larry Hagman, would not disclose the reason for the tests or identify the hospital Monday. The 76-year-old actress became a star of New York theater with her 1938 appearance in the musical ``Leave It to Me.'' She also played nurse Nellie Forbush in ``South Pacific'' and Maria in ``The Sound of Music.'' She first played Peter Pan on Broadway in 1954. Miss Martin was seriously injured in a 1982 taxi-van collision that killed her manager. Actress Janet Gaynor and her husband, producer Paul Gregory, were severely injured in the crash. --- APPLE VALLEY, Calif. (AP) - Cowboy star Roy Rogers is back on his feet after surgery to repair a weakened artery, his son says. The 77-year-old actor got out of bed Monday and walked without assistance for the first time since the operation Oct. 21, said Roy ``Dusty'' Rogers Jr. ``His oxygen hose only went 15 feet and he said, `This is boring, going out only as far as your hose will take you,' '' the younger Rogers said. Rogers starred in 87 Westerns, 35 with his wife, Dale Evans. He was hospitalized at St. Mary Desert Valley Hospital after complaining of stomach pain. He underwent surgery to correct an aneurysm, or weak spot, in his aorta, the body's main artery. Since Rogers was hospitalized, more than 400 well-wishers have called the Roy Rogers-Dale Evens Museum in Victorville and 1,000 have sent cards and letters, Dusty Rogers said.

DOC.HEAD: Educator, Businessman Call for National Standards
DOC.TEXT: States should have a ``national education index'' to measure student achievement and pinpoint failing schools or ineffective local leaders, a top educator says. With a benchmark to measure education progress, states would have license to place failing schools on probation, remove principals or school boards or even close ineffective schools, Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, said Monday. ``Local school control is crucial, but it's insufficient. In the end, students must be served, and if a school, for whatever reason, does not provide an effective education, state officials have both a legal and moral obligation to intervene,'' Boyer told a Fortune magazine seminar of about 300 businessmen, government leaders and educators. As an extension of the education index idea, William ``Jerry'' Hume, head of American Foods Inc. of San Francisco, suggested creating an employability skills scale for potential employees. ``This matrix would define the job applicant's academic skill level on a one-to-five scale for reading, computation, writing, problem-solving and critical reasoning and scientific reasoning,'' Hme said. Such a scale would define the individual's skill level on a basic, intermediate and advanced level for organizational effectiveness and leadership, social and teamwork skills, motivation and self-development, listening and oral communication and learning skills, he said. ``As a businessman, I would like to have standards for the United States which define educational outcomes for this country that are superior to outcomes attained by students in countries with which we compete,'' said Hume. ``As a businessman I would like to have a student transcript that shows a student's accomplishments vs. national standards.'' Boyer insisted the nation is ``more than ready for a national policy in education. ... After years of vigorously defending local school control, the nation is now supporting - indeed almost demanding - national leadership in education, while still maintaining vitality at the local level. ``It's time to go beyond goals - important as they are - and begin to talk more precisely about education standards and how progress toward national objectives can be measured.'' State must have clearly defined goals, an assessment procedure requiring annual progress reports from schools, and clearly defined methods of intervention in case a school is failing, Boyer said. Besides accountability and intervention, the foundation president said, the index also should include: -School completion rates of students in every state. This category would include a look at each student's proficiency in English and mathematics, performance on general knowledge tests and whether a state gives priority to writing. -The condition of teaching. States would be judged on whether they have a plan for attracting outstanding students into teaching, special strategies to attract teachers in math and science and requirements for training that include sabbaticals, fellowships and teacher institutes. Teacher salaries also would be considered. -The schools' climate as it relates to the quality of buildings, classrooms and laboratories, as well as class size. -Financial support of schools. States' per-student expenditures and other costs would be compared regionally so that cost-of-living can be considered. Equity in school finance would be a key consideration. -How schools are governed. States must have clearly defined goals, as well as intervention methods in case of a failing school.

DOC.HEAD: `Graveyard Shift' Buries Competitors at Box Office
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Cashing in on the pre-Halloween thirst for a thriller, ``Stephen King's Graveyard Shift'' opened in first place at the box office over the weekend, selling $5.1 million in tickets. The new Kirstie Alley comedy, ``Sibling Rivalry,'' took in $4 million and came in second, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. Third was the Susan Sarandon-James Spader romance ``White Palace'' with $3.45 million. Fourth was Steven Seagal's ``Marked for Death.'' The karate-adventure film made $3.43 million, falling from first place after three weeks. The other-worldly love story ``Ghost'' was No. 5 with $3.08 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Graveyard Shift,'' Paramount, $5.1 million, 1,603 screens, $3,170 per screen, $5.1 million, one week. 2. ``Sibling Rivalry,'' Columbia, $4 million, 1,448 screens, $2,775 per screen, $4 million, one week. 3. ``White Palace,'' Universal, $3.45 million, 864 screens, $3,990 per screen, $5 million, three weeks. 4. ``Marked for Death,'' 20th Century Fox, $3.43 million, 1,654 screens, $2,071 per screen, $33.9 million, four weeks. 5. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $3.08 million, 1,766 screens, $1,742 per screen, $176.5 million, 16 weeks. 6. ``Memphis Belle,'' Warner Bros., $3.07 million, 1,332 screens, $2,301 per screen, $15.5 million, three weeks. 7. ``Quigley Down Under,'' MGM-UA, $2.7 million, 1,094 screens, $2,049 per screen, $7.7 million, two weeks. 8. ``Avalon,'' Tri-Star, $2.1 million, 635 screens, $3,325 per screen, $6.5 million, four weeks. 9. ``Fantasia,'' Disney, $2 million, 481 screens, $4,187 per screen, $17.9 million, four wees. 10. ``Mr. Destiny,'' Disney, $1.9 million, 1,025 screens, $1,854 per screen, $9.2 million, three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurant Leftovers Feeding the Nation's Hungry
LaserPhoto RM1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of homeless and hungry Americans are getting their daily meals from restaurants and caterers instead of trash cans. At least 40 cities across the nation have launched programs to put leftovers to use, according to Share Our Strength, a Washington group that is waging a campaign to fight food waste. Prepared food left at the end of the day at deli counters, banquets, restaurants and executive dining rooms is picked up and distributed to shelters and soup kitchens. ``What's the point of throwing away all this wonderful food when you could feed it to hunger relief agencies in your city?'' asked Jennifer Hadley, coordinator of the campaign. ``These people are hungry. And it's better to get food served from a catering company than to pick it out of a trash can. ``The beauty of it is our country is concentrating a lot on environmental issues and recycling, and this applies to food as well.'' The programs must adhere to strict health guidelines. No table scraps are allowed, nor foods that are good candidates for contamination, such as mayonnaise- or seafood-based salads. ``If I couldn't take it out of my refrigerator at home and feed it to my granddaughter, I'm not going to give it to somebody else,'' said Jo Anna L. DeBolt, who runs the Richmond program that was modeled on programs in Norfolk and Atlanta. ``And if I'm not sure the agency is going to serve it in a timely manner or have it refrigerated correctly or frozen correctly, then I'm not going to be able to give it to them.'' Caterers and some of the larger hotels with convention center business had so much in leftovers that they were embarrassed, said Rob Johnson, project director of the Atlanta Community Food Bank program. ``We have about 150 donors of food that include restaurants, caterers, hotels, corporate cafeterias, schools and hospitals,'' said Johnson, whose Atlanta's Table was launched in 1987. ``We are now averaging about 30,000 pounds of food each month.'' During its first month of operation in September, the Central Virginia Food Bank distributed more than 7,000 pounds of food, or about 7,000 meals, to nine organizations through Virginia's Table. Most of that came from the deli counters at 20 Richmond-area grocery stores, Ms. DeBolt said. Cooked chicken breasts, rolls of salami, bologna, fettucine and crepes have been donated, she said. For restaurateurs and caterers afraid of being sued if someone gets sick, Ms. Hadley said all 50 states have adopted good Samaritan laws that offer varying degrees of protection to those who donate food in good faith. ``Not once in the 10 years since the laws have been implemented has there been one suit. It has a great track record,'' she said. While Virginia's Table picks up and delivers donated food, the D.C. Central Kitchen in Washington goes a step further. People are trained in the art of cooking. They prepare meals from leftover food. ``Instead of being a crutch, it ends up being a bridge for them from one part of the community into another one,'' Ms. DeBolt said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Criticizes Decision to Allow Dugan to Retire at Higher Pay
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is begrudgingly allowing Gen. Michael Dugan, relieved as Air Force chief of staff for his public comments on the Persian Gulf, to delay his retirement until Jan. 1 and boost his pension by more than $17,000 a year. Over the weekend, the Senate Armed Services Committee and the full Senate approved President Bush's nomination of Dugan to retire in the grade of full general. However, in a report accompanying the panel's recommendation and released Monday, the committee questioned the extraordinary treatment of Dugan. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney fired Dugan, 53, as the Air Force's top officer on Sept. 17 after Dugan told reporters about contingency plans to unleash massive air raids on Iraq and target Saddam Hussein personally. Under current law, Dugan would have been demoted two pay grades to major general 90 days after his firing and would have been retired on Dec. 17 with benefits based on the lower rank. However, Bush nominated him to retire at four-star rank on Jan. 1. ``The primary reason for allowing Gen. Dugan to retire on Jan. 1, 1991, is to permit him to take advantage of the increase in the basic pay for the grade of general upon which his retired pay would be calculated,'' the committee said. A four-star general's basic annual pay goes from $78,199 to $97,814 on Jan. 1, and retirement as a full general on that day will mean an increase in Dugan's pension of $17,625 over what he would have received in retirement in 1990 as a major general. Earlier, when Dugan's firing was announced, Pentagon officials estimated his pension at $60,000 in the four-star rank, if he retired then. Although the committee acknowledged Dugan's 32 years of distinguished services, it strongly disagreed with Cheney's decision to keep Dugan on active duty beyond the 90 days. Dugan remains at the Pentagon as a special assistant to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice. He is overseeing studies on the future needs for pilots and navigators as well as the officer evaluation system. ``The committee is concerned not only about the circumvention of the generous 90-day transition period, but the effect that such a favored decision for one senior officer could have on the perception of all other military personnel of the fairness and integrity of the personnel system,'' the Senate panel said. Some other generals are being retired before Jan. 1, and are not eligible for the higher retired pay, the committee said.

DOC.HEAD: Americans May Still be Held in Southeast Asia, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: A congessional staff report conducted for Sen. Jesse Helms questions the government's long-held contention that no Americans who fought in the Vietnam war are still being held captive in Southeast Asia. The interim report, released Monday, contends that the Pentagon adopted its position about missing Americans and then discredited evidence to the contrary. Information ``uncovered during this inquiry provides enough corroboration to cast doubt upon the veracity of the U.S. government's conclusion,'' said the report by the Republican staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The government has contended there is no evidence that American prisoners are still alive in Southeast Asia - or that any were left behind alive after U.S. prisoners returned in 1973. But the staff said, ``Classified, declassified and unclassified information all confirm one startling fact: That the Defense Department in April 1974 concluded beyond a doubt that several hundred living American POWs remained in captivity in Southeast Asia.'' The information also does not rule out the likelihood that Americans are still being held, the report said. A Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Ken Satterfield, said the department had not received the new report and had no comment. The report said defense intelligence discredited - often in error - live-sighting reports about U.S. personnel from hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos during the 1970s and 1980s. It also contended that some witnesses may have been intimidated and that information was dismissed on technicalities. Since the fall of Saigon in 1975, the Defense Intelligence Agency has received nearly 12,000 reports on missing Americans, most of them from Indochinese refugees. None has panned out thus far, the Pentagon has said. The report disagrees with the findings of a House select committee, which concluded a year after the war ended that there were no POWs being held. However, that panel said a small number of deserters or civilians might have voluntarily stayed behind. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., ranking GOP member on the Foreign Relations Committee and a critic of the improving relations between the United States and Vietnam, asked the panel's minority staff to conduct the study. The government considers 2,103 personnel missing since U.S. forces withdrew from Southeast Asia nearly 20 years ago. More than 55,000 Americans died in the war. The number of military personnel missing in action could be higher because the Defense Department's files on various covert actions during the war have not been opened and those who took part were never identified, the report said. The release of the report comes nearly two weeks after Vietnam promised to increase cooperation with the United States on an accounting of American servicemen still missing. Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach, who met with President Bush's special envoy for the MIA issue, said both sides agreed to accelerate their efforts to locate missing Americans. In a letter accompanying the report, Helms said Thach's visit was inappropriate at a time when the administration was unwilling to address the issue of living Americans being held captive in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Five Debates Scheduled This Week for Congressional Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Challengers in political races frequently complain that the incumbent won't agree to debates. But that's no problem in the race between U.S. Rep. Jim Jontz and his Republican challenger, John Johnson. The two will debate five times - this week. There will be debates on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, plus two on Friday, said Scott Campbell, Jontz's press secretary. The candidates already have debated five times. Four debates were canceled while Jontz was in Washington for work on the federal budget. Congress adjourned early Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Does Martinez Ad on Eve of Debate With Chiles
DOC.TEXT: First Lady Barbara Bush took to the airwaves in support of GOP Gov. Bob Martinez, who is in a neck-and-neck race with Democrat Lawton Chiles. In a new Martinez television ad, Mrs. Bush says she cares about the race because she has family in the Sunshine State.
