Son Jeb Bush of Miami is the governor's campaign chairman and the president's mother, Dorothy Walker Bush, is a wintertime resident of Hobe Sound. ``I can't vote for Bob Martinez, but I wish I could - and I hope you will,'' says Mrs. Bush, a snapshot of President Bush visible on a shelf behind her. Mrs. Bush credited Martinez for his support of the 1989 law that toughened sentences for anyone convicted of a drug crime within 1,000 feet of a public school. She also appears to allude to the 60-year-old Chiles' decision to leave the Senate in 1988 because of burnout. ``He's (Martinez) got the strength and energy a governor needs to fight crime and drugs,'' she says. Chiles shrugged off the first lady's ad. ``I think Barbara's a neat lady. I'd like her to be speaking for me,'' Chiles said.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Was Raped Criticizes Williams
DOC.TEXT: A woman blasted Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams after being sexually assaulted by a man who repeated Williams' joke about rape. Chris Ausland ``had quoted Clayton Williams during the attack, telling me that if it was inevitable, I should just relax and enjoy it,'' the 31-year-old woman said Monday of the March assault. Williams made the rape remark during a cattle roundup at his ranch when he likened bad weather to rape. He later apologized for the comment. Ausland, 34, was sentenced Monday in state district court to 50 years in prison in a plea bargain agreement on several charges. The woman, trembling as she spoke, talked with reporters on the condition her identity not be revealed. ``Any candidate who jokes about rape shows a gross insensitivity towards women and is not likely to take a stand in promoting victims' rights,'' she said. ``Speaking from personal experience, rape is anything but a joke and at no point Mr. Williams was I able to relax and enjoy it,'' she added. She said she did not blame Williams for the attack, but said ``I just blame Clayton Williams for voicing the attitude that is outdated and is wrong and is hurtful.'' Gordon Hensley, a spokesman for the Williams campaign, said Williams had apologized for the remark and that the Republican's anti-crime proposals are stronger than those of his Democratic opponent, Ann Richards.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Apologizes For Mistaken Leaflet Describing Him as Incumbent
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Anthony Castagno isn't an incumbent and he wants everyone to know it. Castagno mistakenly sent a mailing to nearly 30,000 households asking them to ``re-elect Senator Tony Castagno.'' That prompted him to issue an unusual press release that began: ``Oops.'' ``I know there's not a real friendly feeling toward incumbents these days,'' he explained. ``So it's not in my best interest to pretend that I am.'' His Republican opponent, Edward Munster, said Castagno might benefit from the mistake. Munster said he would ask the secretary of the state's office whether the false mailing violated state law. ``I was appalled when I saw it,'' Munster said. ``Once a bell is rung, it's hard to unring it.''
DOC.HEAD: Williams Pumps $1.4 Million More into Campaign, Outspends Richards
DOC.TEXT: Republican Clayton Williams has spent about $20.4 million on the Texas governor's race, including $8 million of his own money, according to campaign records. His Democratic opponent, Ann Richards, has spent about $11.7 million. In the 30-day campaign finance report submitted Monday to the secretary of state, Williams reported raising about $3.75 million, including $1.4 from his ranching and oil fortune and $225,000 in loans from financial institutions. Williams spent almost $4.42 million from Sept. 28 to Oct. 27 , the period covered by the report. Richards reported contributions of about $1.83 million, including $175,000 in loans, and expenditures of nearly $2.26 million during the 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: President Lays Nation's Woes to Democrats
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, unveiling a harsh partisan political attack a week before the election, says he will travel the country telling voters to blame Democrats for the nation's troubles. With the Republican Party stumbling toward Election Day and his own public approval ratings in a nosedive, Bush on Monday launched an all-out attack on Democrats in Congress. The Democrats, he said, were interested in only two things - ``taxing and spending.'' In a speech heavily geared toward repairing the damage the GOP has suffered because of public discontent with the budget quagmire and the weakening economy, Bush said he had to ``pay ransom'' to the Democratic-run Congress in the form of higher taxes in order to get spending cuts. ``We stopped them cold,'' from passing even higher taxes, he claimed. Trying out his new speech at an Oklahoma City fund-raiser for gubernatorial candidate Bill Price, Bush called for election of more Republicans. The president suffered many defections by House and Senate Republicans who voted against his position in the recent budget battle and criticized him for abandoning his ``no new taxes'' pledge. ``The problem is this Democratic Congress that protects its perks and privileges and turns its back on the American dream,'' Bush said. He was to make a similar address today in Washington to a partisan crowd gathered by the Republican National Committee, and take a cross-country political swing later in the week. The president blamed the Democrats for everything from being soft on crime to playing ``class warfare'' with the budget negotiations, to passing ``feel-good proclamations'' instead of addressing real problems. ``America doesn't need a liberal House of Lords. America needs a responsible Congress. America needs a Republican Congress,'' he said. The Democrats, who unsuccessfully tried to pass a stiff surtax on millionaires, have seized on the budget turmoil to paint Republicans as defenders of the rich. ``I'm used to that kind of demagoguery and so I'm out here now on the campaign trail laying it to rest,'' Bush said. ``I've got to get that in focus because they've been getting away with this tax-the-rich, class warfare kind of garbage that they always resurrect at election time. ``I'm taking that message all across this country. ... We are for the working people of this country,'' he said. Continuing to try and distance himself from the tax-raising portion of the new budget package that he has promised to sign, Bush said: ``I cannot join the liberal Democrats in an orgy of self-congratulation. ``I think people know that this Congress is controlled by the taxers, by the liberal Democrats.'' He said Republicans saved Americans from a Democratic plot to raise taxes on working people in the guise of soaking the rich. In the budget negotiations, Bush ultimately agreed to raise the tax rate on the highest income brackets to 31 percent, from 28 percent now. The package also diminishes the ability of high-income taxpayers to take itemized deductions. Bush earlier Monday claimed to take no notice of public opinion polls saying he has slid to a 48 percent approval rating. He said at the Oklahoma event that he had tried his best to work with Congress and do the job people elected him to do. ``I've tried very hard, only to have a parade of liberal Democrats march to the microphone in the House of Representatives to blame me for their failure,'' he contended. In a homestretch effort to swing votes for Republicans, Bush leaves Thursday for Massachusetts, Florida and Ohio. He then travels to Minnesota, Iowa, California and Texas before returning to Washington on Tuesday, Election Day.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Bill a Boon to Irish
DOC.TEXT: The prospects of legal citizenship for thousands of illegal Irish immigrants are about to improve. Immigration reform legislation awaiting President Bush's signature will provide thousands of extra residency visas to Ireland. An estimated 100,000 Irish immigrants live illegally in the United States, and tens of thousands more are hoping to leave their economically strapped country. ``It's just a fact of life that a lot of young and skilled people are going to leave Ireland anyway,'' Sean Minihane, a lobbyist for the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, said Monday. ``Why not, from the standpoint of the U.S., shouldn't they be allowed to come in?'' The visas would be available to those living in Ireland or illegal aliens living in the United States. The change in U.S. policy toward Irish immigration is contained in the first comprehensive immigration reform bill in 25 years. The bill, passed by Congress this weekend, would substantially boost the number of immigrants allowed into the United States each year, especially those with job skills. Bush supports the legislation. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the bill could be signed into law as early as this week. For the Irish, the bill could provide more than 80,000 permanent residency visas by the turn of the century. That's roughly double the number of Irish visas granted throughout the 1980s. Existing immigration law has cut off the supply of visas granted to Ireland at well below the actual demand. The current formulas favor visa applicants who have recent-immigrant relatives already living in the United States - countries such as Cambodia, Vietnam and Mexico. Irish illegal aliens are concentrated in the Boston and New York metropolitan areas. Other pockets of Irish residents include Chicago, Hartford, Conn., Philadelphia and San Francisco. Irish advocates celebrating passage of the immigration bill told of the hardships brought on by illegal status: immigrants unable attend a family funeral in Ireland for fear they would be forced to stay; skilled professionals forced to tend bar because they could not enter the job market; tenants unable to challenge a rent increase because the landlord threatened to turn them in. In Ireland, the education system is turning out skilled graduates to an economy with 17 percent unemployment. ``By most economic forecasts, we will be stuck with the problem of emigration until the next decade,'' said an Irish embassy official who asked not to be identified. ``We are providing new jobs but not at a fast enough rate.'' The official said the Irish government is ``delighted'' with the bill. For the next three years, Ireland would be the only country with a guaranteed number of visas - 16,000 per year for a total of 48,000. Starting in 1995, up to 7,700 Irish would receive visas annually under a ``diversity'' provision of the bill designed to offset the unfairness of past immigration formulas. In addition, Irish could apply under the traditional categories of family ties and employment. The maximum allowable total for any country is 20,000. Those numbers compare to the roughly 3,000 to 5,000 Irish visas issued per year in the early 1980s. For the past five years, the number has averaged 5,000 to 7,500.

DOC.HEAD: European Community Agrees On Carbon Dioxide Emissions Cap
DOC.TEXT: In a commitment to curb global warming, the 12-nation European Community has pledged to limit its output of carbon dioxide emissions in the year 2000 to the 1990 level. The move Monday by EC ministers was seen as an attempt to pressure the United States into a adopting a similar pledge at a major international conference on the issue. Next week, negotiations open in Geneva on a convention aimed at curbing the release of carbon dioxide and other man-made gases that are causing a gradual increase in global temperature - with potentially catastrophic environmental implications. Plans call for the drafting of a convention that would to be ready for signing in 1992. The United States has yet to issue a proposal on how it plans curb its carbon dioxide emissions - produced largely through the burning of fossil fuels. ``A divided European Community would have been an excuse for the Americans not to proceed any further,'' said a European Community source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Scientists believe that if nothing is done to curb them, emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases could boost global temperatures 5.4 degrees by the end of the next century, the fastest rise in 10,000 years. They call the phenomenon the greenhouse effect, and say that if unchecked it could cause sea levels to rise and deserts to spread. About 500 scientists convened in Geneva on Monday for a 10-day U.N. conference on global warming. A conference-ending meeting of about 80 ministers is expected to draw several heads of government, including British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French Premier Michel Rocard. The United States has sent a lower-level delegation. The EC's position to maintain its overall output of carbon dioxide at 1990 levels in 2000 matches a pledge by Japan. In the European Community, these emissions come largely from coal-fired power plants and traffic and grow at a rate of between 2 percent and 4 percent a year, officials said. The 1990 level is almost 3 billion tons. The EC executive commission will work out quotas for each member nations by the end of this year. The community's richest members, such as Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Germany, France and Denmark, will have to compensate for those members less able to do so, officials said. The latter include Britain, which has a disproportionately large number of coal-fired power plants, and the community's poorer southern nations. The EC states agreed on a general commitment to save energy, promote public transportation and encourage use of alternative energy sources. Opening the Geneva conference on Monday, the top U.N. environmental official, Mostafa K. Tolba, urged industrial nations to take immediate steps to curb global warming. Tolba said a complete change in attitudes and living habits is needed to avert a danger ``potentially more catastrophic than any other threat in human history.'' He said that only drastic reductions in emissions of ``greenhouse gases'' will stop warming of the planet.

DOC.HEAD: Small Operator Companies Due for New Regulations To Stem Abuses
DOC.TEXT: A federal law going into effect next month clamps new controls on companies that sometimes charge telephone users at airports, hotels and other public places two or three times what they normally pay for long-distance calls. As of Nov. 17, the so-called alternative operator service companies will be required to clearly identify themselves during calls, provide rates and billing procedures on demand, stop charging for unanswered calls and allow some access to the interstate long-distance company that callers wish to use. The Federal Communications Commission, which already had instituted many of these rules but had found widespread lack of compliance, also will be required to begin monitoring the rates these companies charge. If the commission finds the rates unjust, it could order them rolled back. The FCC also is empowered to establish rates for the entire industry in about two years. The operator service companies handle ``dial-O'' calls, such as collect, person-to-person and charge card calls made by the traveling public. These companies contract with the owners of phones at hotels, universities, airports, hospitals and other public places to handle their long-distance service and then lease lines on carriers such as AT&T, MCI and US Sprint. Callers often are unaware when they dial a phone away from home that they're using one of the operator companies. Many callers have complained of excessive charges and billings from cities they've never visited. The FCC says it receives more complaints about operator services companies than any other telephone issue - about 150 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Unyielding in Interview
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT Cables to Cable
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says his talks with a Soviet envoy were useful, but that the results will not necessarily become known publicly. In an interview with Cable News Network correspondents in Baghdad aired Monday night, Saddam also reiterated his determination to maintain control of Kuwait. ``Meetings are always useful,'' Saddam said of his discussions with Yevgeny M. Primakov, Middle East adviser to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Primakov has been reported as saying his discussions with Saddam produced little movement, but Gorbachev has said there were signs of flexibility on Saddam's part. Saddam called his discussions with Primakov ``wide-ranging and very useful,'' but said the first statements would have to come from Primakov. ``Not everything that was agreed will come out in the open,'' Saddam said. As he has in the past, Saddam said his troops have no intention of leaving Kuwait, which they occupied on Aug. 2. And any fighting, he said, would be the result of what he called aggression by the United States, Britain or Israel. Saddam also insisted again that the Arab nations' problems be resolved as a whole, not piecemeal, and linked resolution of the Palestinian issue to the Kuwait crisis. The Iraqi leader said he hoped war would not break out and ``if the Americans were to opt away from war, then they will establish a strong position for itself and humanity.'' But he said Iraq and Iran were ``the only armies with wide experience in fighting wars'' in the Persian Gulf region. Saddam appeared relaxed and smiled on occasion during the CNN interview. He wore a civilian coat and tie. At one point he was asked if he would enjoy fishing with President Bush, a sport both men are fond of. ``I have no objection to looking into this proposition,'' Saddam said. But he said he would like a meeting with Bush only if it meant a substantive discussion.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Agency Warns Of Injuries From ``Slap-Wrist'' Bracelet
DOC.TEXT:
A popular toy known as the ``slap-wrist'' bracelet may cause hand and wrist injuries to children, says the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The wrist bracelet is a thin strip of metal covered by woven fabric or paper. The commission said Monday it is concerned that the fabric or paper covering the thin metal may tear over time, exposing the user to a sharp metal edge. The panel said parents should alert children to the potential danger and should examine the toys frequently.
---
DOC.HEAD: FDA Moves To Ban Ingredients In Diet Drugs
DOC.TEXT:
The Food and Drug Administration wants to ban the use of 111 ingredients in non-prescription diet drug products, including one it says presents a safety hazard. That ingredient is guar gum, which is extracted from plant matter. Three months ago, FDA told the distributor of one brand of diet tablet, Cal Ban 3000, that contains guar gum to stop distributing the tablets because it had received 17 reports of users suffering from obstruction of the esophagus. Aside from those tablets, the agency did not give brand names of products affected. The action does not affect guar gum use in small amounts in foods where it poses no health hazard, foods such as cheese, salad dressings and ice cream, the agency said. The agency said the 111 ingredients had not been proven effective in diet products. The ban includes alcohol, corn syrup, dextrose, kelp, pineapple enzymes, rice polishings, saccharin, salt, sodium bicarbonate, vitamin C and wheat germ. FDA said it had given manufacturers opportunities to prove the ingredients were effective but that it had received no significant information. The proposed ban is being published in today's Federal Register along with another proposed ruling tht calls for a warning on general over-the-counter drugs containing water soluble gums like guar gum. Products containing such substances, including guar gum, psyllium, and the like, would have to carry labels warning users to take them with adequate fluid and to avoid them if the user had ever had difficulty swallowing.
---
DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Drops Non-Obscenity Pledge
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has quietly dropped a controversial requirement that grant recipients sign a non-obscenity pledge, now that Congress has voted to scrap explicit restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for federal subsidies. The pledge, instituted by endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer late last year, has spawned three federal lawsuits charging that it violated the Constitution's free-speech guarantees. At last count, 16 artists and arts institutions refused to sign the pledge and forfeited more than $318,000 in endowment grants last year. The endowment made no formal announcement of Monday's action, but agency officials confirmed that the pledge had been withdrawn and would not be required as a condition of receiving grants for the 1991 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. Shortly before it adjourned last weekend, Congress junked the obscenity ban it imposed on the arts endowment a year ago and voted instead to leave judgments of obscenity to the courts. The proposed new law awaiting President Bush's signature would require the endowment to recoup its grant money from any recipient who is later convicted of violating obscenity laws. The bill omits any explicit obscenity restrictions, saying only that obscenity lacks artistic merit, is not protected speech under the Constitution and ``shall not be funded'' by the endowment.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Nikkei Declines
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the yen in active trading today, while the weaker yen and higher oil prices helped push down share prices. The dollar closed at 129.00 yen, up 1.65 yen from Monday's close of 127.35 yen. It opened at 128.95 yen and ranged between 128.80 yen and 129.80 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 25,242.40, down 86.91 points, or 0.34 percent, from Monday's finish of 25,329.31. The key index gained 323.67 points Monday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 400 million shares, down from Monday's 500 million shares. Dealers said the yen's decline and higher oil prices discouraged investors interest. North Sea Brent crude oil for December delivery was valued at $34.85 to $34.95 a barrel at 4 p.m., about 85 cents above late Monday levels in New York. In bond trading, the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds were quoted at 84.84 points at 5 p.m., down from 84.94 points late Monday. Their yield rose to 7.735 percent from 7.710 percent. The dollar's advance followed a rally in New York, where it closed at 128.65 yen Monday, up from 128.25 yen on Friday. Dealers said trading was active. Spot transactions totaled $14.842 billion, well up from Monday's $4.371 billion and also above last Friday's $10.605 billion. ``The dollar is changing hands in a range, and it is near the top of the range today,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a trader with Chemical Bank. Ms. Takeuchi said the U.S. Federal Reserve's reduction in the federal funds rate from 8 percent to 7.75 percent Monday did not affect the Tokyo market much. ``We had been anticipating an easing since mid-August, when the move surfaced,'' she said. Besides, she said, it was seen as a less aggressive move than expected to ease monetary policy in the United States. Lower interest rates usually tend to push down the dollar because they diminish the value of dollar-denominated securities. When the dollar surged to the upper 129-yen level in afternoon trading, Japanese institutional investors began converting dollars to yen, taking profits on the dollar's rise, dealers said. But purchases by oil companies paying dollars for petroleum helped the U.S. currency, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Game 8 of Chess Match Adjourned
With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: The eighth game of the world chess championship was adjourned until tonight with experts saying a series of seemingly bad moves by titleholder Garry Kasparov had given Anatoly Karpov the edge. Play resumes at 5:30 p.m., when Kasparov's 41st move is to be unsealed. The players are tied 3{-3{ in points. A player gets one point for a victory, a half point for a tie. The first player to reach 12{ points wins the championship. Each player has won one game; the other games ended in draws. Kasparov appeared to have the advantage most of the time Monday, but experts said he left Karpov in a better position by the time the game was adjourned. ``Everyone was shocked and staring in complete amazement,'' international master Alex Fishbein said of the turnaround. ``Karpov was brilliant in defense, extraordinary. His tactics were very strong in time pressure and his nerves were very good. This is a devastating blow to Kasparov.'' Others said Kasparov could still salvage a draw. Karpov was under severe time pressure. After 27 moves, he had only five minutes left for his next 13 moves, while Kasparov had 33 minutes to go. Each player is allotted 2{ hours to make his first 40 moves. ``It's unbelievable how bad Kasparov played in the time scramble and how well Karpov played,'' said grandmaster Michael Wilder. ``At one point, it looked as though he (Kasparov) was making completely random moves.'' The first 12 games are being played in New York and the remainder will be played in Lyon, France. The winner will get $1.7 million, the loser $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Lottery Ticket Left as Bar Tip Produces $25,000
DOC.TEXT: There are big tippers - and then there are those who leave $25,000, even though they might not know it. Just ask Keith Thomlinson, a bartender at the Greenhouse Inn and Restaurant in Middletown. He found an instant lottery ticket among his tips last week. When he scratched off the numbers, he had won $25,000. ``It sat there for almost two days until I scrubbed it off,'' Thomlinson, 42, said Monday. ``I was just shocked.'' The ticket came from Russell Clark of Newport, a regular at the Greenhouse who often leaves an instant lottery ticket with a dollar or two as a tip at area restaurants and bars. He said he often leaves candy or flowers, too. ``It's just something I do,'' he said. Thomlinson gave $1,800 to Clark and $5,000 to his mother and father. ``She's going to pay bills,'' Thomlinson said. ``Dad's retired. They don't have a real big pension.'' Clark, 60, a lab technician in Newport, said he probably would use his $1,800 to buy more lottery tickets for his friends in the restaurants. He has an informal agreement with the waiters and bartenders that if they win more than $600, he gets a cut. Clark said that in the 10 years he had been handing out tickets, a waitress once won $500.

DOC.HEAD: Carlson May be Only Choice for State GOP
With PM-Minnesota Sleaze, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite their distaste for Arne Carlson, members of Minnesota's conservative Republican Party say they may have no choice but to back him as their replacement nominee for governor this close to the election. Carlson, the state auditor, is considered too liberal by some Republicans to replace Jon Grunseth, who dropped out Sunday after being accused of philandering and swimming nude with teen-age girls. Grunseth denied the allegations. Carlson, a Republican who favors abortion rights, had jumped into the race last week as a write-in candidate as pressure mounted on Grunseth to step down. Carlson said he is confident party leaders will conclude that he should be on the ballot to face Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich on Nov. 6. The party's 14-member executive committee meets tonight to discuss whether it even has the authority to name a successor to Grunseth. Today's Star Tribune reported eight members of the executive committee said they either will support Carlson or are leaning that way. Others said having Carlson as the party's choice is inevitable. ``I think we do have to be realistic and realize that it's too late to force another candidate on the ballot,'' said Evie Axdahl, a committee member. ``I feel that's the only choice at this point and I think that's unfortunate.'' Secretary of State Joan Growe said if the party does not reach a decision, the law calls for the runner-up in the primary - Carlson - to go on the ballot. State GOP Chairwoman Barb Sykora said she has concluded that ``the only sensible option is the option that looks like we are legally bound to - support Arne Carlson to the best of our ability and beat Rudy Perpich.'' Growe, the state's chief election office, said Republicans have until 5 p.m. Friday to get a new candidate on the ballot. But she urged GOP leaders to decide as quickly as possible to allow more time to print an estimated 2 million ballots. Another complication involved Grunseth's running mate, who did not file papers withdrawing from the race for lieutenant governor. ``As far as we're concerned, she is the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor,'' said Elam Baer, executive director of the Grunseth campaign. But Growe said her office has concluded Clark no longer is a candidate because of Grunseth's withdrawal. ``Since state law requires you to be a team, there no longer is a team,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: William French Smith, Reagan's First Attorney General, Dies at 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `A specialist ...' to ADD dates of service, succeeded by Meese.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: William French Smith, who as Ronald Reagan's personal lawyer helped guide him to the White House and then worked to carry out the Reagan Revolution as the president's first attorney general, has died at 73. Smith, who died of cancer Monday, helped lead the administration's conservative shift on such issues as civil rights and corporate mergers. ``William French Smith served his country with the greatest dedication and distinction,'' Reagan said in a statement. ``As attorney general, he brought talent, wisdom, and the highest integrity to the Department of Justice. ``Nancy and I are deeply saddened today,'' Reagan said. ``We have lost a dear friend, who we will always remember with the greatest respect and affection.'' Born in Wilton, N.H., to an aristocratic Yankee family, Smith pursued a career in corporate law, leaving New England behind for Los Angeles. A Navy officer during World War II, Smith later became Reagan's personal attorney, helping guide investments that made the former actor a millionaire. Smith served as informal chairman of Reagan's so-called kitchen cabinet, a group of California millionaires who saw Reagan socially and helped his quest for the governorship, and finally, the presidency in 1980. Others in the group included Justin Dart, Walter Annenberg, Verne Orr, William Clark, Alfred Bloomingdale and Holmes Tuttle. A specialist in corporate labor relations, Smith was managing partner of the law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher when Reagan named him the nation's 74th attorney general in 1981. Smith served until 1985 and was succeeded by Edwin Meese III. Among the policy changes in which he played a key role were the appointment of the first woman to the Supreme Court, Sandra Day O'Connor; legislation overturning a 100-year-old ban on military aid to civilian law enforcement; relaxation of rules against corporate mergers, which had not been changed in 15 years, and halting the Justice Department's advocacy of mandatory busing to desegregate schools and of hiring and promotion goals to remedy job discrimination. His relaxation of antitrust enforcement infuriated consumers and liberal Democrats. Black groups and women's organizations were outraged by his civil rights policies. They prevailed in Congress over hisopposition to toughening the Voting Rights Act and in court over his unprecedented effort to give tax exemptions to racially discriminatory private schools. Smith's personal finances and patrician style also drew attacks. Career department attorneys jeered his establishment of a second private dining room at the Justice Department and his regular appearances on the Washington social circuit. In 1982, Democrats, including Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, criticized his investment in two oil and gas tax shelters and his acceptance of a $50,000 severance payment when he left the board of the Earle M. Jorgensen Steel Co. to become attorney general. Smith agreed to return the $50,000 and limit his tax deductions in the two ventures. Smith is survived by his wife, Jean; three sons; a daughter; a stepson; a stepdaughter, and seven grandchildren. Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Fail To Repair Broken Hatch
DOC.TEXT: Soviet cosmonauts, working in open space for nearly four hours, failed today in an attempt to repair a malfunctioning hatch aboard the Mir space station, the official Tass news agency said. Cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov, who have been in space for nearly three months, left the spacecraft at 45 minutes past midnight to work on the door, which failed to close properly during a spacewalk in July. ``They did not manage to correct the hatch malfunction,'' Tass said. The malfunctioning hatch is on Kvant-2, a module containing photographic and technical equipment attached to the Mir space station. During a spacewalk in July, Mir's previous tenants, Anatoly Solovyov and Alexander Balandin, apparently were unable to close the hatch after they entered the airlock, and had to enter the spacecraft through another port, officials said at the time. They were reported by Soviet to have come dangerously close to running out of oxygen. Tass said that today's malfunction presented no danger to Manakov and Strekalov. ``This was just ordinary maintainance work in space, not some extraordinary situation,'' Tass quoted Mission Control specialists as saying. Today's spacewalk had originally been scheduled for Oct. 19, but was postponed after Strekalov caught a cold while working out on an on-board running track. The Soviet Union's manned space program, which for decades has been a source of national pride, has been plagued in the past two years by docking equipment failures, mistakes by cosmonauts and budget cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Vessel Accidentally Fires Shells in Vladvistok
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet inspector, testing artillery aboard a navy submarine chaser, forgot to check if the weapons were loaded and accidentally fired off 17 shells in the direction of Vladivostok, Tass said today. ``Several artillery shots boomed in Golden Horn Gulf, the very center of Vladivostok,'' the official Soviet news agency said in a report from the Far Eastern port city on the Sea of Japan. ``Seventeen shells were fired from the large submarine chaser Admiral Vinogradov.'' Tass said Monday's accident occurred after V. Kolganov from the local armaments factory began checking a firing circuit without checking first to see if the weapon was armed. ``The triggering mechanism worked faultlessy,'' Tass reported, and 17 shells were fired. The news agency did not further describe the weapon or the ammunition. ``The city was saved from serious damage by the angle of the gun barrels, which were almost vertical,'' Tass said. The report did not say if there were any injuries or if any action would be taken against Kolganov.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Firmer, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was firmer at higher levels in calm European trading today, after a long-awaited move by the U.S. Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. Traders said the one-quarter percentage point easing in the Federal Funds rate was a relief to the market. ``The dollar is still in a downtrend, but it is retracing its steps,'' one trader in Milan said. Gold prices were mixed. David Deitch, senior dealer at Nomura Bank International in London, said the dollar's rise was triggered by a combination of factors. Increasing tension in the Persian Gulf helped the dollar as did hints by U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady that third quarter gross national product (GNP) data to be released today will show faster than expected growth. But, Deitch added, underlying economic concerns haven't faded and the market will continue to take any rallies by the dollar as just another opportunity to sell. ``There has been some temporary demand for the dollar but it is much less likely that the dollar will hold these levels for long,'' he said. Market attention was likely to focus on the release of the new GNP data. Brady hinted that it could be as high as 2.4 percent rather than the expected 1 percent. But dealers warned that if the number proves closer to market forecasts, the dollar could fall heavily. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.00 yen, up 1.65 yen from Monday's finish. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.20 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5205 German marks, up from 1.5170 -1.2890 Swiss francs, up from 1.2865 -5.0907 French francs, up from 5.0775 -1.7135 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7090 -1,139.50 Italian lire, up from 1,136.75 -1.1640 Canadian dollars, unchanged In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9513, compared with $1.9525 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $373.35 per ounce at midmorning, up from $372.75 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $373.50, up from $372.50 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $3.49 an ounce today, to close at $374.65. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.14 a troy ounce, up from Monday's $4.10.

DOC.HEAD: Li Says Planning Meeting Will Precede Party Session
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Premier Li Peng has announced a special national conference to plan economic strategy, newspapers said today in another sign top Communist officials are unable to reach agreement among themselves. The official China Daily quoted Li as saying a long-awaited meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee will be held only after the national planning conference. He said both meetings will be held before year's end. The 195-member Central Committee, which sets policy, was to have met shortly after the Asian Games ended in Beijing on Oct. 7 to approve the economy's next Five-Year Plan. The current plan ends in December. Foreign diplomats say the meeting has not convened because divisions are so great that no draft plan is sure of winning approval. Conservatives are said to be pressing for continued strong central controls, while opponents argue that the economy is healthy enough to resume a market-oriented reform program put on hold two years ago. The debate goes deeper than economic issues because the participants' stances reflect conflicting ideological convictions and visions of how China will enter the 21st century. For example, the leading figure among the central planners, 85-year-old Chen Yun, regards reform as an effort to improve efficiency with the economy remaining largely state-owned and directed. Many younger economists, however, say state ownership is the problem and that reforms should lead to privatization. The lower-level planning conference may be an attempt to work out a compromise. Li said only that it would plan next year's economic program. The China Daily quoted him as saying that ``quite a lot of time for preparation and discussion'' is needed before the Central Committee meeting can be held. He predicted that no major changes would be made in China's development program not just during the next five years, but the entire decade. The newspaper said Li made the comments Monday when meeting with a group of foreign ambassadors. He may have been seeking to dispel the impression that the leadership has been paralyzed over the issue. Li did not say who would attend the conference, but the session was likely to include provincial and major city leaders as well as central government officials. A similar meeting was held in September but mainly highlighted differences of opinion without reaching any solutions, according to foreign diplomats who spoke on condition of anonymity. In a separate report, the China Daily quoted a senior official from the People's Construction Bank of China as saying the 2-year-old policy of strictly controlling loans will continue next year, ruling out a return to fast growth. Some of the strongest pressure to resume free market reforms comes from provincial authorities. During the mid-1980s under Li's predecessor, Premier Zhao Ziyang, provinces were given substantial power to retain profits from local industries and approve imports, exports and loans. The central government lost revenue but remained responsible for major infrastructure investment and price subsidies, resulting in annual state deficits. Shortly after becoming premier in 1988, Li began a strict austerity program that has cut state spending and partially reined in the provinces. Reforms have been under an ideological cloud since June 1989, when the conservatives crushed a massive popular movement for democratic change. Nonetheless, debate recently has resumed on steps such as privatizing housing, selling stock in state companies and reducing state price subsidies. Vice Premier Tian Jiyun announced Saturday that grain prices will be adjusted over the next five years to reduce subsidies. The state buys grain from farmers and sells it to urban residents at a loss.

DOC.HEAD: West Virginia Mayor Proposes Tax On Panhandlers
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tony Senecal, looking to cut down on the number of beggars in town, wants to charge panhandlers $25 every six months. ``There's nothing that says there can't be a licensing fee charged for panhandling,'' Seneca said. His ordinance would apply to all individuals and organizations that set up collection efforts in the downtown area, the mayor said. The proposal goes before City Council on Thursday. Bob O'Brien, spokesman for the West Virginia chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, doesn't like the idea. ``It's a way of making life difficult for people whose life already is difficult,'' he said. The ordinance also would require panhandlers to pay business, occupation and state sales taxes. Violators would be fined $500 and face up to 10 days in jail. ``How are they going to pay a tax if they're already panhandling?'' O'Brien said.

DOC.HEAD: Frozen Catfish Cargo Salvaged by Food Bank
DOC.TEXT: At least 1 ton of frozen catfish filets that spilled into a downtown park from an overturned truck will be used by a food bank to feed the hungry, officials said. The Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank, which provides food for 310 non-profit charities, said Monday that the owner of the cargo allowed the food bank to use the fish Department of Agriculture officials considered salvageable. ``It's a blessing,'' said the organization's executive director, Joyce Rothermel, who estimated the food's value at $4,000 to $5,000. ``Donations that are high in protein, like fish, are very rare.'' The truck carrying cargo of the Delta Pride Catfish Co., of Indianola, Miss., slammed into a wall on the side of an overpass Sunday as it left a downtown tunnel. The truck's trailer toppled into the park below, crushing two trees and littering the grass with fish.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to restore paragraph marker in 1st graf
Alaska Car Wash Owner Wants City to Pay Rent for Boulder Dumped on His Land
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a car wash says a 35-ton boulder sitting on his property is bad for business and wants the city to pay more than $3,000 in rent for the space the unwanted rock takes up. The city put the boulder on the car wash site during street improvements, Pioneer Carwash owner Malcolm MacIntosh said. The rock was there when he bought the business. MacIntosh said he began asking the city to get rid of the rock soon after he took over the business about two years ago. He offered it as a gift for use as a landscaping ornament in a park, but the city didn't budge on the offer. ``All I ever wanted them to do is move it so I can use the land,'' MacIntosh said. ``It's costing me money because if I have a car here washing and a car here vacuuming, no one can get around.'' His lawsuit in Small Claims Court seeks two years' rent at $120 a month plus interest for payments he says are overdue, for a total of $3,085.22. City Manager C.E. Swackhammer said he is researching MacIntosh's claim but hasn't found any documents on the rock in city files. He said he also is trying to find past owners of the car wash. MacIntosh said he began billing the city for back rent in June. He said he arrived at the amount by comparing rates at local storage yards for an item of that size. He added a bit for the inconvenience to his business.

DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in Washington state early today, and dry weather prevailed across much of the remainder of the nation. Today's forecast called for moderate temperatures along the East Coast and parts of the Midwest, with warmer weather in the West and Southwest. A storm system moving in off the Pacific Ocean brought rain to Seattle and Spokane, Wash., and strong wind to the state and Oregon. Sunny skies were expected along the Eastern Seaboard, with temperatures in the 50s in Maine, the 60s and 70s in the mid-Atlantic states and the 80s in Florida. Highs in the 80s were likely in the South and Midwest, and temperatures were expected to reach the 90s in the desert Southwest. The high for the nation Monday was 97 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., and Parker, Ariz.
