DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Candidate Sues Foe for Libel Over Campaign Mudslinging
DOC.TEXT: The Republican candidate for Arkansas attorney general says all campaign mudslinging isn't protected by the Constitution. Asa Hutchinson of Fort Smith filed a defamation lawsuit against his Democratic rival, Lt. Gov. Winston Bryant, on Monday, claiming some television ads and public statements misrepresent the facts. The ads claim Hutchinson received illegal campaign contributions in a failed 1986 run for the U.S. Senate, Hutchinson's lawsuit said. It also said Bryant accused Hutchinson of engaging in criminal conduct during a speech. Bryant of Malvern scoffed at the suit, calling it a desperate move by a floundering campaign. ``This is really nothing more than a last-ditch desperate attempt by my opponent,'' Bryant said. ``He's falling in the polls. His campaign is falling apart.'' Bryant said his public statements and campaign advertisements are supported by documentation. ``Although this lawsuit is unusual in a political campaign, the attack ads of Mr. Bryant go beyond routine campaign rhetoric,'' Hutchinson said. ``This lawsuit is important to reverse the trend toward mudslinging campaigns that are based upon distortion and outright lies.'' The suit seeking unspecified damages claims that Bryant's television advertisements used deliberate or reckless falsehoods as a political tool. According to the suit, Bryant approved the ads with knowledge of or reckless disregard for the alleged false statements. The ads accuse Hutchinson of accepting illegal campaign contributions from the National Republican Senatorial Committee during his unsuccessful 1986 campaign, the suit said. Hutchinson said the suit is bolstered by a 1989 U.S. Supreme Court decision in a libel trial filed by an Ohio judicial candidate against a newspaper. In the case, Harte-Hanks Inc. vs. Connaughton, the high court upheld a $200,000 award against the newspaper, ruling that ``speech used for political ends does not automatically bring it under the protection mantle of the Constitution.''

DOC.HEAD: `Devil's Night' Brings, Curfew, Foot Patrols, Free Cable TV
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf, `The annual' with resident quote. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The Southeast...
DOC.TEXT: The city imposed a curfew and organized patrols by residents toting fire extinguishers, while free cable TV was offered to keep firebugs home tonight during Devil's Night, Detroit's pre-Halloween arson spree. The measures are part of an effort by Detroit to remake its lawless image and end the annual outbreak of fires that has become a national embarrassment. Devil's Night is actually three nights of vandalism, beginning two nights before Halloween and peaking one night before. Mayor Coleman A. Young last week unveiled a ``My Heart is with Detroit'' campaign, urging residents to take pride in their city and step up anti-arson patrols. More than 35,000 residents and city workers have volunteered to keep an eye out for arsonists, Young said. Rewards of up to $1,500 have been offered for information leading to the conviction of arsonists. Volunteers wearing red-and-white ``My Heart is with Detroit'' T-shirts and caps began walking the streets Monday night, some carrying fire extinguishers to put out small blazes. Until the 1970s, Devil's Night featured typical Halloween tricks such as egg tossing, covering homes and yards with toilet paper and burning piles of leaves. Then came larger fires, set in garages, trash bins or abandoned homes, bringing flames that sometimes spread to occupied houses. The worst Devil's Night came in 1984, when 810 fires were set during the three-day period. Last year, there were 223 fires between Oct. 29 and Oct. 31, 115 of them on the night before Halloween. The annual rampage has left families homeless and gutted dozens of buildings, bringing bad publicity for Detroit. Rowena Williams, 64, a retired Chrysler Corp. worker who posted a ``My Heart is with Detroit'' sign in her front yard, said she dreads the Halloween season. ``I don't even put on the lights. You're too scared,'' Williams said as she stood behind security bars at her front door. ``I don't open my door for trick-or-treaters. I wish I could, but it's too dangerous.'' The Southeast Michigan Cable Association this year decided to unscramble TV signals, including movie services such as HBO and Showtime, in hopes of keeping arsonists indoors. As in the past two years, Young imposed a 6 p.m.-to-6 a.m. curfew for people 18 and under from Monday through Thursday. Police arrested 379 curfew violators last year. By early today, more than 113 had been arrested, police said. ``It's really going to be up to the discretion of the officer,'' police spokesman Officer Thomas Martinelli said. ``If a kid is stopped on his bike about a mile away from home and he is going away from his house he could be arrested.'' Ze'ev Chafets, a 43-year-old writer born in Pontiac who moved to Israel at age 20, is in town to drum up sales for his book ``Devil's Night and Other True Tales of Detroit.'' In the book, which has been blasted by Young and other officials, Chafets refers to Detroit as ``America's first Third World city.'' Chafets says in the book he met people on Devil's Night who make annual trips to the city just to watch it burn. He wrote that in a restaurant on the 70th floor of the Renaissance Center, ``suburbanite patrons were cheering the fires as they dined alongside revolving glass walls.'' The mayor said Chafets' expose doesn't help solve the problem. ``We're attempting to come up with a more positive image for the city,'' he said. ``It's obvious that Devil's Night has a bad connotation. It always has. Then some guy writes a book about it and it becomes worse.'' The arson trend has begun to spill over into the suburbs. A curfew was imposed in Highland Park after a few buildings were burned in recent years. ``We're working with two shifts over the next three days to cut down on any problems,'' police Lt. Ron Behrend said Monday night. In Flint, where about 140 fires were reported last year, the Fire Department began last week lecturing at schools and to neighborhood clubs.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS New York-dated item in PM-Deaths, a0473, to CORRECT spelling to Hexter sted Hexler throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Maurice Hexter, a leading fund-raiser for Jewish causes that included rebuilding homes destroyed by Jewish-Arab rioting, died Saturday at age 99. Hexter started his career as executive director of the Milwaukee Federation of Jewish Charities. He later taught social ethics at Harvard and at Simmons College in Boston. He also helped found schools for social work at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., and Yeshiva University and Hunter College in New York.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Los Angeles-dated item in PM-Deaths, a0473, to CORRECT reference to Smith in 4th graf, sted French.
DOC.TEXT: William French Smith, who as Ronald Reagan's personal lawyer helped guide him to the White House and then joined the Reagan administration as attorney general, died Monday of cancer. He was 73. ``William French Smith served his country with the greatest dedication and distinction,'' Reagan said in a statement. ``As attorney general, he brought talent, wisdom, and the highest integrity to the Department of Justice.'' Born in Wilton, N.H., to an aristocratic Yankee family, Smith served as informal chairman of Reagan's so-called kitchen cabinet, a group of millionaires who helped his quest for the governorship and later the presidency. Smith was appointed the nation's 74th attorney general in 1981 and served until 1985. Smith is survived by his wife, Jean; three sons; a daughter; a stepson; a stepdaughter; and seven grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavian Parliament Expels Christian Turkish Deputies
DOC.TEXT: The Moldavian parliament has expelled 10 Christian Turkish deputies for urging the secession of the Gagauz people from the republic and organizing elections, Tass said today. The move came as nationalist and secessionist forces were reported to be pulling back from a confrontation and more talks were planned on resolving their ethnic conflict. Tension in southern Moldavia, a republic bordering Romania, has dissipated since two regiments of Soviet Interior Ministry troops began arriving over the weekend to establish a buffer between Moldavians and the Gagauz minority, the official news agency Tass and the independent agency Interfax reported Monday. Tass said today that the Moldavian parliament expelled 10 of 13 Gagauz deputies because they ``shunned parliamentary sessions, ignored parliamentary laws and resolutions, provoked citizens to violate Moldavian laws and organized general elections in the Gagauz republic.'' The Gagauz, descendants of Christians who fled religious persecution in Turkey about 160 years ago, claimed the southern corner of the republic last week and began holding elections for an autonomous government within Moldavia. Numbering about 150,000 in the republic of 4.3 million, the Gagauz said they feared rising Moldavian nationalism and were angry over a law making Moldavian the republic's official language. Tass said the declaration of independence, declared unconstitutional by the Moldavian parliament, had heightened ethnic tensions in the republic. A state of emergency was declared in the region Friday, and Soviet troops were sent to keep the peace. ``The situation ... has improved slightly during the past 24 hours. Previously the situation was characterized as explosive,'' Tass said Monday night. The ethnic unrest was the latest to strike the Soviet Union and could further complicate President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hopes to hold the country together with a new union treaty. Interior Ministry troops also have been deployed in several other republics to prevent ethnic violence.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says He Expects Attack in Next Few Days
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details of INA report, comments by diplomats. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today summoned senior military aides and told them the United States and its allies might attack in ``the coming few days,'' the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Saddam and the joint command of the armed forces met to complete preparations for ``urban warfare'' in occupied Kuwait, the report said. The agency, which was monitored in Nicosia, did not explain why Saddam believed an attack was imminent. But Middle East diplomats said Saddam was reacting to statements Monday by Secretary of State James Baker III, who said that ``there is a limit to the international community's patience.'' ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait,'' Baker said in a speech in Los Angeles. The diplomats spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. The meeting in Baghdad came one day after the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members held a high-level military meeting to discuss how to further pressure Saddam into quitting the emirate he invaded on Aug. 2. The Security Council voted on Monday to hold Iraq liable for damages from the Iraqi invasion and occupation. The Iraqi News Agency dispatch said the meeting of the military command in Baghdad was the second in 24 hours to be chaired personally by Saddam. It said he led the session to ``discuss preparations for urban warfare and necessary measures to be taken in the event of combat in the operation zone of the Kuwait province.'' After the invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait, Baghdad's official media took to referring to the oil-rich emirate as Iraq's 19th province. The Iraqi News Agency said today's meeting was attended by all members of the joint command of the armed forces. Saddam is the supreme commander, and there are at least eight top generals and three Cabinet members: the ministers of defense, information and military industries. ``We must be prepared with all that God has given us of potential to thwart perfidious intentions by the United States and its allies to launch an attack in the coming few days,'' Saddam told the military command. The agency did not give other details, but said officers on duty in Kuwait were brought to Baghdad to attend the session. With 220,000 servicemen deployed to operation Desert Shield, the United States is by far the largest contributor to the force facing Saddam's army in the gulf. Other countries have together committed about 100,000 troops to the operation. The multinational force faces more than 400,000 Iraqi troops.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Victim Dies of Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes that ravaged northwestern Illinois in August have claimed another victim. Kent A. Keeley, 52, died from injuries he suffered when the storm wrecked his car, said Will County Coroner Duane Krieger. Keeley died Friday at St. Joseph Hospital in Joliet, becoming the 29th victim of the tornadoes. Storms ripped through Plainfield, Joliet and Crest Hill on Aug. 28, injuring more than 300 people. Property damage has been estimated at more than $100 million.

DOC.HEAD: Father, Mother Plead Guilty to Nine Years of Raping Three Daughters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A husband who raped three of his daughters repeatedly over nine years has pleaded guilty to rape and child abuse. His wife, who brought the girls to him, also pleaded guilty in the case. The rapes caused 10 pregnancies, each of which ended in abortions. Monday's pleas by the couple, both age 43, were part of a bargain with prosecutors to avoid a trial in Baltimore Circuit Court on 30 counts of various sex and child abuse offenses. The father admitted to three counts of first-degree rape and three counts of sexual child abuse. He agreed to three consecutive life sentences and must serve the first 30 years. He will be sentenced Dec. 7. The mother, who had described the family as ``very close and...very religious,'' admitted to three counts of first-degree rape and three counts of sexual child abuse. She will be sentenced Dec. 6, but agreed Monday to a 25-year sentence, 15 years of which must be served. Under Maryland law, a person who helps someone else commit a felony can be charged as if he or she committed the crime. The names of the parents were withheld to protect the identity of the victims, who are now living with relatives. The two eldest of the three daughters, now 17, 20 and 23, are daughters of the woman from a previous marriage. The youngest is the child of both defendants. One of the daughters is now a medical student, the others still live in Baltimore. The abuse that began in 1981 remained undiscovered until last March, when one of the daughters wrote at the bottom of a history test: ``I hate life. I hate school. I hate people. I hope to die. Soon....!!!'' Police were notified by social services workers and two days later, on March 22, the father confessed. According to court documents, the father told the police that he first started fondling his stepdaughters when they were 5 or 6, and began having sexual intercourse with them and with his daughter as they reached the age of 10 or 12. Assistant State's Attorney Wanda Robinson said Monday the mother brought the girls to their father, then was present when some of the rapes occurred, either pretending to be asleep or facing the wall while her daughters screamed and fought. The mother had not wanted her husband's assaults to become public, nor to be left alone to raise her seven children, five girls and two boys, Robinson said. There were no allegations that the father abused the other children. In a letter to the court, the mother wrote: ``I'm sorry for not being there when my daughters needed me.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Government Says Top Dissident Has No Political Future
DOC.TEXT: Burma's state press has said there is no political future for leading dissident Aung San Suu Kyi, whom the military government has detained without trial for more than a year. In a two-part article Oct. 22-23, The Working People's Daily also indicated the government would release Ms. Suu Kyi only if she accepted exile. A copy of the article was obtained in Bangkok today. The articles were the clearest statement yet of the government's intentions toward Ms. Suu Kyi, whose National League For Democracy won the May general election by a landslide but has been blocked from taking office. ``Aung San Suu Kyi has no right according to the law to take part in the political activities of (Burma),'' the article said. Ms. Suu Kyi was put under house arrest in July 1989 and later barred from the election. She was accused of subversion, but never formally charged. The decision to disqualify her from the election ``puts an end to her political career once and for all,'' the paper said. The daily also reprinted without comment a report from a Thai newspaper last month, in which a Japanese diplomat quoted the head of Burma's government, Gen. Saw Maung, as saying he would free Ms. Suu Kyi if she accepted exile. A political source in Burma's capital, Rangoon, said the state press had stepped up attacks on Ms. Suu Kyi after authorities cracked down on dissident Buddhist monks last week and arrested at least a dozen senior officials of the National League For Democracy. ``It's an all-out attempt to discredit (the National League) and Aung San Suu Kyi,'' said the source, who was contacted by telephone from Bangkok and spoke on condition of anonymity. A recent cartoon in the Working People's Daily said Ms. Suu Kyi had defiled the Burmese race by marrying a foreigner, the source said. Ms. Suu Kyi, the 45-year-old daughter of Aung San, Burma's revered independence leader, is married to British academic Michael Aris. The source said the government appeared to have succeeded in squelching dissent among the monks. Buddhist monks stopped ministering to soldiers last month to protest military violence against demonstrators. The authorities responded with stern warnings, raids on monasteries and arrests. The source also said the government was trying to force leaders of opposition parties to sign a document saying they agreed to follow a program requiring that a new constitution be approved before the government steps down. The National League For Democracy had ignored the plan when it was announced in July. Instead, it demanded the government convene the Parliament chosen in the May election and negotiate a transfer of power. A Burmese source in Rangoon said Cho Cho Kyaw Naing, leader of one political party, the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League, had refused to sign the agreement. Both Rangoon sources dismissed news reports that Myint Myint Khin, a central executive committee member of the National League For Democracy, had signed the document.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Collapses, Two People Killed
LaserPhoto MLA1
DOC.TEXT: A bridge collapsed into the San Juan River today, plunging at least 10 vehicles into the water and killing two people, police said. Officers said a loaded concrete carrier and several other vehicles were crossing the bridge linking Manila and the city of Mandaluyong when part of the span's eastbound lane fell at about 11:20 a.m. At least 20 people were pulled from the polluted water. Others swam to shore. Taxi driver Danny Iskuriel said the bridge fell so slowly he was unaware it had collapsed until he water began seeping into his car. ``We realized we were already in the water,'' he said. ``We went down in slow motion.'' Iskuriel said he saw one of his passengers escape but did not know what happened to the other. Crisostomo Jopson said he was in a car on the bridge when it buckled and collapsed. ``When we collapsed, we floated,'' he told a radio station. ``I got out of the car and swam.'' Another survivor, Tomasa Villegas, said she was seated beside the driver in a crowded passenger jeep when the bridge fell. ``I saw other passengers swimming,'' she said. There was no explanation for the collapse, but neighborhood residents said the bridge was cracked during an earthquake in July that killed more than 1,600 people. The crack was never repaired, residents said. President Corazon Aquino's government has been criticized in Congress and the media for allowing the nation's roads, bridges and public buildings to deteriorate. The government says it lacks the money for such projects.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Team Says Election Was Rigged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Naeemuddin, one name, is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A French human rights group said today vote rigging defeated Benazir Bhutto's populist party in last week's elections. The International Federation of Human Rights is the first group of poll watchers to echo Ms. Bhutto's charges of fraud in voting for national and provincial legislatures. The Islamic Democratic Alliance, which will form Pakistan's next government, called the group's assessment ridiculous. ``They must have had super vision like the the comic book character Superman to be able to see massive fraud which dozens of other observers could not see,'' said an alliance spokesman who insisted on anonymity. Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party was handed a stunning defeat in Wednesday's national parliamentary elections. In provincial legislative polling three days later, her party won support only in her home province of Sindh. In a statement issued by the French Embassy in Islamabad, the four-member human rights team said there was a discrepancy between the widespread impression of sparse voter turnout and the official report. The statement also cited problems with what it said were delayed polling results and the absence of official vote tallies. Almost without exception, international and local witnesses reported sparse voter turnout, but officials said 45.6 percent of the electorate cast ballots Wednesday, nearly 3 percent more than in November 1988. The Paris-based human rights organization, which has members in 54 countries, charged that Ms. Bhutto's opponents altered the election results, suggesting the intervention could have occurred between the polling stations and the election return offices. Ms. Bhutto said vote rigging was widespread in 100 of Pakistan's 217 constituencies. She claimed between 2 million and 4 million pre-prepared ballots were stuffed into boxes en route from polling stations to election return offices. Chief Election Commission Justice Naeemuddin dismissed the charges, saying: ``I have not received a single complaint.'' But the French report claimed several polling agents were not given certified results following the vote count at the polling station. Instead they have only slips of papers to prove their count. ``Something very important - no official paper with the results was given to polling agents when the voting was over,'' the group's statement said. The human rights group's report was at odds with that of the Washington-based National Democratic Institute, which said polling was ``generally open, orderly and well-administered.'' The institute sent 40 observers to Pakistan. A 15-member team from India, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh also concluded the voting was fair, as did a three-member Canadian team. Ms. Bhutto, 37, was sacked as prime minister Aug. 6 by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who charged her party indulged in corruption, nepotism and confrontational politics during her 20 months in power.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire on Crowd in Religious Dispute, Five Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE death toll, ADD Singh offer to resign, details. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Hindu holy...'
DOC.TEXT: Troops opened fire today on Hindu fundamentalists who broke through police lines and surged toward a holy site claimed by both Hindus and Moslems. At least five people were killed and 20 wounded. Thirteen more people died in Hindu-Moslem clashes in several cities hundreds of miles away, police said. At least 125 people have been killed in riots across India this past week, most in clashes between Hindus and Moslems. The dispute threatens to topple the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh, who opposes the Hindu campaign to replace a 16th-century Moslem mosque. Militant members of the country's Hindu majority had said they would begin tearing down the mosque today and replacing it with a temple. Singh today repeated his offer to resign if members of his party in Parliament ``feel that change of leadership will serve larger goals.'' He made a similar offer Monday. About 200 Hindus eventually reached the site today in Ayodhya. Those who got through planted Hindu religious flags on the mosque in victory before police drove them away. About 10,000 people who had surged past police barricades surrounded the perimeter of the disputed site when three Hindu holy men urged them to halt the violence, saying they had negotiated a peaceful sttlement with local officials. But part of the crowd apparently did not hear the appeal and pushed toward the mosque, setting fire to six police jeeps along the way. Police then opened fire. The federal government later announced that five people were killed. About 20 others were injured by the gunfire, witnesses said. Hindu holy men screamed obscenities from rooftops and pelted the police with stones. At least four officers were injured. Many of the militant Hindus were beaten back by police, who fired tear gas and lashed out with iron-tipped bamboo canes. Dozens were injured. The crowd initially halted about 100 yards from the mosque, where police and paramilitary troops stood with rifles ready. But later about 200 Hindus broke through police lines and reached the small, one-story mosque. Young men wearing orange headbands, the color of the Hindu faith, climbed atop the mosque and chipped concrete from each of its three domes, claiming this was a ``symbolic destruction'' of the Islamic shrine. They planted a saffron flag atop each dome before police drove them away. Jubilant crowds poured through the streets, shouting ``Victory to mother India!'' In New Delhi, the government's chief spokesman, Ramamohan Rao, said there was no damage to the mosque. The World Hindu Council, which is leading the temple program, said it would go ahead with its construction effort. ``We will only rest when the temple in complete,'' Girilal Kishore, a Hindu holy man and senior official of the council told reporters in New Delhi. Ayodha, a city of 40,000 people, had been under a round-the-clock curfew since Friday and roads leading to the mosque were blocked as authorities tried to halt any attempt to tear down the mosque. But people emerged from hiding places in fields around Ayodhya before sunrise and stormed a bridge leading into the town. About 20,000 police and paramilitary troops were deployed in and around Ayodhya, 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. They were among 200,000 security troops on alert throughout Uttar Pradesh state. About 80,000 people have been arrested in the last week in the rural state. Most were made under preventive detention laws that allow authorities to hold people without charge when they believe public safety is threatened. The detainees included top leaders of the right-wing Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party. It has withdrawn its support for Prime Minister Singh in Parliament, plunging India into political crisis. Singh now does not have a reliable vote bank in Parliament to preserve his minority government, which took office last December. The mosque at issue was built on the place that many Hindu leaders claim is the very spot where the god Rama was born. Moslems, who make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, fear that if one mosque is moved or destroyed, hundreds of other Islamic shrines across India would be in peril. Athough India is constitutionally a secular nation, Hindus comprise 82 percent of the population and have always held the prime minister's post.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: U.S. To Discuss Timetable for Possible Gulf Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after 2nd graf, `In his....', to UPDATE with Bush declining comment. Picks up 3rd graf, `The newspaper...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials - believing sanctions will not force Iraq to pull out of Kuwait - plan to discuss a timetable with U.S. allies for a possible military offensive, it was reported today. In his visits to Europe, Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations, Secretary of State James Baker III will assess the impact of the U.N.-backed embargo and consider additional steps, including the use of force, the Los Angeles Times said. President Bush, asked about the report at the White House today, told reporters, ``I could, but I'm not going to comment.'' The newspaper says a senior government official who is involved in Persian Gulf strategy considers war almost inevitable. The official, whose name was not disclosed, is quoted as saying: ``I know of no one who disagrees with my assessment of the situation and what we have to do to achieve our goals.'' The official said the most likely time for an offensive would be in December or January, ``although it could come earlier or a little later,'' the newspaper reported. In an address to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council on Monday, Baker reaffirmed that the United States strongly prefers a peaceful solution consistent with the mandate of U.N. Security Council resolutions. ``We are exhausting every diplomatic avenue to achieve such a solution without further bloodshed,'' he said. However, he added: ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait.'' He said Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein must realize ``there is a limit to the international community's patience.'' The Times quotes another U.S. official as saying it is the United States that cannot wait indefinitely. ``He can sit there indefinitely and he knows how to absorb pain,'' the official said of Saddam. ``But we can't sit there forever. We've got to make some hard decisions about how to resolve it, and those decisions may come sooner rather than later.'' Baker travels to Saudi Arabia and the other countries starting on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO CORRECT OVERLINE
Palestinian Attacker Killed, Another Arab Killed in Bomb Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with details on attacks, reports saying about 20,000 Palestinians will be affected by new travel restrictions. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A security agent shot to death a Palestinian who stabbed an Israeli guard in the West Bank, and an Arab died in a failed bombing near Tel Aviv. Both deaths came in apparent revenge attacks for the Temple Mount killings. A third attack occurred in Arab east Jerusalem, where a Palestinian stabbed a policeman. The victim suffered superficial neck wounds, and the assailant was arrested, police and Israel army radio said. The attacks were the latest in violence set off by the police response to the Oct. 8 riots on the sacred Temple Mount. Twenty Palestinians were killed by police who opened fire on Arabs who had pelted Jewish worshipers with rocks. Since then, five people have been killed and 11 wounded in a series of revenge attacks by Arabs and Israelis. In the occupied West Bank today, a Palestinian stabbed a private Israeli security guard who was escorting a gasoline truck into Nablus, the army said. Army radio said the guard was stabbed three times in the back as he stood on the street. A plainclothes Israeli security officer who was passing shot the attacker to death, it said. The guard suffered moderate wounds. The army imposed a curfew on Nablus and the surrounding refugee camps, confining some 130,000 Palestinians to their homes. Three masked Palestinians announced through a loudspeaker that the slain assailant, identified as 18-year-old Haitham Jamla, was a member of Islamic Jihad, a Moslem fundamentalist group outlawed by Israel on Monday. The decision to ban the group apparently came after it claimed responsibility for the stabbing deaths of three Israelis in Jerusalem last week. Israel has blamed Islamic Jihad for dozens of earlier attacks on Jews. In the Tel Aviv suburb of Bnei Brak, meanwhile, a bomb exploded in a vegetable store, killing one Arab and wounding two as they tried to assemble the device, police said. Chaim Selzer, a medic who arrived first at the scene, told army radio that one of the wounded lost a hand in the explosion. A third Arab suffered minor injuries, officials said. Both were taken to a nearby hospital. The radio said the three Arabs were employed at the store in the ultra-Orthodox suburb and slept there at night, indicating that they were from the occupied territories. Israeli law bars Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip from staying in Israel overnight. Many Israeli employers sidestep the law, however, and provide primitive accommodations for Palestinian laborers so they don't have to make the long journey home to the West Bank or Gaza every night. After last week's revenge attacks, Defense Minister Moshe Arens closed off the occupied lands for four days, barring Palestinians from entering Israel. On Monday, he announced tougher restrictions to permanently ban Palestinians from entering Israel, saying he would block all those with records of crime or activities in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising. The daily Haaretz said today that about 20,000 would be banned, up from 8,000 now. Among those banned will be Palestinians held under emergency regulations that allow them to be jailed for up to a year without charges. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said on Monday night that Israel would crack down hard on Arabs attacking Jews. ``We shall react to them whether they use stones or firebombs, knives or other weapons,'' he told American Jewish fund-raisers. ``We shall not expose our citizens to danger. We shall build a wall of steel and love around our people, as we face threats.'' In other violence today, masked assailants shot and killed 45-year-old Khalil Hassan Najar in the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Rafah on suspicion he collaborated with Israel, Palestinian reporters said. The army said police were investigating. The death brought to 292 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the uprising, most on suspicion of helping Israel. The death in Nablus brought to 767 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis. Fifty-one Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Shoves Heckler at Campaign Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to RECAST and UPDATE with comment from heckler. Picks up 4th graf, `About 100...'.
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Jesse Helms, locked in a tough re-election contest, sparred with hecklers at a rally, pushing one protester away from a microphone and grabbing pamphlets from his hand. Helms invited one protester, Marty Leary, to his microphone Monday to speak for a minute, and Leary questioned the senator's votes on the deregulation of savings and loans. But when time was up, the senator moved Leary out of the way. ``Go to the Gantt rallies if you want to waste your time, but don't be rude,'' the senator said, pushing Leary away from the microphone. Helms faces Democrat Harvey Gantt in his bid for a fourth term. Leary, 25, of Durham, said Helms' push wasn't very forceful. ``I think he gave me a little reminder nudge that my time was up,'' Leary told radio station WRDU. ``It didn't seem like too unfriendly a push.'' About 100 supporters and a dozen hecklers had met Helms as he kicked off the final week of campaigning. When Leary and other protesters shouted, ``But why did you vote for it?'' Helms invited Leary to come to the microphone and ask his questions. ``Four times you voted for the savings and loan bailout or to deregulate the financial industry,'' Leary said, asking Helms to explain his votes. ``I'd say this to anybody who voted for it,'' Leary said, drawing hoots from the crowd. ``No you wouldn't,'' Helms responded. He drew a roar from supporters as he pushed Leary away, saying, ``Your minute is up.'' ``I would ask the Gantt supporters to go back to their candidate and tell him to try to tell the truth once in a while,'' Helms said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Uncover Grave in Rio With More Than 100 Bodies
DOC.TEXT: A grave containing more than 100 bodies, most believed to be those of murdered teen-agers, has been found on the outskirts of Rio, a church worker said today. Eduardo Gomes, who works for the Roman Catholic Church, said police discovered the grave Saturday in the city of Nova Iguacu. ``There appear to be about 100 bodies in the grave and most are almost certainly teen-agers, killed by death squads,'' he said. The death squads, which are largely made up of police officers, are normally paid by small shopkeepers to kill petty thieves. Many victims are destitute minors. Gomes said only a few bodies had been retrieved from the grave thus far. He said clothing and shoes found in the grave indicated most of the corpses were those of youngsters. Initial attempts to confirm Gomes' report were unsuccessful. No one answered the telephone at police headquarters in Nova Iguacu. In a report issued earlier this year, the London-based human rights group Amnesty International said hundreds of children were being murdered each year in Brazil. ``There is a marked presence of organized actions for the elimination of children and adolescents with a view to `cleaning up the streets,' '' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helicopter Crashes, Two Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd pvs to CORRECT spelling of Coalinga.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army AH-64 Apache helicopter struck a power line and crashed in southern Germany during a training flight, killing the two crewmen, the military said today. A U.S. Army 7th Corps statement identified the two victims as Clarence E. Hall, 24, of Coeburn, Va., and John A. Wilkinson, 32, of Coalinga, Calif. Both were warrant officers. Hall was the pilot in command. The accident occurred Monday evening near Baiersdorf, about 70 miles north of Munich. Both men were with the 4th Battalion, 229th Aviation, stationed at Illesheim. The helicopter was on a routine training flight when it apparently struck a power line, the statement said. Military authorities were investigating the crash.

DOC.HEAD: President's Party Barely Retains Control of Parliament in Gabon
DOC.TEXT: President Omar Bongo's governing party won a slim majority of parliament seats in Gabon's first multiparty elections in 22 years. Official results released Monday after the fourth round of voting in the central African nation gave the Gabon Democratic Party 59 of 117 seats in which representatives have been chosen. Independents allied with Bongo's party won an additional three seats. Six opposition parties took a total of 55 seats. Three seats remained to be filled in voting that was ordered rescheduled because of alleged irregularities. The Woodcutters' Movement for National Redress won 19 seats and the Gabon Progress Party 18 to lead the opposition parties. Sunday's balloting and the September voting that preceded them were forced on Bongo by violent protests against one-party rule. The president's seven-year term expires in 1993. The first two rounds of voting in September were marred by allegations of widespread fraud, and opposition parties called on the government to resign and cancel the results. But a compromise was accepted in which voting for disputed seats was rescheduled for Oct. 21 and Oct. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Guns 'N' Roses Singer Arrested for Allegedly Hitting Neighbor
DOC.TEXT: Guns N' Roses lead singer Axl Rose was arrested today for allegedly striking a woman on the head with a wine bottle, authorities said. Rose and his neighbor had been arguing about loud music Rose was playing in his apartment, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Roger Hom. Rose allegedly grabbed the woman's keys and tossed them off a balcony. He then allegedly emptied a bottle of wine and swung at her, Hom said. The neighbor, Gabriela Kantor called deputies, who arrested Rose without incident. He was booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon. Bail was set at $5,000, Hom said. Ms. Kantor, 37, was taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center for observation, a nursing supervisor said. The Guns N' Roses band, based in Los Angeles, has been rebuked in the past, with critics calling their lyrics homophobic and racist. The band gained notoriety earlier this year after they made an obscenity-laced acceptance speech for a music award on television.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Man Hit By Truck Falls Off Vehicle at Car Wash
DOC.TEXT: A motorist stopped at a car wash early today to wash off blood from a pedestrian he struck, and found that the victim's body had clung to the vehicle, a sheriff's official said. Sean M. Dingess, 20, of Columbus, allegedly drove more than a mile to the car wash after his pickup hit a man in Franklin County northeast of the city, said sheriff's Sgt. Denny Poole. When a passenger opened his door, the body fell off the truck. Poole said the victim's body had been thrown over the truck's cab and hung from a ladder rack and the body of the truck. The passenger called police. Sheriff's officials took both Dingess and the passenger into custody. No charges were immediately filed because sheriff's officers hadn't talked to prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: China Releases Census Results: Population at 1.13 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= BEIJING (AP) - China today released preliminary figures from its largest-ever census showing a population of 1.133 billion - 20 million more people than the government had planned. The census, conducted in July, marked the first time the government had conducted door-to-door surveys. It is considered the most accurate figure ever for China's population. The census found 1,133,682,501 people residing permanently in mainland China, the nationally televised evening news and the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The last reported population figure, in late 1989, showed 1.112 billion Chinese, but that figure was based on previous population figures that Chinese officials have conceded were unreliable. An editorial to be published Wednesday on the front page of the party newspaper, the People's Daily, called for greater attention to population control. ``For China to reach its goal of a population of 1.25 billion by the year 2000 ... is still very difficult. We must have a full understanding of this,'' it said. The editorial was excerpted by Xinhua and read on the newscast. The government had hoped to keep the population down to 1.113 by the end of 1990, but the census showed that by mid-1990 the population had exceeded the goal by 20 million. The growth rate for the July 1989-June 1990 period was 14.7 per 1,000, the census found. China's growth rate has been increasing steadily since 1985, when it was 11.23 per 1,000. The birth rate also rose for the fourth straight year, to 20.98 per 1,000. In 1985, it was 17.8 per 1,000, the census showed. China's population increases by more than 30 people every minute, or about 17 million people annually, according to official reports. China has failed to stay within its population targets because of a baby boom and the government's inability to maintain its one-child-per-family policy, especially in the countryside. Under the policy, instituted in 1980, families must pay steep fines following the birth of a second child. In rural China, the idea that a large family means prosperity remains strong and some farmers have become rich enough to pay fines for having extra children to work on their properties. The one-child policy also has been relaxed for some families in economic difficulty, including those with one daughter. Further complicating matters, people born during a baby boom in the mid-1960s are now in their marriage and childbearing years, causing a new peak in the population curve. The census, carried out over 10 days, involved 7 million people. Final results will take two years to compile.

DOC.HEAD: Outsider or Insider? Incumbent Senators Decide How to Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs `Go to ...' to UPDATE with comment from Helms' protester. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Just two ...' graf pvs, Helms' comments.
DOC.TEXT: Back home after a turbulent 101st Congress, senators are in a political dilemma over whether to campaign as government outsiders or legislative insiders. In North Carolina, Republican Sen. Jesse Helms faces a stiff challenge from Democratic rival Harvey Gantt, who is telling voters it's time for a change. The three-term senator was put on the defensive about his votes in Congress as he kicked off his final week of campaigning on Monday. The senator shoved a protester at a rally in Durham after the man questioned Helms' votes on the savings and loan bailout. ``Go to the Gantt rallies if you want to waste your time, but don't be rude,'' the senator said, pushing 25-year-old Marty Leary away from a microphone. Leary said Helms' push wasn't very forceful. ``I think he gave me a little reminder nudge that my time was up,'' Leary said. ``It didn't seem like too unfriendly a push.'' Just two days earlier, Helms had been campaigning by speaker-phone from his Washington office and criticizing the legislation approved by Congress in the last-minute rush toward adjournment. The Clean Air Act is ``just not fair to the taxpayers and to the workers of America,'' Helms said, contending that the benefits could occur at half the bill's $50 billion price. Helms' comments came as Gantt complained that Republican administrations have damaged the government's image. ``I basically see the government has become a dirty word to so many of us in recent years,'' Gantt said over the weekend. In Illinois on Monday, Democratic Sen. Paul Simon and Republican challenger Rep. Lynn Martin boasted about major bills that cleared Congress with benefits for their constituents. The budget rolls back higher U.S. Customs Service fees at airports in Rockford and Waukegan, Ill., Martin said. The transportation bill fully funds Amtrak routes in Illinois, Simon said. ``The transportation pie has been getting relatively smaller, but Illinois once again is a clear winner in the transportation budget,'' the senator said during a campaign appearance Sunday night. Simon holds a solid lead over Martin in recent polls. Forced to remain in Washington until just eight days before the election, several candidates sought to create the impression that they were hard at work ensuring that their state or district benefited in Congress' rush to adjourn. Some lawmakers, however, believe the turmoil that surrounded the drawn-out budget fight hurt their campaigns. Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz held a substantial lead over Democratic challenger Paul Wellstone during the summer, but a recent poll showed the race as a dead heat. Boschwitz rushed home in the middle of last week and acknowledged, ``I think the turmoil in Washington is having an effect on my campaign.'' In Indiana, Republican Sen. Dan Coats sought to distance himself from President Bush and the 101st Congress. ``I just think the president made a major mistake by thinking he could play the good guy, play the compromiser and negotiate with the Democrat Congress,'' Coats said Monday. Although his campaign filmed Bush's appearance and endorsement earlier this year, it does not plan to use the footage. ``It's going to make some good home movies,'' said Coats, who was appointed to succeed Vice President Dan Quayle in the Senate. Coats said the deficit-reduction plan changes a government course that led to peace and prosperity in the 1980s and he called the 101st Congress ``a major disappointment.'' Coats maintains a solid lead over Democratic challenger Baron Hill. In Oregon, where Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield is fighting for his political life, Democratic challenger Harry Lonsdale has accused his opponent of receiving more than $80,000 from special interest groups in the past two days. ``I think Oregon voters would rather have an independent voice like Harry Lonsdale,'' said the candidate's spokesman, Dan Walter. Hatfield, who returned home often during the last month of Congress, focused on such local issues as timber industry jobs while launching a campaign ad that questions his opponent's competency. The campaign of Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry also has begun airing negative ads that attack Republican James Rappaport's wealthy real estate background. In an interview with The Associated Press, Kerry sought to portray Rappaport as a candidate of Reaganomics and a product of the last decade of Republican administrations.

DOC.HEAD: General Upset Over Protesters Against Military Buildup in Middle East
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force general is accusing police of ``coddling'' protesters opposed to the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East. Chicopee's mayor reminded the general that the protesters have rights. Air Force Reserve Brig. Gen. Frederick D. Walker, commander of the 439th Military Airlift Wing, fired off letters to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Chicopee aldermen earlier this month calling periodic protests at the base gates by several dozen people ``weekly outbursts of lawlessness.'' He also accused police of trying to ``coddle and placate the lawbreakers.'' He complained that in one instance a fuel truck was delayed for 45 minutes while police ``pleaded with protesters to `temporarily' stand aside.'' Walker was in Georgia and could not immediately be reached for comment today. But Gordon Newell, base public relations officer, said the general was upset over what he considered a dangerous situation. ``From the viewpoint of a military commander in a time of world tensions, the refusal of the city of Chicopee to maintain clear passage to this military installation in unacceptable,'' Walker said in his Oct. 9 letter to the governor. Westover, the nation's largest Air Force Reserve base, is the main staging area in the Northeast for cargo flights to Saudi Arabia. The base is in Chicopee in western Massachusetts, near Springfield. The general got little sympathy from Chicopee Mayor Joseph J. Chessey Jr., who called Walker's conduct ``totally inappropriate for a person holding his rank and position'' and accused him of trying to muzzle dissent. ``I don't personally agree with the protesters, but they have rights and in the general's mind those rights should be denied,'' Chessey said Monday. ``They have a right. This is America. This is not Iraq.'' The mayor fired off his own letter of complaint to Walker's superior, Maj. Gen. Alan G. Sharp, asking that the Air Force ``bring sanity and resolution to this problem.'' Chessey and acting Police Chief Joseph J. Wilk Jr. said police have arrested protesters who blocked access to the base and refused to move. Twenty-one protesters were arrested Oct. 20 at two base gates and two others were arrested Aug. 27. ``As far as I'm concerned, ... there have been no dangerous situations up there,'' Wilk said. ``And as far as I'm concerned, it's been a minimal inconvenience.''

DOC.HEAD: General Says Units Being Readied to Rotate to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Army is preparing to rotate fresh combat units to Saudi Arabia to relieve units that have been in the desert since the start of Operation Desert Shield, a senior Army official said today. Gen. Gordon R. Sullivan, the Army vice chief of staff, said, however, that the Army had not yet been instructed to increase the overall number of soldiers in Saudi Arabia beyond the more than 100,000 already there or en route. More than 210,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen are in the Persian Gulf area, and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said Monday that as many as 100,000 more could be sent. Sullivan said in an interview that the last pieces of the originally planned Army deployment to Saudi Arabia will be ashore ``within the next couple of days.'' President Bush ordered troops to the gulf to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack five days after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``They're essentially there,'' Sullivan said of the remaining elements of the Army deployment, which is the largest operation since the Vietnam War. The four-star general said no final decision have been made on a rotation policy for Desert Shield, and he did not say when the replacement units would be sent. Cheney has said he expects a six-month rotation, and Sullivan said that while details won't be decided for a couple more weeks, the Army already is making arrangements. ``Some headquarters do know'' they'll be sending replacement units, Sullivan said. ``Now if you were to get down and ask the guy down in the infantry squad someplace if he knows, the answer is `no' he doesn't. They haven't been alerted.'' Sullivan said troops from U.S. bases in Europe that are scheduled to be closed are likely to be used as replacements in Saudi Arabia. For the first time in a major U.S. military operation, the Army will rotate whole units in Desert Shield instead of replacing individual soldiers, Sullivan said. The switch in approach is designed to prevent the kind of breakdown in cohesion of combat units that was experienced in the Vietnam War, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gun-Wielding Straight-A Student Takes Classmates, Teacher Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to update with judge's action, prosecutor's comments, picking up at the 4th graf, ``The boy.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: A straight-A student under suspension took seven hostages at gunpoint in a high school classroom, then let them go and surrendered, leaving behind chalkboard graffiti about death and suicide. Eli Dean, 17, was taken to a mental health center for evaluation after the eight-hour standoff Monday at Charlestown High School. No one was injured. No charges were immediately filed. Juvenile Court Judge Clementine Barthold today ordered Dean to undergo a psychiatric evaluation. Clark County Prosecutor Steve Stewart said he would review the test results and information from police and witnesses before determining formal charges. In the meantime, Dean was being held on a preliminary juvenile charge of committing a delinquent act, armed criminal confinement. The boy made no demands during the siege but threatened several times to kill himself, police said. ``I think he just had a lot of personal problems that he wanted brought out,'' said Sgt. John Mann, a hostage negotiator with the State Police. Dean, a senior suspended twice recently for triggering a false fire alarm and breaking a window, was carrying a .38-caliber pistol and a bottle of whiskey, police said. The teen-ager had come to school Monday morning to get his homework assignments, Vice Principal Susie Reis said. Reis told him he was not supposed to be on school grounds. Dean instead took over the English class taught by Melody Money. He entered the classroom and began waving the gun. Students thought he was playing a joke until he began knocking items off desks and hollering, said Ruby Wray, a student. Jason Fultz, another student, said: ``We were scared stiff. Miss Money kept pleading with him to let us go.'' Dean freed most of the students, taking hostage six youngsters and the teacher. Besides trashing the classroom, he scrawled suicidal graffiti on the blackboard, witnesses said. Principal George Marshall said he went to the classroom during the standoff and Dean told him, ``Just give me time and I will release them.'' Pupils at the 643-student school about 20 miles from Louisville, Ky., were evacuated onto the football field. Dean was on probation for being a runaway and for illegal alcohol consumption, said John Buford, his probation officer. He was suspended most recently last week, for breaking a window, said his stepfather, Rocky Williams. ``He was falling behind in his school work and was upset,'' Williams said. Dean was a straight-A student who also excelled at sports, school officials said. Friends speculated about what brought about the standoff. ``Ninety-five percent of this school doesn't accept you if you are your own person,'' classmate Richie Otersbach said. Dean was ``into heavy metal, had long hair for a while and was ridiculed for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Detain Prominent Union Leader
DOC.TEXT: Police detained the nation's most prominent labor leader today in connection with last week's national strike after he appeared on a TV panel show with Manila's police chief. Crispin Beltran, leader of the May First Movement, and police Col. Ernesto Diokno were among the panelists who discussed Wednesday's strike on TV station GMA's weekly show, ``Viewpoint.'' Diokno said police had been looking for Beltran since the strike because of allegations that he made seditious statements. Diokno said he would ``invite'' Beltran to police headquarters. After the program, Beltran was led away to a police car and driven to the Western Police District headquarters. Diokno said Beltran would be held overnight and that police would charge him with inciting to sedition and illegal assembly. Last week's strike was the most extensive since President Corazon Aquino took office in February 1986 during the ``people power revolution'' that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. The strike, which was called to demand a 42 percent increase in the daily minimum wage, paralyzed public transportation in Manila and other cities. Militants believed to include Communist rebels burned 23 buses, passenger jeeps and other vehicles during the labor unrest. Mrs. Aquino refused to grant the $1.50-a-day increase and instead told union leaders to refer their demand to a government-labor wage council. Later, the unions scaled down their demand to $1 a day, but Mrs. Aquino refused that request too. She also promised to punish strike leaders responsible for violence.

DOC.HEAD: Ferries Work Around The Clock to Get Tourists Off Island
DOC.TEXT: The number of cars waiting to get off Ocracoke and Hatteras Islands decreased to 180 today as ferry operators worked around the clock to rescue tourists stranded by a bridge collapse last week. At least 300 vehicles queued up at the Ocracoke ferry slip Monday. But today, only 50 cars were waiting to travel from Ocracoke to the mainland and 130 were waiting for a shorter ferry ride from Hatteras to Ocracoke. ``Our short-term goal is getting visitors off the island,'' Joe Myers, director of the state Division of Emergency Management, said at a Raleigh news conference Monday. Hundreds of tourists were trapped Friday when a dredge slammed into the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, severing the only road linking Hatteras and Ocracoke islands to the mainland. The accident also knocked out electrical power for the islands' 5,650 residents. Power was restored to most areas by Monday. Four ferries moving 150 cars every six hours are the only way off the islands. Travelers must take one ferry for the mile trip to Ocracoke, then another ferry 30 miles to the mainland. The complete trip takes about 3{ hours. Meyers said the ferries were working 24 hours a day. Buffy Warner, an owner of the Island Inn, a hotel within walking distance of the Ocracoke ferry slip, said the group of tourist waiting to leave had been calm. ``I think everybody's taking it pretty much in stride,'' Warner said. ``This is a pretty good crowd of people to be stranded.'' Getting one lane of the bridge open should take 45 to 90 days, depending on the weather, said Bill Marley, highway administrator with the North Carolina Department of Transportation. Replacing the span will cost at least $1 million, he said. Contractors should begin clearing the bridge debris from the Oregon Inlet by Wednesday, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Nuclear Reactors Shut Down Due to Breakdown
DOC.TEXT: Technicians at Bulgaria's sole nuclear plant shut down two of its five reactors today because of an unspecified breakdown, the state BTA news agency reported. The brief dispatch said the mishap occurred outside the plant's nuclear reactor core, but offered no other details. It said the two reactors, one with a capacity of 400 megawatts and another of 1,000 megawatts, were shut down as a precaution. The breakdown occurred less than a week after international experts expressed concern about safety at the plant and a day after Premier Andrei Lukanov pledged to shut it down if international safety standards could not be met. A review by the International Atomic Energy Agency found there were not enough senior operators or engineers at the plant at Kozlodui, located on the Danube River in northern Bulgaria. Earlier this month, workers at Kozlodui warned that a sixth reactor now under construction is flawed and could explode if started up. Despite a worsening energy crisis that already has resulted in some rationing of electricity, Lukanov said on Monday the plant, which provides 30 percent of the country's electricity, would be mothballed unless it could meet international safety standards.

DOC.HEAD: President Discusses Options With Aides, Congressional Leaders
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; trims at end to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's ``patience is wearing thin'' in the Persian Gulf crisis, one lawmaker reported today after a White House meeting that included discussion of possible military action. Congressional leaders emerging from the meeting said they had urged the president to explore all other avenues for resolving the crisis and got no indication that U.S. military action was imminent. ``His patience is wearing thin,'' said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, one of several lawmakers who met for an hour at the White House with the president. But Cohen added, ``for the time being, he's going to continue to pursue the course that we're currently on.'' Cohen said, ``there was no ... indication that we're at the near-break point,'' for moving from sanctions to military action against Iraq. Asked if Bush appeared to have a military strike on the front burner, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said, ``It's certainly on the burner and not ruled out.'' ``There's concern on Capital Hill ... that this is somehow a prelude to immediate military action,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said after the meeting. ``People want to make sure that options are explored,'' he said. Participants described Bush as highly disturbed at reports of atrocities in occupied Kuwait and the plight of U.S. Embassy personnel and other Americans who have been blocked from leaving. The lawmakers said Bush sought their opinions in what Leahy described as ``one of the livelier'' such sessions he has attended with the president. ``Nobody asked the president to rule out a military option,'' Leahy said, ``But many of us told him to make sure that we don't use the military option out of impatience, that we try the embargo the sanctions, the United Nations resoultions, our allies efforts first and foremost.'' Cohen, who has been outspoken in saying that Bush must get congressional approval before undertaking hostilities, said, ``There obviously is a difference of opinion in terms of whether that power resides with the executive branch or the congressional branch. I believe the president is doing his best to say `let's work together' and that's precisely what the thrust of the meeting was.'' Bush met with the leaders a day after he declared that he ``would have no hesitancy'' to using force if provoked by Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. At a picture-taking session at the beginning of the meeting, Bush brushed off a reporter's question on reports that administration officials plan to discuss a timetable with U.S. allies for a possible military offensive. ``I could, but I'm not going to comment'' on the story in today's editions of the Los Angeles Times, Bush said. The president also planned to meet with foreign policy advisers today. The Constitution gives Congress the power to declare war, although the president is commander-in-chief of the armed forces. Bush has held regular consultations with Congress on the gulf crisis since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait prompted him to send more than 200,000 troops to the region. But beyond that, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said recently the administration would not promise to get congressional approval if a decision was made to engage in armed conflict with Iraq. Baker was responding to calls by some lawmakers that Congress be called back into session to approve such an escalation. Bush told reporters Monday, ``I know the authorities that a president has. I'm working to try to get this matter resolved peacefully. We have a lot of force there and they're well-trained, they're highly motivated, and that alone is sending an enormously strong signal to Saddam Hussein.'' He noted he was consulting with congressional leaders today, adding: ``But history is replete with examples where the president has had to take action. And I've done this in the past and certainly - somebody mentioned provocation - would have no hesitancy at all.'' Bush and Baker both took a harder line toward Iraq on Monday while still saying they want to see a diplomatic solution if possible. ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait,'' Baker said in a speech in Los Angeles. Baker said Saddam ``must realize there is a limit to the international community's patience. He must also realize that should he use chemical or biological weapons, there will be the most severe consequences.''

DOC.HEAD: Bakker Lawyers Argue Appeal In Court
DOC.TEXT: Jim Bakker, the former televangelist convicted of defrauding his followers, was denied a fair trial and his sentence was excessive, his attorneys told a federal appeals court today. Most of the nearly 90-minute hearing before the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals focused on Bakker's 45-year sentence for 24 counts of wire fraud, mail fraud and conspiracy. Alan Dershowitz, a Harvard University law professor brought in for Bakker's appeal, said U.S. District Judge Robert Potter of Charlotte, N.C., made an ``incredible departure'' from federal sentencing guidelines. He said Bakker would have received a sentence of two to four years if the guidelines had been used. He asked that Bakker be resentenced by another judge. ``We, your honors, will take our chances,'' Dershowitz said. ``Let the chips fall where they may.'' Deborah Smith, a U.S. Justice Department lawyer, said Bakker would be eligible for parole after serving 10 years and could have received as much as 12 years without parole under the guidelines. ``I don't think this is a case where there is a broad disparity,'' she said. She said the judge did not have to apply the guidelines because the crimes took place before November 1987, when the guidelines took effect. Judges J. Harvie Wilkinson III, J. Dickson Phillips Jr. and John D. Butzner Jr. will decide whether to uphold Bakker's conviction and sentence. The founder of the PTL television ministry is serving his sentence at a federal prison in Rochester, Minn. Bakker was convicted of bilking followers of his television ministry out of millions of dollars. Three other former PTL officials also have been convicted for their roles in the scheme. In a brief filed with the appeals court, Bakker's attorneys also said Potter was influenced by his religious beliefs when he gave Bakker an overly harsh sentence. Before sentencing Bakker a year ago, Potter said the televangelist ``had no thought whatsever about his victims, and those of us who do have a religion are ridiculed as being saps (for) money-grubbing preachers or priests.'' The lawyers also argued that Potter failed to ensure that Bakker got a fair and impartial jury because the judge refused to move the trial out of Charlotte and refused to sequester the jury during the trial. They said Potter should have delayed the trial after Bakker was hospitalized briefly at a federal prison in Butner, N.C., for a competency examination. Potter ordered the evaluation after Bakker's attorneys said he was depressed and began hallucinating after leaving court the previous day. Bakker was declared fit to stand trial and the trial resumed.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ethics Order Gives White House Lawyer Power to Police Himself
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has granted White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray a power denied everyone else in government - authority to permit himself to decide issues in which he might have a conflict of interest. The authority is contained in a new presidential order on ethics issued Oct. 17. White House and federal ethics officials who helped prepare the order expressed surprise this past week when shown that the document authorizes Gray to exempt his own actions from criminal conflict-of-interest laws. Nevertheless they were confident that Gray, who once said ``I was my own ethics officer'' while counsel to then-Vice President Bush, would never actually use the authority. Gray himself declined to respond to a week's worth of telephone calls. ``Mr. Gray would never grant a waiver for himself,'' said deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen. ``In the event that that hypothetically were to ever come up, the president would be the decider.'' Government employees who take official action that could affect their personal or family finances are subject to criminal penalties. However, a supervisor can allow an employee to participate in a particular case anyway by ruling in advance that the employee's financial interest is ``too remote or too inconsequential'' to influence his or her decision. That ruling waives the penalties. Ms. Glen said last week's order contained minor ``fine-tuning'' - only a handful of changes in five pages of rules - in the ethics order Bush issued last year for executive branch employees. In the new version, Bush gave Gray his authority to waive the conflict-of-interest penalties for certain White House staffers. Neither Gray nor those staffers are mentioned by name, which may be the reason for the oversight by government lawyers who prepared the order for Bush. It says the counsel to the president - Gray - can grant waivers to every employee hired under a specific section of federal law. That section is the one under which Gray himself was hired. At the Office of Government Ethics, which polices executive branch employees, General Counsel Gary Davis said the wording of the new order was ``a technical point.'' ``That's a quirk in the statute,'' Davis added. ``But that would be the last thing he would ever do. That would be political suicide. They would never in 100 years do that.'' During his eight years as counsel to Vice President Bush, Gray, a multimillionaire, served as chairman and trustee of his family's cable television and broadcasting company, Summit Communications Group, Inc. of Atlanta. He also received more than $200,000 in fees from Summit during those years. Those arrangements were not barred at the office of the vice president where Gray, by his own declaration, set the ethics rules. At the time, he was working side-by-side with Reagan White House employees bound by unwritten policies that banned earning outside income or serving on corporate boards. When Gray moved to the White House with Bush, he resigned the corporate post, and he has put large blocks of his holdings into two blind trusts. He still retains control over more than $1 million in assets and receives income from a family trust that also has more than $1 million in assets, according to his 1990 financial disclosure statement. The family trust contains more than $250,000 in Summit stock and more than $250,000 in stock of Media General, a newspaper publishing and television broadcasting corporation. Gray reported dividends in 1989 of between $50,000 and $100,000 on the Summit stock and between $15,000 and $50,000 on the Media General stock. Also outside his blind trusts are substantial investments in real estate limited partnerships, which are commonly used by the very wealthy as tax shelters. Ms. Glen said Gray holds no current exemption from the conflict statute and foresees no need of one. Presidential orders such as Bush's are regularly reviewed in advance at the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel. Larry Simms, a former deputy assistant attorney general who served in that office during the Carter and Reagan administrations, said such a drafting error, ``ought to be pointed out.'' ``It ought to be changed or some document put in the record to clarify the intent. Someday everyone who drafted it (with an unstated intent) will be dead,'' Simms said. Asked if an amendment or clarifying document were planned, Ms. Glen said, ``It's not considered necessary to amend it, because it is evident that one cannot decide a waiver for oneself.''

DOC.HEAD: Sisters Support Each Other on the Farm
LaserPhoto GRF1
DOC.TEXT: Florence and Hildred Newsom have gone through tough times and good times on their farm, even through cancer surgery. But the two elderly sisters wouldn't live anywhere else. Florence, 75, took care of the cattle while 70-year-old Hildred cooked, cleaned, made the cottage cheese for their dairy route and delivered eggs to dozens of customers. That was the routine the sisters followed before they had cancer surgery during the same week last May. Now, they take life easier, but not much easier. ``Everything came to a screeching halt when she went to the hospital April 30,'' Hildred recalled. ``She told the nurse down at the hospital that she knew something was wrong because she couldn't lift two bales at one time.'' Shortly after Florence was hospitalized for colon cancer surgery, Hildred checked into the hospital for a mastectomy. Hildred was released from the hospital in May, but Florence suffered two small strokes after her surgery and was in therapy until July. Hildred nursed her sister back to health, giving her medicine 14 times a day and setting out a table of fruits, nuts and candy to encourage her to eat in between meals so she'd put on some pounds. Florence did her part by lifting 2-pound rocks in each arm and rolling a hay bale back and forth. It's a type of therapy she prescribed for herself. ``I'd roll it up and back and up and back and every 10th time I'd lift it,'' Florence said. The two sisters never married. When Florence was younger, she took care of the livestock and raked and hauled hay with a 1952 tractor, while her brother, Melvin, who now lives in Bismarck, raised the crops. ``I worked 16-hour days and then came in at night and read and wrote,'' Florence said. ``Any white piece of paper was a challenge.'' She published her first story in the ``Dakota Farmer'' when she was 10 and continued writing for the magazine for several years. For the last 15 years she's written a weekly column called ``By the Way'' for the Herald-Press in Harvey. Most of her columns are about nature. She's a student of birds, rocks, grass. She can hear a flock of geese flying over the farmyard long before someone with an untrained ear. Her keen interest in nature led her to become an observer for the National Weather Service. She recently received a citation for recording barometric pressure, wind direction and precipitation daily for 10 years. While Hildred doesn't talk about nature as much as Florence, she loves living on the farm. She lived in Bismarck in the late 1950s and '60s before returning to the farm to help care for her mother, who was ill. The pace has slowed for the sisters now. They sold their 100 hens a couple of weeks ago and don't milk the cow anymore. But don't ask them to leave the farm. ``People in town are telling us we shouldn't be out here,'' Hildred said. ``There's a businessman in town who says he has a house picked out for us. ``I don't want to live in town. Twelve years of it was enough.''
