List of Fatalities in Operation Desert Shield
With PM-Gulf Rdp, PM-Gulf-Fatal Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with another sailor dying.
DOC.TEXT: Forty American military personnel have been killed during Operation Desert Shield. Here is a list: --- Oct. 30 - Eight American sailors died when a steam line ruptured in the boiler room of the USS Iwo Jima. Oct. 30 - One Marine was killed when the vehicle in which he was riding overturned in the Saudi Arabian desert. Oct. 10 - A U.S. Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. Oct. 8 - In Saudi Arabia, two U.S. pilots died in the crash of a RF4C Phantom reconnaisance jet belonging to a unit of the Alabama Air National Guard. Oct. 8 - Two UH-1 helicopters, carrying eight Marines, vanished during a training flight. Searchers find debris in the north Arabian Sea but no bodies. Sept. 30 - Two Air Force pilots were killed when their F-15 fighter plane crashed during an exercise in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 26 - A Marine Corps staff sergeant from the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing in Saudi Arabia died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Sept. 20 - An Army specialist from the 82nd Airborne was killed in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 14 - An officer from the U.S. Army's 24th Infantry Division was killed when his vehicle left the road and crashed in Saudi Arabia. Aug. 29 - A C-5A transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf crashed and burned shortly after takeoff from Germany, killing 13 crew members. Aug. 21 - An electrician's mate aboard the USS Antietam was electrocuted in an accident while working on the ship's ventilation system. Aug. 12 - An Air Force Staff sergeant died when he was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Sailors Killed By Boiler Accident Aboard USS Iwo Jima
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with death of another injured sailor. Pickup 9th graf pvs ``The ship...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
LaserPhotos DOD1,2,NY20
DOC.TEXT: A pipe ruptured today in the boiler room of the USS Iwo Jima, releasing steam that killed eight American sailors and severely injured two. In a separate accident, one Marine was killed and three others were injured today when the vehicle they were traveling in overturned in the Saudi desert, the U.S. military Joint Information Bureau said in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The Information Bureau also reported today that three U.S. Navy sailors traveling in a military pickup truck were injured Monday when a U.S. Marine Corps sentry accidentally opened fire. The Iwo Jima's commander, Capt. Michael O'Hearn, called the accident aboard the amphibious assault ship ``a terrible setback.'' Cmdr. Mark Neuhart, spokesman for the U.S. Naval Forces Central Command, said the steam line in the boiler room ruptured as the Iwo Jima was sailing out of Bahrain after a routine port visit. The ship has been operating since Sept. 16 as part of the Amphibious Task Force in support of Operation Desert Shield, the Navy said. Neuhart said four sailors were critically injured. They were taken to the hospital ship USS Comfort in the gulf, where two of them later died. Neuhart said the names of the victims would be released after their relatives have been notified. The bodies will be flown home today, he said. The ship went back to Bahrain for inspection and assessment of the damage, Neuhart said. Repairs will be done in Bahrain, he said. Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle, Navy spokesman in Dhahran, said steam in a line such as the one that leaked could be as hot as 850 degrees. Interviewed by the Navy aboard his ship, O'Hearn said: ``We will overcome this terrible setback. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of those who have departed us.'' In addition to the deaths aboard the Iwo Jima and the fatality in the desert accident today, 32 U.S. servicemen have died since Operation Desert Shield began Aug. 7, five days after Iraqi troops overran Kuwait. The Iwo Jima, based in Norfolk, Va., has a crew of 685 officers and crewmen and about 1,100 Marines. The victims were all crew members, Neuhart said. The 602-foot-long, 84-foot-wide vessel displaces 18,000 tons. It was the second fatal accident aboard a U.S. Navy vessel since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait prompted the American miliary deployment. On Aug. 21, an electrician's mate was electrocuted aboard the USS Antietam. The worst previous incident linked to Operation Desert Shield occurred Aug. 29 when a C-5A transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the gulf crashed and burned shortly after takeoff in Germany, killing 13 crew members. In the desert accident, a Marine from the 1st Batallion, 3rd Marine died and three others were injured when their High Mobility multipurpose vehicle, known as a Humvee, overturned. The four had been participating in a routine night exercise when their vehicle went over an embankment and dropped approximately 20 feet, the U.S. military command said in a statement. It said the three injured Marines were in stable condition. The four names were withheld pending notification of next of kin. In the accident Monday involving the sailors and the Marine sentry, the sentry fired two 50-caliber rounds of ammunition at the pickup carrying the sailors, the military information bureau said. It said only that the sailors were approaching the entrance to a facility being used by the Marine Corps. One sailor was struck by the bullet, the second was injured by glass shards and the third suffered a concussion. All three were evacuated to the Comfort. Their names also were witheld pending notification of next of kin.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Problems, Dyson Holding His Own in Congressional Race
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Roy Dyson never really stopped campaigning after he came within a hair of losing his House seat to Republican Wayne Gilchrest in 1988. Dyson, a five-term Democrat from Maryland's 1st District, has been pummelled in the last two years by questions about his ties to defense contractors, the suicide of his chief aide and improper campaign financing. Most recently, the hawkish Dyson was criticized for being a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War. Gilchrest won the Purple Heart for his service in Vietnam. But Dyson's tenacity has made the rematch with Gilchrest, a race that GOP leaders had thought was sure to go their way this year, too close to call. ``I have no idea'' why Dyson is doing so well, said Liz Hamel, spokeswoman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, which put Dyson near the top of its hit list of vulnerable Democratic representatives. ``He's just a complete embarrassment,'' she said. ``Hopefully, this time the voters will realize it.'' Dyson campaign manager Chris Robinson says the Democrat made a ``prodigious rehabilitation effort'' after political novice Gilchrest came within 1,400 votes of upsetting him two years ago. ``When the campaign was over in 1988, we went right back to work,'' Robinson said. ``(Dyson) attended 70 town meetings in the last two years. We never stopped.'' Dyson must not only overcome the ethical questions that have beset his campaign, but also the anti-incumbency mood that has settled on the district. Gilchrest, a quiet, likeable schoolteacher, is the antithesis of the professional politician. On leave from his teaching job, Gilchrest is waging a low-tech, tight budget campaign. He spends 18-hour days shaking hands and addressing the issues. He's paid $208 a week from his campaign chest. Campaign manager Tony Caligiuri says voters see Gilchrest as ``someone they can talk with.'' But other GOP officials say they're afraid that Gilchrest's diffidence - sometimes to the point of shyness - is a liability. He needs to toughen his message, supporters say privately, adding that his nice-guy campaign is letting Dyson off too easy. ``I haven't liked negative campaigns per se. That's not my style,'' Gilchrest said. He has disavowed two television ads paid for by the independent Free State Republican Fund that bitterly attack Dyson. Dyson contends the group is working with Gilchrest. ``They are like tag-team wrestlers,'' Dyson said. ``Gilchrest is trying to come off as Mr. Clean, while the Free State Republicans throw mud.'' Gilchrest's major problem is money. Dyson had collected more than $650,000 in campaign contributions through Oct. 17, much of it from political action committees associated with organized labor, agriculture and defense. Dyson had raised $177,000. Dyson, who sits on the House Armed Services Committee, has been in trouble since 1988 when his name surfaced in connection with the Pentagon procurement scandal. While never the subject of an investigation, Dyson accepted $18,000 in contributions from defense industry lobbyists later convicted of bribery. He returned the money last year. In May 1988, Dyson's top aide and political mentor, Tom Pappas, committed suicide the day The Washington Post reported that he had recruited single young men for Dyson's staff and required them to spend their free time socializing with him and other staff members. In 1989, Dyson was fined by the Federal Election Commission for irregularities in his campaign finance reports. Then, late this summer, Dyson revealed that he had been a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War. The announcement came a day after The Washington Post sought an interview to discuss his draft records. The Gilchrest camp capitalized on that revelation, airing ads by Adrian Cronauer, the former military disc jockey made famous by the movie, ``Good Morning, Vietnam.'' ``I want to tell you about Wayne Gilchrest, a Marine who won the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star in Vietnam,'' Cronauer says in the radio ad. ``Wayne Gilchrest is a man of character who answered the call then ... and now he's ready to serve his country once more.'' Former Republican state Sen. Porter Hopkins, who lost to Dyson in 1982, rates Gilchrest's chances at 50-50. However, he said Dyson is more in tune politically with the conservative district than the more moderate Gilchrest. ``As far as Gilchrest is concerned, people admire his guts ... but I detect a good number of people who think he's too liberal i a number of areas,'' Hopkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Old Revolutionary Bemoans Abandoning of Term `Comrade'
DOC.TEXT: An old revolutionary scolded his countrymen Tuesday for abandoning use of the term ``comrade,'' once a common form of address in Communist China. ``Some people say `comrade' ... is out of date now. This is muddled thinking,'' Li Huang said in a signed commentary in the People's Daily, the Communist Party newspaper. ``I still consider being called comrade the greatest honor.'' In the early days of Chinese communism, he said, the term ``comrade'' meant respect, admiration and common aspirations. ``When (you) encountered difficulties, a comrade would give (you) faith and wisdom,'' Li said. But in recent years, the term has become increasingly rare in China's large cities as people switch to using professional titles or simply calling ``Miss'' or ``Sir'' to get a shop attendant's attention. Li contended that using professional titles reflects a return to the class system of old China and confused political thinking. ``That we can today call each other comrade is not ... a simple thing. It symbolizes the victory of the revolution and was exchanged for the blood of countless martyrs,'' said Li, who described himself as a retired Communist Party member. The paper's editorial department said by telephone that Li was an old cadre from Jilin province, but it could provide no other biographical information. A man by the same name was listed in government directories as being a ranking party official in northeast China's Liaoning province from the 1950s to the 1970s, but it was not known if he was the same Li who wrote the commentary. Li railed against television and radio shows that refer to ``audience friends'' rather than ``audience comrades.'' He said he called a station to ask why ``comrades'' had been dropped and was told that not everyone in the audience is necessarily a ``comrade'' and that the term carries political overtones. But Li countered, ``Can you say that everyone in the audience is a friend? ... (And) to be socialist is to be political. What's to fear in being too political?''

DOC.HEAD: Baker To Meet With Shevardnadze on Gulf Consultation Trip
With AM-Bush-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze during a visit to Islamic and European countries to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the State Department said Tuesday. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said they will meet Nov. 9 at an undisclosed location on the final stop of Baker's week-long tour. Baker and Shevardnadze will also discuss arms control issues, she said. Baker will confer on Sunday with officials in Bahrain and meet with the Emir of Kuwait on Monday in Taif, Saudi Arabia. He will confer with Saudi officials in Jiddah later that day. Ms. Tutwiler said Baker will spend Tuesday in Egypt and Turkey and Wednesday in France. After meetings Thursday in Great Britain, he will travel to another European country for talks Friday and Saturday with Shevardnadze. Ms. Tutwiler emphasized the itinerary is subject to change. Baker said on Monday he had no plans to visit Israel during the trip because he wants toavoid the impression there is a link between the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israeli dispute. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has attempted to draw parallels between the two situations.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Marcinkus Ends Four-Decade Vatican Career
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the American prelate linked to Italy's biggest postwar banking scandal, said Tuesday he was retiring and returning to the United States, ending a four-decade Vatican career. The 68-year-old native of Cicero, Ill., who resigned from the post he still held as deputy governor of the Vatican city-state, said he planned to take up pastoral work in Chicago. Pope John Paul II accepted the resignation after repeated requests from Marcinkus, the Vatican said. American bishops issued statements praising Marcinkus and welcoming him back to the United States. Marcinkus was president of the Vatican bank for 20 years, until 1989 when the job was eliminated under a reorganization of the Institute of Religious Works, the bank's formal name. He has maintained he was innocent of any wrongdoing. During his tenure, the Vatican finances were clouded by scandal. Over the past decade, two Italian financiers with close ties to the Vatican, Michele Sindona and Roberto Calvi, died under mysterious circumstances. The 6-foot-4-inch prelate acted as a bodyguard to the pope during his early foreign travels and seemed headed for promotion to cardinal when the banking scandal broke. ``I have never done anything wrong,'' Marcinkus said Tuesday, adding that some day ``I would like to set the record straight.'' But he said: ``I don't want people to think I have sour grapes. I want to leave here on a happy note.'' Warrants for the arrest of Marcinkus and two lay Vatican bank officials were issued in 1987. Italian prosecutors charged them with being accessories to the fraudulent bankruptcy of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's largest private bank, which collapsed in 1982 following the disappearance of $1.3 billion. But the arrests were never carried out. Italy's Constitutional Court ruled that a Vatican-Italian treaty precluded any interference by Italian authorities in the affairs of the Vatican, an independent city-state. The missing money was in loans made to 10 fake companies in Latin America controlled by the Vatican bank. Banco Ambrosiano had loaned the money during the presidency of Calvi, popularlyknown as ``God's banker'' because of his close ties to the Vatican. Calvi was found hanging from a London bridge in June 1982. The Vatican bank, a major shareholder in Banco Ambrosiano, agreed to pay $250 million to the Italian bank's creditors but denied any wrongdoing. The scandal, however, led the Vatican to bring in leading lay financial experts to manage the bank, a move that cost Marcinkus his post. Marcinkus had been a familar figure on the golf course of one of Rome's most exclusive clubs, but lowered his public profile following the Ambrosiano case. The second financier, Sindona, who also advised the Vatican on financial matters, died in March, 1986, while serving a life sentence for ordering the death of a bank examiner investigating his financial affairs. He died after drinking a poisoned cup of coffee. A magistrate ruled he had committed suicide. In a statement, Marcinkus said he had spent 40 years away from home and it was time to return. ``Now that I am free from administrative responsibilities, I plan to return to the United States and make myself useful in whatever pastoral work I may be able to do, much like many priests of my diocese are doing,'' he said. Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago, in a statement released by the Vatican, praised Marcinkus for his ``great dedication to the church and his personal integrity.'' ``I have assured Archbishop Marcinkus, a native son, that the door to his home diocese will always be open to him. The archdiocese of Chicago is proud to claim him as a member of its presbyterate,'' the statement said. Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said: ``As spokesman for the bishops of our country, I am pleased and proud to say, `Thanks Paul. And welcome home.''' In its brief announcement, the Vatican said the pope named Marcinkus a consultant to the commission overseeing the Vatican city-state, essentially an honorary post that can be held while living elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Suffering `Terrible Ordeal' in Iraq and Kuwait, Baker Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Moves pvs grafs 16-17, bgng, Baker will... to grafs 4-5 to raise element of Baker trip
DOC.TEXT: U.S. hostages in Iraq and Kuwait are suffering a ``terrible ordeal,'' being fed inadequate diets and forced to sleep on vermin-ridden floors, Secretary of State James A. Baker III says. Baker shed new light on the hostages' plight in a speech Monday in Los Angeles. A text was made available by the State Department. ``They are kept in the dark during the day and moved only at night,'' Baker said. ``They have had their meals cut to two a day. And many are becoming sick as they endure a terrible ordeal.'' Baker will embark on a week-long visit to Arab and European countries starting Saturday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said today. The purpose will be to consult on futurnited States is ``exhausting every diplomatic avenue'' to achieve peace in the Persian Gulf, but warned that military action may be taken against Iraq if it continues to occupy Kuwait. ``Saddam Hussein must realize there is a limit to the international community's patience,'' Baker said. ``He must also realize that should he use chemical or biological weapons, there will be the most severe consequences.'' Baker reaffirmed that the United States strongly prefers a peaceful solution consistent with the mandate of U.N. Security Council resolutions. ``We are exhausting every diplomatic avenue to achieve such a solution without further bloodshed,'' he said. He added: ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait.'' Later, under questioning, Baker reaffirmed that American policy toward the gulf cannot be influenced by the existence of almost 1,000 American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait even though their lives may be endangered by military action. Asked about diplomatic efforts to achieve a solution, other officials said the administration is closely monitoring efforts by Soviet and Jordanian emissaries, among others, to determine whether there is any flexibility in Iraq's position. Baker said that while the international community tries to build on the successful ending of the Cold War, ``Saddam Hussein seems hellbent on a revival of a hot war.'' Baker asked, ``What can be the long-term meaning of Iraq's extensive chemical and biological weapons program? Why is the Iraqi dictator spending billions of dollars to build weapons of mass destruction, including a nuclear bomb? And why has he turned Baghdad into a haven for international terrorists? Surely, not because he expects this aggression - first against Iran, now against Kuwait - to be his last.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Conducts Columbia Fueling Test, Sets Atlantis Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with no dangerous leaks found but test continuing. Picks up 3rd graf, `NASA officials...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA fueled Columbia today for an elaborate test to determine whether the shuttle is leak-free and ready for an astronomy mission in December, and early results indicated a tight spaceship. ``Managers are very happy with the testing so far,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. ``All the work completed here by the Kennedy Space Center launch team has proved to be successful.'' Liquid hydrogen was pumped into Columbia's huge external tank this afternoon. The engine compartment was fitted with 10 TV cameras and 17 sensors to pinpoint any more of the dangerous leaks that forced three of the shuttle's four launch postponements since May. A small amount of hydrogen escaped into the engine compartment during the test, but was well within allowable limits, Malone said. Nevertheless, NASA continued filling the tank to make sure that rate did not increase. NASA officials, meanwhile, set Nov. 9 as the launch date for Atlantis, also grounded this summer by hydrogen leaks. The shuttle was cleared for flight after a successful fueling test last week. Atlantis will carry into orbit a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq. The launch is scheduled for sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST; the precise time will not be announced until nine minutes before liftoff because of the classified nature of the Defense Department mission. A successful test on the repaired Columbia would allow NASA to move ahead with plans for a December launch with the $150 million Astro observatory. That would enable NASA to close the year with six shuttle flights, three fewer than planned. ``I've been optimistic before and I've been disappointed, so I'm trying to stay calm,'' Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of Columbia's prelaunch operations, said Monday. Cameras and sensors were mounted in Columbia's engine compartment, more monitoring equipment than for any other shuttle fueling test. Suspect joints were covered with plastic bags. New hydrogen lines were installed, a crushed seal was replaced and numerous joints were tightened to try to eliminate the leaks. Officials believe workers accidentally damaged components in the engine compartment while searching for contamination following the shuttle's last flight, in January.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Refuses to Release Stranded British Airways 747
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Tuesday it will not hand over a British Airways Boeing 747 jetliner stranded at Kuwait airport until the airline sends back Iraqi Airways engines it received for maintenance. Shipments like the one demanded by Iraqi Airways are barred under an embargo the United Nations imposed to force Iraq to withdraw from occupied Kuwait. Apart from 15 Kuwait Airways planes captured by Iraq, the BA jumbo jet is the only foreign plane that has remained in Iraq's hands since the invasion. Iraqi Airways Chairman Noureddin Saffi said the British aircraft ``cannot be released until BA releases Iraqi Airways engines under overhaul with BA.'' The pilots and attendants of the British Airways flight were trapped in Kuwait when their plane was captured during the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2. But Saffi said the staff is ``free to travel abroad.'' Saffi's comments were contained in a letter to Guenter Eser, head of the International Air Transport Association, which represents 200 member airlines. The group's general assembly on Monday demanded that Iraq ``release immediately all passengers including those in transit, airline employees and aircraft'' held as a result of the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, UAW Reach Contract Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, adds Chrysler negotiator declining comment. Also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and the United Auto Workers union today agreed on a national contract for 63,000 workers in eight states. UAW President Owen Bieber said the terms were similar to those of contracts with the nation's two biggest automakers. ``We have achieved a pattern settlement for our members here at Chrysler,'' Bieber said after a private meeting with Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca. Bieber declined to discuss details of the pact before it is presented to union leaders and rank-and-file members. Chrysler negotiator Anthony St. John also refused to disuss the contract. ``There are elements in that agreement which are particularly helpful to Chrysler's case,'' he said without elaborating. The union's contract with Chrysler expired Sept. 14 and an extension expired at midnight Monday. But the union urged its members at the No. 3 automaker to stay on the job while talks continued through the night. Bieber and Iacocca met this morning in Iacocca's offices. The UAW already had reached new contracts with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. and said it hoped to take many of the same provisions to Chrysler, which was in more precarious financial shape and which reported a $214 million third-quarter loss this week. Chrysler had said it might be unable to afford the GM-Ford pattern agreement, but the union wanted nothing less. Major issues that remained unresolved Monday included job security, health care and pensions. The strategy of extending a contract, then canceling the extension even while asking union members to report to work puzzled some UAW members. Some union workers said they were ready to strike if the talks dragged on. But a source close to the bargaining who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: ``A strike is just unthinkable.'' The UAW last struck Chrysler in 1985. Chrysler workers, after hearing for months from their union leaders that they would settle for nothing less than the GM-Ford agreement, have been wearing buttons in past weeks reading, ``Pattern or Pickets.'' Among the main features of the pattern contract are income guarantees for laid-off workers, pension increases and no change in health care. The last two items could cause Chrysler the most problems. Chrysler's ratio of nearly one retiree for every active worker is much higher than GM's or Ford's. Consequently, Chrysler's health-care bill is higher than that of the other automakers. The company said it spent about $684 million in health care last year. In addition to Michigan, Missouri and Delaware, Chrysler has plants in Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, New York and Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Government Forces Fire on Hindus, Killing 5, Wounding 20
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with three more dead outside Ayodhya; Pickup 20th, `The army...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AYO1
DOC.TEXT: Government forces fired on thousands of Hindu fundamentalists who broke through police barricades Tuesday and forced their way into a heavily guarded mosque. Five Hindus were killed and 20 wounded. At least 26 people were killed in other parts of India as the decades-old dispute between Hindus and Moslems over ownership of the site came to a head. The controversy has left at least 138 people dead in the past week, brought Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government close to collapse and further strained already tense relations between India's Hindu majority and Moslem minority.
DOC.HEAD: Singh, who opposes the Hindu campaign to replace the 16th-century
DOC.TEXT: Moslem mosque, on Tuesday repeated his offer to resign if his party thought it would help contain the sectarian violence. He made a similar offer Monday. Hindu fundamentalists had said they would start construction Tuesday on a temple to the god Rama on the site occupied by the mosque. The government said it would block any attempt to destroy the small, one-story shrine and arrested 90,000 supporters of the fundamentalist World Hindu Council in the past week. On Tuesday, 10,000 Hindus stormed police barricades outside the disputed shrine. Police first used tear gas and bamboo canes to beat back the crowd. Then, after several hours of clashes as the crowds pushed closer and closer to the mosque, the police fired rifles. Reporters saw four bodies, but a government spokesman in New Delhi later said five people were killed. Witnesses said at least 20 people were wounded. S.K. Gupta, a doctor at a local hospital, said 13 of the injured were in serious condition. ``They have only 10 percent chances of survival,'' he said. Thousands of young men wearing orange headbands, the color of the Hind faith, broke through successive police cordons, entered the small mosque, pried bricks from the wall and chipped bits of plaster from its three domes. They planted an orange flag on each dome before police chased them away. Many Hindus said they were helped by policemen guarding the mosque, which the fundamentalists say stands on the spot where Rama was born. Most of the 20,000 policemen on duty in Ayodhya are Hindus. While the crowds rushed toward the mosque, Hindu holy men screamed obscenities from rooftops and pelted police with stones. At least four policemen were injured. As news spread that the police barricades had been breached, hundreds of Hindus poured into the streets of Ayodhya in defiance of the 4-day-old curfew that had confined them to their homes. Many distributed candy and exploded firecrackers to shouts of ``Jai siya Rama!'' - ``Victory to Rama!'' Many policemen were seen entering the disputed shrine to pray. The World Hindu Council said its success in penetrating police lines meant the temple project had begun. ``In my 19 years of service, I have never experienced such a sense of failure,'' a senior government official at the site said on condition of anonymity. ``It was a collapse of the administration.'' Later, paramilitary troops cleared the shrine of intruders and threatened to open fire if any further attempts were made to breach the barricades. The government's chief spokesman, Ramamohan Rao, said the mosque was not seriously damaged. He spoke in New Delhi, 300 miles northwest of Ayodhya. In several towns hundreds of miles from Ayodhya, Hindus and Moslems fought street battles and police opened fire on rioting mobs. In those incidents, 25 were killed in street battles and the police firing, while one Hindu committed suicide in protest. The army was called out in two towns in the western state of Gujarat. Police in New Delhi said the situation in the capital was tense and troops were alert for trouble. Prime Minister Singh's government lost its patchwork majority in Parliament last week after The Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support over the government's stand on the Ayodhya dispute. On Tuesday, Singh offered to resign if his party felt ``that change of leadership will serve larger goals.'' ``What is closest to my heart is that at this juncture the country be saved from communal flames,'' Singh said in a letter to his Janata Dal party president, Somappa Rayappa Bommai. Singh is scheduled to face a vote of confidence Nov. 7. Bharatiya Janata has said it will oppose Singh's continuing in office. The Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the largest group in Parliament, has made a similar announcement. The Congress and Bharatiya Janata together hold 281 seats - a majority in the 522-member Parliament. Bharatiya Janata says Singh's policy on the dispute is aimed at garnering Moslem votes. The Congress accused him of faulty administration that brought the Hindu-Moslem dispute to a boil. Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people. Athough India is constitutionally a secular nation, Hindus comprise 82 percent of the population and have always held the prime minister's post. At least 900 people were killed in Hindu-Moslem violence last year after the Hindu group announced plans to replace the mosque with a temple.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Defends Rejection of EC Monetary Union
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, isolated in the European Community and sliding in opinion polls at home, on Tuesday defended her rejection of the European Community's leap toward monetary union. In a rowdy Parliament session, opposition parties accused her of ``tantrum tactics,'' being rude to the other leaders and undermining British influence at an EC summit in Rome over the weekend. ``In my view, we have surrendered enough,'' Mrs. Thatcher told lawmakers. ``What is the point of trying to get elected to Parliament only to hand over your sterling and your powers to Europe? ... It is not our policy to have a single currency imposed on us.'' The angry exchanges came when Mrs. Thatcher reported to Parliament on the Rome meeting. Leaders of the other countries - including powerful Germany - unexpectedly agreed to establish a joint central bank by Jan. 1, 1994, and a single currency possibly by the year 2000. Mrs. Thatcher argues that one currency infringes on national sovereignty by robbing governments of the right to set interest rates or run independent economic policies. ``Your tantrum tactics won't stop the process of change,'' said Neil Kinnock, leader of the main opposition Labor Party. ``All they do is strand Britain in some European second division.'' Labor also opposes a single European currency and Kinnock directed his attacks mainly at her tactics and confrontational style. Paddy Ashdown, leader of the small centrist Liberal Democratic Party, the only British party that supports the idea of some kind of federal Europe, shouted at Mrs. Thatcher: ``You no longer speak for Britain. You speak for the past.'' The divisive issue of Britain's role in Europe has revived as the Mrs. Thatcher slides deeper into trouble. Some worried legislators now say openly that Mrs. Thatcher appears likely to lose the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. Two opinion polls, by Harris and by Market and Opinion Research International, published over the weekend showed Labor surging to a 16-point lead over the Conservatives, compared with 7 to 10 points a month ago. The deficit in poll ratings has persisted for 16 months, and the economic troubles - the main cause of the government's unpopularity - show few signs of going away. The Confederation of British Industry, the main employers' organization, on Tuesday issued its gloomiest report since Britain plunged into recession in 1981, two years after Mrs. Thatcher came to power. Half the 1,500 companies surveyed by the organization reported falling orders and most said they had stopped hiring or were laying off staff. Mrs. Thatcher, who has long fought lonely battles in the 12-member community, attacked her neighbors - particularly France and Germany - for failing to agree to cut farm subsidies while making commitments to grandiose plans for economic union and for closer political ties. But she added: ``When we come to negotiate on particular points, rather than concepts or generalities, I believe solutions will be found which will enable the community to go forward as 12.''

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Strike Leader Arrested After Nationwide Strike
DOC.TEXT: The nation's most prominent labor leader was arrested Tuesday, nearly a week after leading a nationwide strike marked by unprecedented attacks on public transport. Crispin Beltran, leader of the leftist May First Movement, was arrested after he and Manila police chief Col. Ernesto Diokno appeared on television to discuss the strike, which began last Wednesday and was suspended Friday. During the program, Diokno said police had been looking for Beltran since the strike because he allegedly had made seditious statements. Beltran had been in hiding until appearing on the program. Beltran was later led to a police car and driven to the Western Police District headquarters. Diokno said he would be held overnight and would be formally charged Wednesday with inciting sedition and illegal assembly. Last week's strike was the most extensive since President Corazon Aquino took office in February 1986 in the ``people power revolution'' that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. The strike, called to demand a 42 percent increase in the daily minimum wage, paralyzed public transport in Manila and other cities. Militants, believed to include Communist rebels, burned 23 buses, passenger jeeps and other vehicles during the labor unrest. Such attacks had not taken place during previous strikes. On the day before the walkout, unknown assailants killed the leader of a transport federation, Oscar Lazaro, who had refused to join the strike. Beltran's arrest was expected to increase tension between the Aquino government and organized labor. The government has said the strike was Communist-run, although the May First Movement denies the claim. Beltran denied he was trying to overthrow the government and said his activities were a legitimate right of organized labor. ``It's up to them to file charges but they should have evidence,'' Beltran told reporters. ``What is clear is we are exhausting all the avenues for a peaceful settlement of the issues.'' In a related development, a human rights group said Tuesday a regional strike leader was slain by unknown assailants. The Catholic Church-backed Task Force Detainees branch in Bataan province said Rey Olano, secretary-general of the Alliance of Democratic Labor Organizations at the Bataan Export Processing Zone, was shot Monday. Olano led affiliated unions in actions that paralyzed eight companies for four days in Mariveles town, about 40 miles west of Manila. He was shot by gunmen on a motorcycle, the group said.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino: Bases Talks to Resume Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Filipino and American negotiators will resume talks next month on the future of the U.S. military bases in the Philippines, President Corazon Aquino said Tuesday. Speaking at a luncheon with foreign newsmen, Mrs. Aquino also said the Philippines wanted to take over the giant Clark Air Base north of Manila next year. But she said the government was considering American requests to allow U.S. military air transit and the continued use of Crowe Valley, a live-fire training range for U.S. jets located at Clark. The subject will be among the matters taken up in the next round of talks, she said. The United States maintains Clark, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities under an agreement that expires in September 1991. The Philippine constitution requires a treaty to keep the facilities after 1991. Mrs. Aquino expressed hopes for a ``new relationship'' between the United States and the Philippines ``not confined to the bases alone.'' ``I think it is best that the Philippines and the United States view each other not only in regard to the bases but more importantly on the overall relationship,'' she said. ``I, for one, am for retaining the friendship with the United States. At the same time I would like for the United States government to realize that our goal is one of national sovereignty.'' Philippine and U.S. negotiators held the first round of talks last month. Mrs. Aquino said the next session would be held before she leaves for Japan to attend the Nov. 12 enthronement ceremonies for Emperor Akihito.

DOC.HEAD: Nary a Pumpkin Patch in Pumpkin Center
DOC.TEXT: Pumpkin Center has a convenience store, general store and auto parts shop but nary a pumpkin patch. Henry Braswell, a 65-year-old former pumpkin farmer, said the Walker County community hasn't had a pumpkin patch in about 45 years. Pumpkins were grown in the late 1800s and early 1900s, he said, and that might have given the community its name. Braswell has another theory, however. A man who worked at his father's lumber company wanted to start a baseball team, and chose Pumpkin Center as the name of the team because of the numerous pumpkin patches at that time, Braswell said. The community of 500, about 30 miles northwest of Birmingham, then took its name from the baseball team, he said.

DOC.HEAD: General Discounts Morale Problem, Says Rotation Will Lift Spirits
With AM-Bush-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American soldiers in Saudi Arabia are suffering normal morale problems, but their spirits will rise when the Pentagon announces plans in November for replacing them with fresh units, a senior Army official said Tuesday. Gen. Gordon R. Sullivan, the Army's vice chief of staff, said the service is taking numerous steps to improve morale, including the possibility of leasing large cruise liners in the Persian Gulf to give soldiers a break from desert training. ``It's tough. It's not an easy mission'' for the more than 100,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield to defend the desert kingdom against a possible Iraqi attack, Sullivan said in an interview in his Pentagon office. The four-star general said the Bush administration will announce within a couple of weeks its decision on when replacement forces would be sent to begin the rotation process. He said the Army had not been instructed to increase its total force in Saudi Arabia, but that extra troops, if needed, likely would come from combat units at U.S. bases in Germany that are scheduled to be closed next year. The Army also could tap the remaining three armored divisions based in the United States. On Monday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that as many as 100,000 more forces - beyond the roughly 240,000 soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines already there - might be sent to the gulf area. He did not say when more forces would go. Sullivan said the full contingent of soldiers assigned to Desert Shield would be in place within a few days, and a shipment of several hundred top-of-the-line M1A1 main battle tanks also is en route to Saudi Arabia from Germany to replace older M1 tanks that are less capable of handling a chemical attack. The biggest psychological lift for the troops, some of whom have been in the Saudi desert for two months, will come when the Bush administration announces a timetable for a rotation of fresh forces, Sullivan said. The four-star general said the Army already has set in motion the arrangements for mobilizing the first fresh units from the United States and Europe, although no individual units have been alerted to begin moving to the gulf. Sullivan acknowledged that some soldiers are grousing about not knowing how long they'll be on duty in Saudi Arabia, where living conditions on the front lines are harsh, but he said he was satisfied that morale is not suffering unduly. ``The troops are in pretty good shape and they are not experiencing what I consider to be inordinate morale problems,'' he said. ``I don't see it.'' Recent news reports based on interviews with soldiers and other servicemen in the gulf area have portrayed the troops as losing patience with the nagging uncertainty of when they might go home and whether they'll be required to fight. Earlier this month, after complaining members of the Army's 24th Mechanized Infantry Division were quoted in the New York Times, the commanding general restricted access to reporters. Some private analysts say the tough conditions in the Saudi desert should not be a reason for poor morale. ``Morale is a leadership problem,'' said James A. Blackwell Jr., a former Army commander of combat units and now a defense analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ``Good leaders will have good morale under the most distasteful and challenging circumstances.'' Sullivan said that rotating troops in Saudi Arabia is complicated by the fact that the Army intends to replace whole units at a time, not make piecemeal substitutions of individual soldiers. He said this would be the first time in history the Army has rotated whole units, a strategy designed to avoid the loss of unit cohesion that Army leaders saw during the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: Court, Souter Hear Debate on Ban on Abortion Counseling
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court began scrutinizing a ban on abortion counseling at federally subsidized family planning clinics Tuesday in arguments punctuated by pointed questions from new Justice David H. Souter and fellow members. Souter voiced doubts about regulations that bar doctors and family planning counselors from discussing abortion even with women whose pregnancies are endangering their health. ``You are telling us the physician cannot perform his usual professional responsibility,'' Souter told Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, the Bush administration's top courtroom lawyer. ``You are telling us the secretary (of Health and Human Services) in effect may preclude professional speech.'' Starr, conceding the ban ``tilts against abortion,'' defended its validity. Although fueled by the continuing struggle over abortion, the legal dispute over the regulations centers on free-speech rights. The court must decide whether the regulations comply with a 1970 federal law and, if so, whether they violate the Constitution. A decision is expected by July. The argument is over information available to the 5 million low-income women who depend on family planning clinics and similar health care providers. Last year, some 4,000 family planning clinics nationwide received about $140 million in federal assistance. Enforcement of the regulations, issued by the Reagan administration in 1988, has been blocked virtually everywhere by legal challenges. None of the justices indicated any interest Tuesday in using the case to alter the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Roe vs. Wade was not mentioned at all by Starr or Harvard law professor Laurence Tribe, representing those who challenged the regulations. ``This is strictly a First Amendment argument,'' Tribe told the court. Four justices have criticized the 1973 ruling, and the court last year gave states greater leeway to make abortions more difficult to obtain. Souter, whose views on the issue are unknown, is considered a pivotal vote for the future of legalized abortion. Souter's comments to Starr followed a series of questions in which the newest justice focused on a hypothetical case of a pregnant woman whose health is endangered by continuing her pregnancy. Starr said a woman, if so diagnosed in a family planning clinic receiving federal assistance, could be told about her health problem but should not be given any advice regarding abortion. Starr argued that the government, in choosing how to spend taxpayer money, may ban discussion of abortion as a family planning technique. He said the 1988 regulations were sparked by a decision to keep the abortion controversy out of the family planning program. But Tribe said barring doctors from discussing all options ``betrays a basic trust'' between a physician and patient. ``We depend upon our doctors to tell us the whole truth, no matter who is paying the bill,'' Tribe said, adding that many doctors believe it would be ``profoundly unethical'' to abide by the regulations. Justices Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia appeared skeptical about some points raised by Tribe's attack on the regulations. Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and John Paul Stevens posed most of their questions to Starr, the government's lawyer. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy also participated in the questioning, but Justices Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun listened in silence. The family planning program was enacted in 1970 by Congress as Title X of the Public Health Service Act. It pays for creating and operating family planning clinics. The clinics always have been banned from using federal money to perform abortions, but regulations until 1988 let the clinic staffs tell women about the abortion option and make referrals. Under the 1988 regulations, a woman who visited a federally funded clinic and asked about abortion would have to be told the clinic staff ``does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning.'' Staff members then could offer help in obtaining prenatal care.

DOC.HEAD: Three Palestinians Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with details on clashes, Shamir comments. Pick up 16th graf pvs, `The deaths...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1, JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian on Tuesday after he stabbed a civilian security guard, and another Arab was killed during a clash in a refugee camp. Also Tuesday, one Palestinian was killed and two were injured when a bomb they apparently were preparing went off in an ultra-Orthodox Jewish suburb of Tel Aviv, police said. Angry Jews gathered in the market in Bnei Brak after the blast and demanded that Arabs be barred from working in the community, Israel's army radio reported. The violence was the latest in a series of assaults by both Arabs and Jews following the Oct. 8 blood bath on the Temple Mount in Jerusale. Police opened fire on Palestinians on the mount after they had stoned worshipers at the Western Wall below. Twenty Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded. Meanwhile, the Waqf, the Moslem religious council that oversees the holy site, issued a report Tuesday on the killings, calling the incident ``the day of the martyrs.'' The report accused Israeli police and paramilitary border police ``of shooting intensively with live ammunition, as if they were in a real war.'' It blamed police for setting off the incident by firing tear gas at women worshipers outside a mosque without reason. Palestinians responded with stones, and the police with gunfire, it said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office responded to the Waqf report by denouncing it as ``superficial, one-sided and non-objective,'' Israel television reported. ``Several members of the Moslem council participated in some of the incidents themselves, and this reflects the degree of the report's credibility,'' the office reportedly added. Two earlier reports, released by Palestinian and Israeli human rights groups, accused Israeli police of indiscriminate fire on the mount and urged Israel to seek non-lethal means of dealing with rioters. A report by the Israeli government last Friday blamed Palestinians stone throwers for setting off the rioting and said police fired live ammunition in self-defense. But it also blamed police commanders for being inadequately prepared. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said, meanwhile, that the continuing violence could mean that Israel will have to drop its 1988 peace plan calling for elections among Palestinians as a step toward negotiations. Arens told a parliamentary committee that ``it is difficult to see how free and democratic elections can be held ... in an atmosphere of violence,'' according to his aide, Danny Neveh. One of the Palestinian deaths Tuesday came in the West Bank city of Nablus, where an Arab stabbed an Israeli armed guard on a gasoline tanker truck, the army said. Israel army radio said the guard was stabbed three times in the back and a plainclothes Israeli security man who was passing shot the attacker to death. The guard suffered moderate wounds. Three masked Palestinians announced through a loudspeaker that the slain assailant, identified as 18-year-old Haitham Jamla, was a member of Islamic Jihad, a Moslem fundamentalist group that was outlawed by Israel on Monday. In neighboring Tulkarem, another Palestinian was fatally shot by Israeli troops as they chased a group of Arab murder suspects, who apparently refused orders to halt, the army said. Three other Arabs were wounded in other confrontations with stone-throwers that ended with a curfew on the camp. The deaths brought to 768 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 34-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation in the territories. An additional 292 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence. In Jerusalem, meanwhile, a policeman was slightly wounded when he was stabbed in the chest by an Arab near the walled Old City, police said. His assailant was arrested. In the West Bank, the army demolished five Palestinian homes, including that of Omar Abu Sirhan, 19, who was arrested for the slaying of three Israelis in Jerusalem last week. Abu Sirhan's father lost an appeal to the Israeli Supreme Court to have the home spared. Twenty-two members of the family lived in the three-story house in the village of Ubbadiyeh. Israeli troops have demolished more than 300 houses in the 34-month uprising to punish anti-Israeli activists. The Supreme Court is known to have reversed only one army demolition order. The four other houses demolished Tuesday were in the town of Sinjil north of Jerusalem, the army said. A resident in each house was suspected of killing collaborators, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Threaten to Kill Kidnapped Journalists
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers threatened to execute seven journalists they are holding if the government launches a new offensive against them, according to a statement sent to news organizations Tuesday. The statement, bearing the letterhead ``The Extraditables,'' as the Medellin cocaine cartel calls itself, marked the first time the traffickers admitted holding the journalists, kidnapped over the past two months. The abductions are ``a response to the violation of our rights,'' the statement said. Among the abducted reporters were Francisco Santos, news editor of the country's leading newspaper, El Tiempo, and Diana Turbay, daughter of former president Julio Cesar Turbay. The traffickers said they had learned of a government plot to kidnap family members of drug barrons, presumably to swap them for the journalists. ``If something of this nature happens, our response will be immediate and we will execute the detained journalists,'' the statement said. In the statement, the Extraditables also said they would kill family members of officials participating in such a kidnapping operation. They said they would attack ``political leaders who sponsor and support the criminal and genocidal police.'' Earlier this year, the cartel was blamed for killing about 10 percent of the police force in Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city. About 250 police officers died in the attacks. Since drug traffickers and the government declared war on each other in August 1989, the Medellin cartel has killed about 550 Colombians in a long series of terrorist attacks, authorities say. Their latest offense was kidnapping the seven journalists and Marina Montoya, the sister of Colombia's ambassador to Canada. Drug traffickers are apparently trying to force the government of President Cesar Gaviria to grant them a pardon. They also want Gaviria to end the government policy of extraditing accused drug traffickers to the United States. Tuesday's statement included the cartel's now familiar motto: ``We prefer a tomb in Colombia to a jail cell in the United States.'' Three of the abducted, Santos, Montoya and Turbay, belong to families that wield tremendous political and economic power in Colombia. The Extraditables said judicial police chief Col. Oscar Pelaez was responsible for, ``all the massacres committed against innocent young people in the city of Medellin.'' They said Pelaez's men killed Luis Gaviria, a relative of the Medellin cartel's leader, after torturing him for ``six hours in front of his family.'' Police said Gaviria, first cousin of cartel boss Pablo Escobar, died in a shootout with security forces on Oct. 23. Gaviria, who is not related to President Gaviria, had helped run the cartel's cocaine smuggling operations as well as its terrorist network, police said. Earlier Tuesday, a statement from two of the kidnapped journalists was read over national radio. Turbay and Azucena Lievano, producer of TV's Cripton News, said they and four other abducted reporters were in good condition. Lievano said they needed a ``miracle: our freedom.'' The statement made no mention of Santos, kidnapped in a bloody shootout two and a half weeks after the other journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Lawmakers Open Hearts, But Not Pocketbooks, to Mandala
LaserPhoto TOK2
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela received a standing ovation in Japan's parliament on Tuesday, but the black South African leader did not get the financial aid he was seeking for his African National Congress. Mandela said he was honored by the unusual chance for a foreigner who is not a head of state to address a joint parliamentary session. In his 15-minute speech, Mandela called the lifting of the state of emergency and other recent reforms in South Africa a ``cause for optimism and encouragement.'' But he said the ANC was handicapped in trying to achieve an end to apartheid by its lack of resources. The visitors' gallery in the wood-paneled chamber was full as lawmakers listened to Mandela's speech, translated into Japanese over earphones. Later, Mandela held a news conference at which he complained about Japan's contribution to the anti-apartheid movement. He said that of four countries he has visited on an Asia-Pacific tour, only Japan has failed to pledge money to his African National Congress, the largest anti-apartheid group in South Africa. Mandela, 72, said he had asked the Japanese government to contribute $25 million to the ANC to help it achieve stability and negotiate with the South African government for an end to apartheid. ``The Japanese government has disclosed that they have already spent $1.8 million toward assisting in improving the conditions of our people in South Africa,'' he said. Compared to aid from other nations, ``the contribution of the Japanese government is absolutely insignificant,'' Mandela said. On Monday, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told Mandela that Japan could not provide aid to the ANC because of its policy of not giving assistance to political parties in other nations. Kaifu said his government would provide aid to grass-roots South African groups, however. A Foreign Ministry official said Japan has the ``political will'' to give money to the ANC, but has been looking for non-governmental organizations through which to channel the funds. ``We really have to establish some sort of framework through which we can expand our aid activities to the African National Congress, and we are about to start this kind of plan-making,'' ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said. He said Japan had not been forewarned of Mandela's $25 million request. Foreign Ministry officials say they welcome recent reforms in South Africa and suggest Japan may lift some of its sanctions against Pretoria in the area of personnel exchanges. Mandela called for all international sanctions to be retained until democracy is achieved. ``We are not prepared to ask the international community for the removal of sanctions until we have the principle of one man, one vote,'' he said. Japan also bans private investment in South Africa, limits diplomatic ties to the consular level and prohibits imports of South African iron and steel. Asked about recent comments by Japanese Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama -who compared foreign prostitutes in Japan to blacks in the United States, saying both ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods they enter - Mandela called himself ``an enemy of racism in whatever form it takes.'' ``But at the same time, I believe this is a matter which is best left to the Japanese people to resolve,'' he said. In his request for aid, Mandela asked for help in reducing poverty and illiteracy among South African blacks and in creating jobs for the thousands of exiles and political prisoners expected to return to South African society. Mandela said Australia had promised to provide $15 million, Indonesia $10 million and India $6.5 million during his visits to those countries. He plans to visit Malaysia after leaving Japan on Thursday. Japan was South Africa's second-largest trading partner last year after West Germany, with two-way trade totaling $3.75 billion, Japanese figures show.

DOC.HEAD: Students Defend Teacher Charged With Shooting Colleague
DOC.TEXT: About 30 high school students cut class to picket the courthouse, asking for leniency for their teacher, who is charged with shooting a colleague he found in a tryst with his wife. Allan Sicks, a photography teacher at Campbell County High School, was charged in June with aggravated assault and aggravated burglary for allegedly wounding fellow teacher Dan Chaney. He found Chaney with his wife - also a high school teacher - in a camper at a Gillette picnic area. The couple never denied having an affair. Jury selection began this week for the trial. Students chanted ``Support Mr. Sicks,'' and carried signs reading ``Have Sympathy 4 Mr. Sicks,'' and ``He's Lost Enough, Why Take More?'' Ryan Bolton and J.C. Reynolds, both 17-year-old seniors, organized the 90-minute rally Monday. ``We don't think it's fair at all,'' Reynolds said. ``This shows this community we care. We'd like to see Mr. Sicks come out just as good as everybody else on the whole deal.'' Sicks resigned in July. Paula Sicks and Chaney still teach at the high school. The Sicks are in the midst of a divorce.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Govt. Says No Exile Contacts About Transition
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro's government has made ``no official contacts'' with any Cuban exile groups in the United States that are pushing for democracy in the communist island nation, a Cuban government spokesman said Tuesday. Jorge Ruiz, who is with the Cuban Interest Section in Washington, D.C., made the comments in response to a report Friday that quoted Cuban Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez as saying the government had opened talks with moderate Cuban exiles who seek a peaceful change in government. Ruiz said Rodriquez's comments were misinterpreted and no talks about government transition were in progress now, not even ``with the ... more neutral group.'' ``He only has words for the (moderate) group in terms of we could eventually sit down and talk to them,'' Ruiz said in a telephone interview. ``But there wasn't even a suggestion it could happen in the near future. The purpose of the interview - the position of the government - just meant to describe how Rodriguez viewed the positions of the Cuban (exile) community. It was not meant to be an overture for possible talks,'' Ruiz said. ``There are no official contacts now with any group. ``Obviously we're ruling out any communication with most reactionaries,'' he said, referring to the longtime reactionaries and the more conservative young Cubans who are pushing for government change now. Cuban foreign ministry spokesman Hector Argiles on Monday denied the reports of contacts ``with any counterrevolutionary organization'' and said there has been ``no direct or indirect contacts with representatives of those organizations.'' The Miami Herald story Friday recounted an interview with Rodriguez on Havana radio in which he discussed the various exile groups in Miami. As Rodriguez described it: The three groups consist of a first group of ``reactionaries'' who sought Castro's violent downfall; a second group of exiles interested in bringing about family reunification through increased travel and communication between the United States and Cuba; and a third group that wants a dialogue to peacefully replace Castro. In the interview, Rodriguez said, ``We are increasing relations with the third group'' and then discussed the increasing travel between Cuba and the United States. The Herald reported Sunday that the Rodriguez comments may have been misinterpreted, largely because he ``misspoke'' when he referred to ``increasing relations with the third group'' and intended to refer to the second group wanting more travel and communications with Cuba. But the Cuban government clearly stated this week that Rodriguez was not discussing any contacts aimed at easing a transition to democracy in Cuba. When Rodriguez' comments were monitored in Miami last week, some exiles concluded that the Cuban official had acknowledged the first formal political negotiations with exiles favoring a change of government in Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Bakker's Attorney Says Evangelist's Sentence Too Harsh
LaserPhoto RM2
DOC.TEXT: Jim Bakker's attorneys argued Tuesday that the former televangelist received a 45-year prison sentence for defrauding his followers because the judge was biased. Defense lawyers also argued at the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that Bakker's conviction on 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy should be overturned because of a faulty jury instruction. The appeals court usually issues rulings within four to six months of hearing arguments. The arguments focused on the sentence issued a year ago by U.S. District Judge Robert Potter of Charlotte, N.C. Bakker, founder of the PTL Network, is serving his term in a federal prison in Rochester, Minn. Alan Dershowitz, a Harvard University law professor assisting Bakker's appeal, said Potter made an ``incredible departure'' from federal sentencing guidelines. Dershowitz said the guidelines that took effect in November 1987 were intended to curb excessive sentences by judges like Potter, who has been dubbed ``Maximum Bob.'' He said Bakker would have received two to four years in prison had Potter considered the guidelines. Dershowitz said if Bakker's conviction is not overturned, he should be resentenced by another judge. ``We, your honors, will take our chances,'' he said. ``Let the chips fall where they may.'' Deborah Smith, a U.S. Justice Department lawyer who prosecuted the case, said Potter did not have to follow the guidelines because Bakker's crimes took place before November 1987. She said Bakker will be eligible for parole after 10 years and could have received 12 years in prison without parole under the guidelines. ``I don't think this is a case where there is a broad disparity,'' she said. Dershowitz also said Potter was influenced by his religious beliefs in sentencing Bakker. Moments before sentencing the founder of the PTL empire, Potter said Bakker ``had no thought whatever about his victims, and those of us who do have a religion are ridiculed as being saps (for) money-grubbing preachers or priests.'' Ms. Smith said those comments merely summarized the testimony about religious belief that pervaded the trial. ``I don't think it at all reflects a personal bias on the part of the judge but rather a reflection of what went on in that courtroom,'' she said. In asking that the convictions be thrown out, defense attorneys said Bakker was a religious visionary who acted with good intentions. They challenged an instruction to jurors that they could convict Bakker if he deceived followers in raising money for PTL ventures. Don Ervin, a Bakker attorney, said there is a difference between deceiving and defrauding the followers. ``You can intend to deceive but not intend to defraud,'' Ervin said. ``It is not against the law in this context to deceive.'' ``This is a very technical argument ... dancing on the head of a pin,'' replied Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III, who heard the case with Judges J. Dickson Phillips Jr. and John D. Butzner Jr. Bakker was convicted for bilking followers of his television ministry who contributed more than $158 million. Three other former PTL officials also have been convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Begin Amphibious Assault Exercise With Arab Forces
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Marines in the Persian Gulf began an amphibious assault training exercise Tuesday that a Pentagon source said will feature a landing of more than 10,000 Marines on a beach in Oman. The exercise, scheduled to last 10 days, is the second major Marine practice of amphibious assault techniques that could be used in the event President Bush ordered an offensive against Iraqi forces in Kuwait. The first was conducted on an Omani beach in September. Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, said the exercise involves elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and Amphibious Task Group 2, which have been in the gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack. Hall called the maneuver a ``routine amphibious training exercise'' designed to ``refamiliarize these forces with a desert environment.'' He declined to specify the number of marines and ships involved. A Pentagon source, speaking on condition he not be identified, said 18 ships, including Marine Corps amphibious vessels and Navy warships, will participate in the exercise, which he said also will involve forces from allied gulf nations. Hall said 20 airplanes and 75 helicopters will be used in staging the beach assault. The amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima was en route to the exercise area Tuesday when a boiler pipe ruptured, killing eight sailors and critically injuring two others. Hall said it had not been decided whether the 1,100 Marines aboard the Iwo Jima would participate in the beach assault exercise as planned.

DOC.HEAD: Jet-Age War Machine Clashes With Centuries-Old Desert Lifestyle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 23rd graf, `Their tracks ...' to DELETE extraneous words.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3,4,5
DOC.TEXT: Fulayyih Al-Azmi peered from his tent one quiet, starry night to behold a U.S. Marine Corps tank clanking just beyond his goat pen. ``My wife was afraid because it had no lights and she didn't know what it was,'' he said through an interpreter. ``I couldn't speak their language, so I lit a lantern to let them know I was here,'' he said inside his tent made of dark brown camel hide and burlap feed sacks. ``So I don't move my herd at night any more.'' Al-Azmi is a Bedouin, one of the nomads of the Saudi Arabian desert. He moves his 240 goats from pasture to pasture, if the scrub that grows like sparse bristles on a brush can be considered grazing land. He is guided by whim and weather without regard to political lines on a map. But like other Bedouin, Al-Azmi is migrating from the north to safer and less crowded southern lands because a 300,000-man force of American, British, French and Arab armies has filled the sands with monstrous metal machines. Home on the range is now home on the firing range. The forces gathered to counter Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's conquest of Kuwait need room to maneuver. And they also need miles of desert to practice firing their tanks, artillery and rifles. The military is sensitive to Bedouin lifestyles and makes an effort to be safe. But the Army has killed one camel and wounded two others since it began live firing recently, said Lt. Col. Arnold Laidig, a Marine officer. The Marines, for example, conduct sweeps with their helicopters to make sure no herds wander into their ranges. They also patrol the ranges in trucks before the shells start flying over the tortured landscape. ``It may look like crap to us, but it's Kentucky blue grass to them,'' said Lt. Col. Bruce Judge, a Marine operations and training officer. ``Safety is a paramount concern,'' said Marine Capt. William Taylor, a public affairs officer. ``It's like going into a farmer's field and telling him we'd like to bust some big caps in your backyard.'' The clash of cultures is stark. A Bedouin tending his bleating livestock can see helicopters flitting through the skies, armored columns rumbling across the terrain and endless convoys of military trucks on the roads. On one night recently, a patrol of three Marine amphibious assault vehicles passed within 25 yards of a Bedouin camp deep in the desert. Goats were visible through night vision goggles, but the soldiers said they never saw the camp. Another night patrol picked up movement on its sensors but couldn't hear anything. It turned out to be a herd of 20 camels passing by. Bedouin require lots of space to roam. Yet they say they welcome the troops in the desert. ``I thank God the government is having people come to defend the kingdom,'' Al-Azmi said, giving a visitor Arabic coffee, sweet tea and fresh dates while sitting on a rug in the shade of a tent flap. ``Saddam Hussein should be punished. He attacked people who did him no harm. God will punish him,'' he said. Although the Bedouin life is rustic, some have the luxuries of modern life such as Mercedes Benz cars and cellular telephones. A camel can fetch $2,500 at auction, and that's a lot to lose to an errant artillery shell or a tank. On the advice of Saudi authorities, another Bedouin named Abdullah Rajab prepared his herd of 70 camels for a journey south and out of harm's way. ``Some of the troops came and drank tea with me. They were very nice,'' Rajab said. As he spoke, dozens of tanks and armored personnel carriers from the British 7th ``Desert Rats'' Armored Brigade shook the ground as they rumbled past his livestock. Their tracks scarred a desert once trodden only by animals and herders. But the military also does good deeds in the desert. When Hassan Rashed Alkhater of Jubail, the eastern Saudi industrial city, got his pickup truck stuck in the sand, an army vehicle stopped to help. ``I was waiting for 30 minutes for someone to help, and a passing army vehicle pulled me out,'' said Alkhater, who owns 150 head of sheep and goats.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri, Illinois Communities Feuding Over White Squirrels
DOC.TEXT: The battle for the title ``Home of the White Squirrels'' is turning a little nutty. Marionville and Olney, Ill., both bill themselves as top spots for white squirrel spotting. But Marionville boasts it has far more than Olney. When Olney Central College biology instructor John Stencel recently doubted that Marionville has as many white squirrels as it claims, squirrel supporters in this southwestern Missouri community took offense. ``I would welcome people from Olney to come here to count our squirrels,'' said insurance agent Jim Smart, Marionville's leading white squirrel promoter. Stencel and several volunteers recently counted 127 white squirrels in Olney, down from last year's 143. Marionville in 1989 claimed to be home to about 1,000 of the white rodents, or roughly half the number of people who live there. ``It's a lot of baloney,'' Stencel said. ``It's a publicity stunt. They're just trying to get attention. They've never taken a count so they don't have any official numbers.'' The white squirrels in both towns are smaller than other squirrels and have white fur, pink skin and pink eyes. Smart concedes the exact number of white squirrels living in the Marionville area is not known. ``No, we have never taken an official count of white squirrels,'' he said. ``I would like to know how you take such a count. It's difficult to give much validity to a squirrel count.''

DOC.HEAD: Payments Of $1.6 Billion To Be Paid Farmers In Conservation Program
DOC.TEXT: About 330,000 farmers participating in the long-term Conservation Reserve Program soon will be getting $1.6 billion in rental payments for taking cropland from production, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday. The payments are for the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Yeutter said the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service will notify county offices to begin payments immediately ``without any further delay.'' During the recent budget-cutting maneuvers, it appeared the payments would be delayed or even reduced. But Yeutter said full cash payments will be made to cover contracts signed to place cropland in the program during crop years 1986 through 1990. Under the program, farmers agree to idle highly erodible cropland for 10 years. In return, the government helps pay the cost of establishing protect grass or trees, and provides annual rental payments for the land taken from production. The payments average nearly $50 per acre annually. Approximately 33.9 million acres have been signed up in the program. Yeutter's announcement was hailed by Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, as ``good news for farmers who need to pay bills for this year's operations and to make plans for next year.'' De la Garza said the conservation program ``continues to play a very important role'' in helping protect the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Passes Fueling Test, Atlantis Launch Date Set
With AM-Delta Launch
DOC.TEXT: Columbia passed an elaborate fueling test Tuesday after months of work to fix dangerous hydrogen leaks, and a jubilant NASA said the shuttle will be prepared for a December launch. ``We ended up with a tight ship,'' shuttle director Bob Crippen said. ``As far as we're concerned right now, Columbia is ready to go fly as soon just as we put it through its final launch preps.'' It is the first time in five months all three spaceships are clear for flight. Atlantis was found to be free of hydrogen leaks during a fueling test last week; it is scheduled to lift off Nov. 9 with a satellite that reportedly will spy on Iraq. ``The next best thing to launching is passing the tanking test,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. Sieck said NASA's image is bound to improve now that the entire fleet is back in service. Discovery's flight earlier this month, in fact, started what looks to be an upward trend, Crippen said. ``Launching space shuttles and reputation, they are tied together,'' Sieck said. ``Safely and successfully carrying out these missions, which is our goal, is only going to help the reputation and our cause to keep the program going.'' During Tuesday's three-hour test, Columbia's external tank was filled with more than 385,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen to pinpoint any more of the dangerous leaks that have kept the shuttle grounded since May. A small amount of hydrogen escaped into the engine compartment, but was well within allowable limits. It was NASA's most extensive fueling test of a shuttle. Ten TV cameras and 17 sensors were mounted in Columbia's engine compartment, the site of previous leakage. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has tried four times to send Columbia on an astronomy mission. New fuel lines were installed following the first attempt, but hydrogen later flooded the engine compartment. Following the last launch attempt in mid-September, NASA formed an engineering investigative team to find the remaining leaks. The nine investigators, who worked seven days a week on the problem, found a second crushed seal on a valve in Columbia's engine compartment and instructed workers to tighten numerous joints. ``The results of all that work has paid off,'' Crippen said. Officials believe workers accidentally damaged components in Columbia's engine compartment while searching for contamination following the shuttle's last flight in January. ``I don't think the work was the problem. There was just a lot of it,'' Crippen said. ``Any time you take your car down and do a complete engine overhaul, sometimes when you put the thing back together you might anticipate a few problems.'' NASA does not plan to conduct any more fueling tests on shuttles, Crippen said. The agency is working to improve prelaunch checks of the shuttles' main propulsion system so problems can be detected before fueling. The leaks on Columbia and Atlantis were not found until the spaceships were fueled. ``I find in this business it goes ups and downs,'' Crippen said. ``We'll have other problems we've got to deal with. There's plenty to work on at all times.'' Crippen said Columbia could be launched in early December if preparations go well and Atlantis goes up on time.
