NASA likes to have at least three weeks between missions. NASA announced Tuesday that Atlantis is scheduled to lift off sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST on Nov. 9. The precise time will not be announced until nine minutes before liftoff because of the classified nature of the Defense Department mission.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted, Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: A man crippled during a car accident was sentenced Tuesday to 20 to 50 years in prison for sexually assaulting an 18-year-old woman he held hostage for four days in January. Archie Hill, 50, was convicted by a Cuyahoga County jury Monday of 15 counts of rape, one count of kidnapping and one count of assault. Prosecutors said Hill's live-in aide, Ray Lesure, 18, dated the woman and lured her to Hill's home, where Hill beat her with an extension cord. Lesure pleaded guilty last month to sexual battery and assault. He will be sentenced Nov. 14. Hill, who has used a wheelchair since the accident 30 years ago, and another live-in aide were convicted Sept. 13 of rape, kidnapping and assault in the rape of a 31-year-old woman. Both men were sentenced to 90 to 225 years in prison. Judge Michael J. Corrigan ordered that Tuesday's sentence be consecutive to the earlier sentence. Hill would be eligible for a parole hearing after 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: US May Open MIA Office in Hanoi
DOC.TEXT: The State Department raised the possibility Tuesday of opening an office in Vietnam as part of the government's effort to obtain an accounting for the nearly 1,700 missing American servicemen in that country. The Vietnamese rejected the idea when it was proposed earlier but the two sides have since agreed to an expansion of their cooperation on the issue. Two weeks ago, during a visit by Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach, it was decided that a U.S. technical team would be sent to Hanoi to work with Vietnamese military experts on improving procedures for locating the remains of the missing Americans. The State Department said the U.S. team could stay there for an indefinite period if the results justified such a presence. The U.S. government has never operated an office in Hanoi since what was then North Vietnam became independent in 1954.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Damages Central Johannesburg, No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: An explosion believed caused by a bomb caused extensive damage Tuesday night to central Johannesburg but no injuries, police said. The blast occurred at 10:25 p.m. at an apartment block on the corner of Jeppe and Troye streets downtown, said police Lt. Ida Van Zwiel. Commercial explosives were believed to have been used in Tuesday's blast, Van Zwiel said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. Officers blocked off the area, which was littered with glass. There have been a series of explosions in central Johannesburg in recent months caused by bombs made of dynamite. Extreme right-wing groups have claimed responsibility for some blasts. Police blame most of the attacks on the right-wing groups, which oppose President F.W. de Klerk's racial reforms. The most serious attack injured 27 people in July, when a bomb went off near a black bus terminal downtown during morning rush hour.

DOC.HEAD: El Greco Fetches Record Price at Auction
DOC.TEXT: El Greco's ``The Disrobing of Christ'' was sold at auction Tuesday for $2.96 million, the highest amount ever paid for a work by the 17th century master. The painting, held privately for its nearly 400-year existence, was sold by Edmund Peel and Associates, the Madrid representative for Sotheby's of London. The names of the seller and buyer were not released. The government refused to issue an export license in order to keep the painting in Spain. ``The Disrobing of Christ,'' portraying the robed and bound figure of Jesus surrounded by Roman soldiers and onlookers, is a smaller version of a painting of the same name that hangs in the Toledo cathedal. It is thought to have been painted between 1605 and 1614 by the Crete-born painter, whose real name was Domeniko Theotokopoulos. The painting is one of only a few Grecos to come up for auction in recent years.Peel auctioned another Greco in March 1987 for $750,000.

DOC.HEAD: Rain And Snow Hit Northwest, Heavy Rain in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: Rain moved into the Northwest on Tuesday, with snow in the mountains. Parts of Hawaii had heavy downpours. A strong cold front ushered rain and wind and lower temperatures into the Northwest. Showers extended from Northern California and the northern Pacific Coast to northern Idaho during the afternoon. The heaviest rainfall total for the six hours up to 3 p.m. EST was 2.36 inches at Crescent City, Calif., on the coast near the Oregon state line. Snow was expected across some of the higher elevations of the Northwest, especially in the Cascades of Washington state. Heavy showers fell on the island of Hawaii during the night and into Tuesday morning. More than 2.5 inches of rain fell at the Hilo International Airport after midnight. Some places received more than 4 inches of rain in 24 hours, the National Weather Service reported. Gusty southerly wind prevailed from the southern high Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley, and temperatures rose into the 70s and lower 80s. But afternoon temperatures were only in the 40s and 50s across the northern Atlantic Coast states and in the Pacific Northwest. Temperatures dipped below freezing early Tuesday from the Great Lakes and the northern Atlantic Coast states to northern Georgia and the Carolinas, and a frost warning was posted into Wednesday morning for the Piedmont and Midlands of South Carolina. Tuesday's low or the Lower 48 States was 17 at Big Piney, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Hostages Talk of `Prison Without Bars'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Denis, 27...' Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Iraq has...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Frenchmen returning from captivity in Iraq said Tuesday they were free to move around in their ``prison without bars,'' but that Americans were closely watched and not allowed to mix with other detainees. Denis, a computer technician, said that at Baghdad's Rasheed hotel, the Anericans``were watched over much more than us.'' ``They were only allowed to go out two hours a day,'' he said. ``We couldn't count them or approach them. Plainclothes police controlled everything.'' Denis, 27, was one of 262 French citizens and 19 other foreigners who flew back into Paris early Tuesday after their release. He asked that his full name not be used. Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said French authorities will debrief the hostages held at strategic sites and inform allied governments what they have to say about their nationals held captive. Iraq has kept thousands of foreigners from leaving Iraq, and has sent hundreds of Western men to strategic sites to deter an attack by the U.S.-dominated military forces massed in the Persian Gulf region. About 1,400 Britons and 1,000 Americans are believed to be held in Iraq and Kuwait against their will. Two British women released with the French hostages said Tuesday they had left behind 17 British men and two Americans at a Kuwaiti oil refinery wired with explosives. ``We are concerned for the people left there,'' Wendy Major said after arriving in London. ``The Iraqis have wired the refinery with explosives ready to blow up the lot if they want.'' Ms. Major, 31, was taken to the camp Aug. 18 after being caught trying to escape to Saudi Arabia 16 days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Saddam decided to release all French citizens last week in a move seen as an attempt to divide the international alliance against it. French officials said 38 French citizens chose to remain in Kuwait or Iraq. ``Baghdad was a prison without bars,'' Denis said. ``It was a part of my life I won't forget.'' The freed hostages said the worst part was the isolation and lack of news. ``Our guards were always courteous, but never gave us a bit of information,'' said Marc, 25, who along with about 60 other Frenchmen was shifted from one strategic site to another. ``One day we were near a chemical factory, another day at a petroleum refinery,'' said Marc, who like most of the ex-hostages refused to give his last name. ``Our only links to the outside were the messages from our families on RFI (Radio France Internationale).'' Some of the former hostages came from Kuwait, where they had eluded Iraqi soldiers for almost three months. Claude, 35, said he moved from house to house to avoid discovery by Iraqi soldiers. ``We never set foot outside, for fear of being arrested,'' he said. He moved about with five other Frenchmen, usually at night so they wouldn't be caught. ``We lived in permanent anguish, without news, asking ourselves what would happen to us the next day,'' he said. Iraqi soldiers caught up with Jacky Mongin, 40, on Aug. 19 at the hotel in Kuwait where he worked. He was taken to a university where he spent 10 weeks with seven Britons. ``Often we had nothing to eat but bread, rice and water,'' he said. ``It was only in the last week that our guards brought us a television and I found out I was going to be freed. Unfortunately my companions stayed behind.'' Gerard Vilate, of Nancy, a decorator and 20-year resident of Kuwait, said: ``We didn't always get enough to eat, and I lost 10 kilos (22 pounds).'' At least one Frenchman - a 23-year-old electrician named Christophe - stayed behind as a gesture of solidarity with the remaining hostages, his family said. ``We are still in shock but I'm not terribly surprised because he was always outraged by injustice,'' his sister said. Christophe's family was told by the Foreign Ministry Monday that he was staying ``because he believed the French should not leave without the other hostages,'' his sister said. Denis, the computer worker, said the hostages hadn't suffered from the global trade embargo against Iraq. His last dinner at the Rasheed Hotel consisted of salmon, lobster and thick steak. ``I've never seen such a feast,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Calls for Inquiry Into Namibian Torture Allegations
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Tuesday appealed for an impartial inquiry into killings, torture and kidnappings during Namibia's war of independence. The human rights group said it was at least the third time it had asked for an investigation; it renewed the appeal because of the Namibian government's Oct. 23 announcement it was appointing Solomon Hawala as army chief. Hawala was accused of torturing and killing prisoners in SWAPO base camps in Angola during the war, the Amnesty statement said. ``At the very least, the government should ensure that those responsible for past human rights abuses are not placed in positions where they could have control or authority over prisoners,'' the organization said. Namibia became independent March 21, after 75 years of South African rule. SWAPO, a mainly black nationalist movement that waged a 23-year bush war, won a plurality of the vote in a U.N.-supervised election in November 1989. ``Both sides in the conflict - the South African security forces and the South West African People's Organization - were responsible for such abuses before Namibia became independent earlier this year,'' the rights organization said. ``At least 350 people imprisoned by SWAPO in Angola are still unaccounted for,'' Amnesty said. Around 60 people were reported missing while in the custody of the South African security forces, ``but this is just the tip of the iceberg,'' said an Amnesty spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. In June this year the SWAPO-dominated Namibian government set up an all-party parliamentary committee to study rights abuses. But the committee ``is not known to have considered the matter in detail,'' Amnesty said. Some prisoners freed from SWAPO bases in Angola said hundreds of SWAPO members were accused of being South African spies and many were tortured until they signed confessions. SWAPO leaders have confirmed incidents of torture, but they blame many of the abuses during the war on a since-disbanded, South Africa-linked paramilitary unit known as Koevoet, the Afrikaans word for ``crowbar.''

DOC.HEAD: 18-Month-Old Goes Home for First Time
DOC.TEXT: Samantha Sawyer was home Tuesday for the first time in her life, all 18 months of which were spent at Wolfson Children's Hospital. Doctors, nurses, social workers and hospital officials bid farewell on Monday to the toddler and her family. ``We really owe a lot of thanks,'' said her mother, Debra Sawyer. Samantha, born four months prematurely, weighed 1.4 pounds at birth and had underdeveloped lungs. She still requires special machines to help her breathing. ``We will miss her a lot, but we know she needs to go home because that's where kids grow up,'' said Debbie Lingle, a respiratory therapist. ``We're glad we got her this far.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Hangs 41 Alleged Drug Smugglers, Bandits
DOC.TEXT: Iran hanged 41 alleged drug smugglers and bandits Tuesday, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The state news agency, monitored in Nicosia, said three Afghans were among 19 alleged drug smugglers hanged in northeastern Khorasan province, which borders Afghanistan. Twenty-two other bandits were hanged in southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province, which adjoins Khorasan. The alleged drug traffickers were convicted of smuggling a total of about 2,645 pounds of opium, 46 pounds of heroin, and 15 pounds of hashish, the agency said. It added the bandits, hanged in Zabol, capital of Sistan-Baluchestan province, were convicted of armed robbery, drug smuggling and kidnapping. Iran has hanged more than 1,500 people, most of them on alleged drug trafficking charges and imprisoned over 50,000 so-called drug addicts since December 1988. Iranian opposition groups and other independent human rights organizations maintain the killings are a cover for liquidating government opponents. Other observers believe Iran would have few qualms about admitting it was liquidating its opponents. In the past, Iran's state-run media have reported executions of spies and other opponents. Iran's draconian laws call for a mandatory death sentence for possession of even small quantities of drugs. According to official figures, some 1 million Iranians are involved in drug abuse. But other independent sources say addicts number twice that figure. United Nations envoy, Reynaldo Galindo Pohl, who visited Iran earlier this month to investigate rights abuses there, said he was satisfied with Iranian due process. Iranian judicial officials have constantly called on judges nationwide to expedite cases as soon as possible, and to pass the stiffest possible sentences.

DOC.HEAD: Another Shooting Hits Sheriff's Race
DOC.TEXT: Gunshots riddled a campaign office of Cook County sheriff candidate Michael Sheahan early Tuesday in the latest round of violence to mar the campaign, police said. About five shots hit the front door and window of an unoccupied Sheahan campaign office on the southwest side, said Chicago police officer Maureen McKeever. A witness reported seeing a car speed away from the office after the shooting, police said. Sheahan, a Democrat, is running against Republican incumbent James O'Grady and Washington Party candidate Tommy Brewer. A week ago, a Sheahan campaign worker was shot three times in what police say was a politically motivated attack. Sheahan says the victim, 34-year-old Irving Bell, was hanging signs for him when the shooting occurred. But O'Grady says Bell was tearing down O'Grady signs. A Chicago man has been charged with attempted murder in that incident. And two other men - including a Cook County correctional officer - have been charged with mob action. Bell remained in serious condition Tuesday at Christ Hospital in suburban Oak Lawn. In addition, Sheahan and O'Grady have accused each other's campaign workers of vandalizing signs and offices. Third-party candidate Brewer says the violence proves that neither of his opponents is fit to hold the sheriff's office.
DOC.HEAD: Major Parties Concerned About Status
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut Party candidate Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is ahead in the polls, prompting concern that Democrats could lose their status as a major party in state politics. A little-known state law stipulates that, to qualify as a major party, with the ability to get state financing for primary elections, they must get at least 20 percent of the vote in each gubernatorial election. This year, public opinion polls have consistently shown the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Bruce A. Morrison, enjoying the support of less than 20 percent of the electorate. A poll last week had him at 12 percent. The Republican, John G. Rowland, has been in the 24-34 percent range. Support for Weicker, a former Republican U.S. senator who created the Connecticut Party for his independent bid for governor, has fluctuated between the 30s and 40s, the higher numbers coming in early polls. State GOP Chairman Richard Foley would love to see the Democrats embarrassed this year, but says he's found that ``Democrats always come home. In most cases, it's easier to change a Democrat's religion than his party affiliation.'' State Democratic Chairman John F. Droney Jr. said the 20 percent law ``should be a wake-up call to Democrats who, for whatever reasons, have been toying with ... voting for one of the two Republicans.'' But, Droney said, ``there's as much chance of Bruce Morrison falling below 20 percent as Lowell Weicker getting a reputation as a man of principle and character. I just don't see it.'' If Weicker does win, that means the Connecticut Party will be listed at the top of the ballot in 1994.
DOC.HEAD: Blunt Expects 50 Percent Turnout; Businessman Offers Employee Incentive
DOC.TEXT: A car dealer is offering his employees an extra hour of pay for voting in the Nov. 6 general election. And Larry Harness is running newspaper advertisements, urging other employers to encourage their workers to cast ballots. ``I'm just trying to maybe stir up some thinking among the businesses that if they will go to their people and tell them how much they support this, maybe we can get 70 or 80 percent out to vote,'' said the Jefferson City car dealer. Secretary of State Roy Blunt predicted Monday that perhaps half of Missouri's 2,747,288 registered voters will go to the polls for the general election.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Hears Case That Could Force Millions In State Tax Refunds
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court heard arguments Tuesday in a tax case that could force Georgia to refund more than $30 million collected from out-out-state distillers under a levy later struck down as unconstitutional. The case has drawn wide attention from state and local officials nationwide because it addresses when states may be required to refund taxes collected under laws later invalidated by court rulings. Thirty-one states, national organizations representing governors, cities, counties, state legislatures and mayors, have intervened in support of Georgia's position. ``Cases such as the one now before this court will have a major fiscal effect on the states,'' Virginia Attorney General Mary Sue Terry argued in a statement filed in behalf of 16 states. ``This court's decisions will affect transfers of public funds, running into the billions of dollars,'' she said. ``And the practical result of such redistributions will be felt primarily by the taxpayers and citizens who are the beneficiaries of state services.'' Morton Siegel, a lawyer for Jim Beam Distilling Co., told the justices the company was denied a $2.4 million tax refund by Georgia even though the state Supreme Court ruled that the law under which the taxes were collected in 1982, 1983 and 1983 was unconstitutional. The law levied excise taxes on alcoholic beverages imported into Georgia at twice the rate of those manufactured in state. It was amended by the legislature in 1985 after the Supreme Court struck down a similar scheme in Hawaii as an unconstitutional infringement on interstate commerce. Jim Beam sued Georgia and a state judge ruled Georgia's law unconstitutional. But the judge refused to grant a refund, despite a state law requiring refunds of ``any and all'' taxes illegally assessed or collected. Two other distillers have since filed identical suits seeking a total of $28 million in refunds. Assistant Georgia Attorney General Amelia Baker argued that the distillers are not entitled to refunds because the state collected the taxes under a longstanding law which the state had ``no reason to believe would be invalidated'' before the Hawaii case. She also said requiring Georgia to refund $30 million would ``create a severe financial burden'' and would force cuts in other valid government programs.

DOC.HEAD: Pickering: Seizure of Assets May be Next U.N. Step Against Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering says the Security Council might order the seizure of Iraq's frozen assets in its next attempt to force Baghdad from Kuwait. Pickering, who on Thursday takes over the council as chairman, also pledges that Washington will take any steps necessary to protect U.S. citizens. Pickering argued for the American right to protect its citizens overseas nearly a year ago, when he defended the U.S. invasion of Panama. As President Bush dispatches 100,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf, Pickering will have a golden opportunity to push the U.S. diplomatic agenda in the Security Council. Pickering becomes chairman of the council for the month of November under the alphabetic rotation the body uses to determine its leader. In December, the ambassador of Yemen, the only Arab council member and the most overtly pro-Iraqi delegate, takes over. ``You can see that there will be action in the next few weeks, or not for a long time,'' a Western diplomat said Tuesday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Security Council has slapped a trade embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, extended it to include air cargo service and given permission to naval powers in the gulf to halt shipping suspected of violating the embargo. On Monday, the Security Council voted to hold Iraq liable for human rights abuses and damages during its occupation of Kuwait, and it warned of unspecified further action if Iraq defies the council. Pickering delivered a warning of possible independent U.S. action, saying: ``It is the solemn duty of every state to protect its citizens. ... ```I want to underscore one point. ... The United States will do that which is necessary to meet its obligation to its own citizens.'' When the United States invaded Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Noriega, Pickering used self-defense as one factor to support the intervention. Several U.S. citizens had been menaced and attacked in the weeks before the December 1989 invasion, and one was killed at a roadblock by guards. Pickering said the U.N. charter allowed nations the right of individual or collective self-defense, and said a country could use military force against another to protect its nationals. Pickering also indicated the United Nations might try to seize Iraqi assets. ``Iraq is liable for full restitution or compensation for the losses and damages it has caused by its illegal invasion and occupation of Kuwait. ``We anticipate the council will address this question more fully in the days ahead,'' he said. Iraq's $4 billion in overseas assets, of which about $800 million is in the United States, would not go far in offsetting the losses other countries have suffered. Jordan alone estimates its economic losses because of the invasion and embargo at $2 billion. The frozen assets would help rebuild Kuwait if its government ever is restored after an Iraqi withdrawal. Monday's resolution also invited nations to compile lists of war crimes committed by the Iraqis against Kuwaitis and other foreigners. The council has been acting under Chapter 7 of the charter, which provides for Security Council sanctions and eventually collective military action against member states that threaten international peace and security. The council has not yet exhausted its non-military provisions, which include interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air and communications links. Article 42, the next step envisioned by some members, calls for ``such action by air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security, (including) demonstrations, blockade and other operations by air, sea or land forces of members of the United Nations.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Training Devices
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that trainers of Tennessee Walking Horses may use lightweight arrangements of chains and rollers to produce the characteristic high-stepping gait of the breed. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia unanimously upheld the Agriculture Department's regulations permitting the use of the chains, called ``action devices,'' if the assembly weighs six ounces or less. The devices had been the object of a lawsuit by an animal protection group. In June, the American Horse Protection Association obtained a lower court ruling that the department's regulations allowing the lightweight chains and rollers had been adopted in an arbitrary manner. The group contended that the action devices encourage trainers to use illegal chemicals that cause the horses to develop sores on the back of the foreleg. It argued that the devices, used in conjunction with chemicals, would cause pain that encourages the horses to walk in the characteristic high-stepping gait of the Tennessee Walking Horse. But the department countered that 99 percent of horses examined by its veterinarians did not exhibit sores even though they wore the six-ounce bracelet-like assembly which the horse, trainers say, tries to ``step out of.'' The appeals court held that the agriculture secretary ``was not under an express duty to prohibit any practice, however safe by itself, that might indirectly cause or perpetuate abuses already separately prohibited by the regulations.'' ``If such were the duty, the secretary might have to eliminate horse show rings entirely because they perpetuate the practice of soring,'' the court said in an opinion by Circuit Judge Abner Mikva. The ruling overturned an opinion by U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch, who had set aside the regulations allowing six-ounce action devices. Gasch had ordered the department to consider banning them altogether. Gasch's order had been stayed pending the government's appeal. Mikva was joined in the ruling by Circuit Judges Harry Edwards and Laurence Silberman.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says U.S. Attack Imminent; 11 Americans Die in Accidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with two more U.S. sailors die from steam boiler accident, raises reference to Baker meeting with Soviet foreign minister, edits to conform. Pickup 22nd pvs, `The Iwo...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY16,WX7, DHA7
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein said Tuesday that Iraq was making final preparations for war and expected an attack within days by the United States and its allies. A U.S. senator said President Bush's ``patience is wearing thin.'' In the Persian Gulf, 10 American sailors died when a steam pipe ruptured in the boiler room of the USS Iwo Jima. And in Saudi Arabia, a Marine was killed in an accident while driving in the desert. Bush discussed possible military action against Iraq in a meeting with congressional leaders on the gulf crisis, but he told them he could not guarantee he would consult them before embarking on hostilities. He refused to comment publicly on a report the United States plans to discuss a timetable with U.S. allies for a military offensive. Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Saturday will begin a weeklong visit to Arab and European countries to consult on future steps in the gulf, officials said. The visit will include a meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Asked about the potential for a U.S. military strike, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``s these things unfold, of course, there are always scenarios for action that have to be considered ... but there is no timetable for action.'' Fitzwater sought to dampen fears that fighting was imminent. ``The attitude at the meeting was ``play it down - be calm,'' he said. The United States has more than 200,000 troops in the gulf region and has announced plans to send at least 100,000 more. It is the largest U.S. military deployment since the Vietnam War. Saddam summoned his military commanders to a meeting in Baghdad to complete ``preparations for urban warfare and necessary measures to be taken in the event of combat in (Kuwait),'' the Iraqi News Agency reported. ``We must be prepared with all that God has given us of potential to thwart perfidious intentions by the United States and its allies to launch an attack in the next few days,'' the report quoted Saddam as saying. The agency did not explain why Saddam believed an attack was imminent. While he talked of possible hostilities, his foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, struck a more cautious note. Aziz told the Iraqi News Agency that Iraq is prepared to talk with ``any Arab or international party'' provided it is not ``prompted by premeditated hostile designs.'' There was some speculation that Saddam's warning may be a propaganda ploy by Iraq to drive a wedge between the United States and those of its allies who seek to avoid hostilities. Diplomats in the Middle East, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam was reacting to statements Monday by Baker. Baker told a gathering in Los Angeles: ``Let no one doubt: We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait.'' Congressional leaders emerging from their meeting with Bush said they had urged the president to explore all other avenues for resolving the crisis and got no indication that U.S. military action was imminent. ``His patience is wearing thin,'' said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, one of several lawmakers who met for an hour at the White House with the president. But Cohen added: ``For the time being, he's going to continue to pursue the course that we're currently on.'' Participants described Bush as highly disturbed by reports of atrocities in occupied Kuwait and the plight of U.S. Embassy personnel and other Americans who have been blocked from leaving. Before the meeting, Bush declined to comment on a newspaper report that administration officials would discusss a timetable with U.S. allies for a possible military offensive. The Los Angeles Times, quoting an unidentified senior government official, said he considers war almost inevitable and considers a strike most likely in December or January. The report said the United States now believes sanctions will not force Iraq to pull out of the emirate it invaded Aug. 2. The accident aboard the Iwo Jima came as it was sailing out of Bahrain to take part in military exercises. Cmdr. Mark Neuhart of the U.S. Naval Forces Central Command said the cause of the leak aboard the amphibious assault ship was under investigation. Two injured sailors who had been in critical condition died later Tuesday, the Pentagon in Washington said. The ship returned to Bahrain for repairs, Neuhart said. The Iwo Jima was to be part of a 10-day exercise that began Tuesday. A Pentagon source said it would feature a landing of more than 10,000 Marines on a beach in Oman. Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman, called the maneuver a ``routine amphibious training excercise.'' He declined to provide specifics on the number of Marines and ships involved. In a separate accident, one Marine was killed and three others were injured when the vehicle they were traveling in overturned in the Saudi desert, the U.S. military Joint Information Bureau said in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. In addition to the deaths Tuesday, 32 U.S. servicemen have been killed since Operation Desert Shield began in August. In other developments Tuesday: -Two freed British hostages said two Americans and 17 Britons were being held as human shields at a Kuwait oil refinery that the Iraqis have wired with explosives. They are among hundreds of foreigners held by the Iraqis at strategic sites to deter attack. -An Iraqi dissident group reported that Iraq has moved essential machinery and equipment from its arms production and chemical weapons plants to new, secret locations as a precaution against possible air attack. The report by the London-based Kurdistan Democratic Party could not be independently confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Leader Agrees to Form Government
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Gro Harlem Brundtland agreed Tuesday to form her third government since 1981, replacing a center-right coalition that split over talks with the European Community. ``We have concluded that it is possible to assume the task of ruling,'' said Ms. Brundtland, after telling Crown Prince Harald, Norway's acting monarch, that her party was willing to form a minority government. Jo Benkow, president of Parliament, polled the national assembly's six parties, then advised Harald that the majority favored Ms. Brundtland to succeed the Conservative-led coalition that forced her from office a year ago. Ms. Brundtland would not say when the new government would take over, but news reports said it would be ready by Friday. ``We are the biggest party in Parliament and will follow the same line we have in the past, which is in keeping with our political philosophy,'' said Ms. Brundtland. She met with opposition leaders through the afternoon on seven key issues including the environment, child care, economic policy and the distribution of wealth according to socialist tradition. Labor has only 67 seats in the 165-seat Parliament, but Ms. Brundtland said there was sufficient support from other parties to let her govern. Ms. Brundtland was asked to lead the country because a three-party coalition led by Conservative Prime Minister Jan P. Syse resigned Monday. The coalition split over what policy to pursue in negotiations between the European Economic Community and the European Free Trade Association about forming a joint 18-nation trade bloc after 1992. The Center Party, backed by the country's subsidized farmers, had refused to remain in a coalition or support a Conservative single-party government because of Syse's support for the EC. Norway is a member of the European Free Trade Association, but the Conservatives want to eventually join the EC. Center refused changes demanded by the EC in Norwegian laws protecting domestic resources and industry. Syse resigned and said he could not lead a government that was divided on important international negotiations. Ms. Brundtland also supports a strong agreement with the Community, but said Center was free to pursue its own anti-membership efforts. One newspaper described Ms. Brundtland's return to office as calling ``Mother Gro to Clean Up'' in the difficult political situation. Parliament is nearly deadlocked and there is no constitutional provision for calling elections for three more years. Ms. Brundtland, a 51-year-old physician, Harvard-educated public health specialist and grandmother, is known as a tough, veteran politician. She became Norway's youngest and first woman prime minister in 1981, in a term that lasted seven months. She also led the government from May 1986 until Syse's coalition forced her to resign in October 1989. Ms. Brundtland is best-known abroad as a champion of the environment. She headed the U.N. commission that published ``Our Common Future,'' a 1987 textbook of environmental concerns. Labor's first test may come in dealing with a 1991 national budget, including tax reductions for higher income families, which the former coalition parties drafted and still favor. ``That cannot be the starting point for our government,'' said Brundtland about the budget proposals. Center, Parliament's smallest party, thwarted Syse's attempt to form a single-party Conservative government by declaring its preference for Ms. Brundtland. After the Sept. 11, 1989 national election, the Conservative-led bloc controlled 84 seats and the socialists had 81 seats in parliament. Center's 11 votes now swing the parliamentary balance in favor of the Labor-led socialists.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Appealing against Election Results in Ivory Coast
DOC.TEXT: Opposition presidential candidate Laurent Gbagbo said Tuesday he will ask the Supreme Court to overturn election results he says were rigged by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. The Interior Ministry announced that Ivory Coast's leader of 30 years won Sunday's balloting with 81.67 percent of votes in the country's first contested presidential election. Gbagbo was the sole challenger. The election marked the first time a leader of one of Africa's one-party states faced opposition at the polls since a wave of protests and rioting for democracy began sweeping sub-Saharan Africa this year. Gbagbo told reporters that lawyer Emile Boga, a leading member of his Popular Front, was preparing papers to present to the Supreme Court. Election results remain unofficial until they are declared by the court, an announcement expected next week. The court, appointed by Houphouet-Boigny, also hears appeals about elections. Boga said about 100 opposition party members had been arrested since Sunday, when Gbagbo's supporters smashed dozens of ballot boxes to halt the elections at numerous voting stations. They charged the boxes were stuffed with votes for Houphouet-Boigny. The lawyer said the detainees were being held at an army camp, and that some of them were being beaten and ill-treated. Gbagbo has charged massive fraud in elections he called ``a masquerade'' of democracy. Houphouet-Boigny was expected to win, but not by so large a margin. Interior Minister Leon Konan Koffi said the charges were slanderous lies. He said the opposition tried to stop elections because they knew they could not win. In a personal attack on Gbagbo published Tuesday by the government-controlled daily newspaper, Konan Koffi said the opposition leader wanted power so that he could live in luxury. He described Gbagbo's supporters as ``a band of fanatics,'' and accused the opposition leader of leading astray young Ivorians perturbed by the country's economic crisis. The crisis was brought on over-spending and slumping prices for cocoa and coffee, the main export earners.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Levels Scathing Attack Against Democrats
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs with Democratic response from Gephardt after 2nd graf, Addressing a
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday launched a blistering partisan attack on ``arrogant'' Democrats in a maneuver designed to rally Republican forces for next week's midterm elections. Addressing a group of GOP workers, Bush alternately portrayed Democrats as clumsy, bumbling, uncaring toward the nation's children, ``unresponsive and irresponsible,'' and ``an arrogant majority.'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt said the country needs a leader who ``acts like a president, rather than a president who acts like a party chairman.'' ``When he talks about giving Americans a better deal, let's be clear about what he really means. A better deal for the rich, a raw deal for the elderly and a raw deal for the middle class,'' said Gephardt. Gephardt said Bush seeks to take ``this misleading message to the campaign trail to elect a Republican Congress, something which working families and elderly Americans should deeply fear.'' Bush began the day on a bipartisan note, briefing both Democratic and Republican leaders on his Persian Gulf strategy at a morning session at the White House. But by the afternoon, he was again beating political drums. ``There are two things you should never watch being made, sausage and laws,'' Bush said, repeating an old saw. ``As for the Democrats in Congress, this year we've all been taken on a first-class tour of the hot dog factory.'' Standing on a stage with a majority of his Cabinet behind him, Bush told about 500 party workers at a hotel rally assembled by the Republican National Committee: ``Their rhetoric is wrong and their purpose is wrong and we're not going to let them get away with it.'' The crowd included party workers from the national committee and from congressional GOP committees, whom Bush termed ``the faithful, those who are standing there getting the job done day in and day out.'' One party worker conspicuously absent was Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, whom the White House has been trying - so far unsuccessfully - to have fired. Rollins' memo to House Republicans saying it was OK to distance themselves from the president on tax issues raised the president's ire. Gary Koops, a spokesman for the GOP congressional committee, said Rollins was too busy analyzing new campaign polling data to attend. Bush's scalding campaign speech was in keeping with the highly partisan tone he set on his just-concluded four-day campaign swing to the West. Bush was to attend a rally for a GOP congressional candidate in the Washington suburbs Wednesday, then begin a cross-country trek Thursday that will keep him on the campaign trail through Election Day. The president called Democrats ``an arrogant majority that uses its power to protect its own prerogatives, its own privileges, its own pet projects. And it is time that American people say, enough is enough. No more.'' He accused them of a ``distortion of Republican motives, goals and accomplishments,'' and of a ``clumsy explanation'' of their proposal to delay tax indexing for one year. Bush apologized anew for supporting a deficit-reduction package containing some $140 billion in new taxes over the year, again sounding the theme that he was forced into it by Democrats. ``There was a ransom, and that ransom was taxes,'' he said. But he said he reluctantly agreed to the plan because ``I just simply could not bring myself to leave America's children an avalanche of unpaid bills.'' After condemning the fact that the Democrats forced him into accepting the new taxes part of the plan, Bush said the overall $492 billion deficit-cutting package was ``long overdue and, in my view, it is essential.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Pressures Former Communists Over its Assets
DOC.TEXT: Parliament deputies on Tuesday sharply criticized the leaders of the former East German Communist Party amid reports they pilfered state property and sent money abroad before ceding power. A former secret police officer said late Monday that the party's holdings may b worth up to $40 billion. They include such properties as a hotel on the island of Korfu bought from Greek communists, said the former official, Juergen Perdus. In Parliament, Social Democratic leader Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier on Tuesday charged the former communists, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, had taken the ``material worth of the old communist state without accepting responsibility for 40 years of injustice and a ruined economy.'' Gregor Gysi, leader of the reformed Communists, promised he would clear up questions about the party's assets, which he has said were worth about $1.3 billion. Party leaders have promised to open the party's accounts and hand over everything to a public trustee, except what they need to meet obligations and continue political activities. With the first all-German elections due on Dec. 2, the scandal is expected to hurt the party at the polls. In Communist East Germany, most property was owned by the state. Although these businesses are supposed to have been turned over to a board of trustees, the Communists are reported to have spent their last days in power hiding or transferring wealth. Two party officials, Wolfgang Langnitzschke and Wolfgang Pohl, have been arrested on charges they illegally transferred $72 million to accounts in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Police Uncover Clandestine Grave on Rio's Outskirts
DOC.TEXT: An abandoned well where death squads dumped their victims was discovered in a slum called Shangri-la, a police official said Tuesday. An official with a special commission that investigates death squad activities said the grave was found Saturday, after police arrested six suspected killers. The official asked not to be named for security reasons. He said no bodies had yet been retrieved from the site on the outskirts of Nova Iguacu, a city about 20 miles outside of Rio. It isn't clear how many victims were left there, the official said. Press reports said there were about 100 bodies buried in the grave. Eduardo Gomes, a church worker in the region, confirmed the press account. ``Most are almost certainly teenagers, killed by death squads,'' he said in a phone interview, in which he said that clothing and shoes uncovered from the grave indicated most of the corpses were those of youngsters. But the special commission official denied any of the victims had been exhumed, and suggested the reports were exaggerated. ``It's all speculation,'' he said. The death squads consist largely of active and off-duty police officers who make extra money by killing petty thieves at the behest of shopkeepers and others. Many of the victims are poor minors involved in the drug trade and small-scale theft. Death squads operate in many areas of Rio but are notorious for their activities in Nova Iguacu and other cities of the Baixada Fluminense, a sprawling lowlands area west of Rio. The AP late Tuesday visited Rio's 54th precinct, which normally handles investigations in the area where the grave was found. Police Chief Celso Bezerra said the case was being handled by the special commission and he could not provide details. Bezerra did confirm the area where the grave is located had been used as a dump by death squads. But he expressed skepticism that large numbers of bodies would be uncovered. The AP also went to the Shangri-La neighborhood, an impoverished area criss-crossed by dirt roads dotted with small bare brick homes. No one could be found who was eager to talk about clandestine graveyards. Homicide investigator Walter Codong dos Reis said the grave was in an extremely dangerous area. He said he would only send detectives there if they were armed with machine guns. Residents of areas where death squads operate rarely speak to police, or outsiders, for fear of retribution, Codong dos Reis said.

DOC.HEAD: Government and Blue Cross to Collaborate in Massive Experiment
DOC.TEXT: In a novel combination, government researchers and a major health insurer are sponsoring experiments to test the effectiveness of bone marrow transplants as a treatment for breast cancer. The clinical trials will try to determine whether the complicated procedure offers hope for women with early-stage breast cancer who are at high risk for recurrence and women in advanced stages of the disease. ``We want to help women with breast cancer, but these therapies are very toxic, very expensive and very difficult, and you don't want to expose women to these therapies unless you're confident there's a good chance you'll help them,'' Dr. Michael Friedman, director of cancer therapy evaluation at the National Cancer Institute, said Tuesday. The procedure, called autologous bone marrow transplantation, is considered effective treatment for certain forms of leukemia and lymphoma and some other diseases, and health insurers usually cover it in these cases. But most health insurers, including Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, don't cover the procedure for women with breast cancer because they consider it experimental treatment that has not been shown to be effective. Yet, some physicians are recommending it and some patients have taken their insurance companies to court to force them to cover the procedure, which can cost from $75,000 to $150,000. ``Many of our plans have had to debate the issue in court, which we do not believe is the appropriate setting for medical policy-making,'' said Douglas Peters, senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the nation's largest private health insurer. ``By funding some of the clinical care costs associated with the NCI trials, we're able to provide access to this treatment while contributing to the search for a definitive answer to the question of whether or not it works,'' he said. At least 15 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans are expected to participate in helping to finance the clinical trials by providing funds for care of patients. It marks the first time a health insurer has joined the government in sponsoring medical experiments. In an autologous bone marrow transplant, some of a patient's bone marrow is removed and stored while they undergo high doses of chemotherapy to kill their cancer. After chemotherapy, their stored bone marrow is put back in. The bone marrow is the source of blood cells, both the oxygen-carrying red cells and important cells of the immune system that fights foreign bodies. Storing marrow shields it from the toxic effects of the chemotherapy, enabling the marrow to recover its function when the stored marrow is returned to the body. About 1,200 women are expected to participate in the trials, which are expected to last two to four years. Half of the women in the trials will be given conventional treatment and the other half will be given bone marrow transplants, Friedman said. Aside from whether the transplant is effective, ``this may teach us some very valuable things,'' Friedman said. ``We're going to be confronted in the future with new, complex, expensive technologies,'' he said. ``If we learn how to evaluate this particular situation, it may have implications as to how we face other scientific and economic problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Vander Jagt Has Challenger For House GOP Campaign Group Chair
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Don Sundquist, a savvy four-term Republican from Tennessee, is challenging veteran Michigan Rep. Guy Vander Jagt for the chairmanship of the House GOP campaign organization, sources said Tuesday. Sundquist began making a flurry of telephone calls and personal contacts in the final hours before Congress adjourned this weekend to amass support for his bid to unseat Vander Jagt, who has what many see as a lackluster record in the post. But Sundquist's challenge also appeared to be exacerbating splits among House Republicans, who are deeply divided over how best to conduct themselves as the minority party in the chamber. One Republican staff source, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said the challenge is opposed by Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 GOP leader in the House. Gingrich views Sundquist's bid just a week before the Nov. 6 elections as a damaging distraction to the campaign arm, the National Republican Congressional Committee. ``There will be plenty of time after Nov. 6 for whatever fighting there's going to be,'' the aide said. ``If they do this now, we may lose our focus'' before Election Day. Sundquist spokesman Ralph Perrey acknowledged that his boss had discussed running against Vander Jagt with colleagues, but added he would make no formal announcement until after the elections. ``Mr. Sundquist has a background as a manager of campaigns, a grassroots organizer and one who can recruit and develop candidates,'' Perrey said. ``Many believe those are precisely the skills needed'' at the NRCC now. Sundquist managed former Sen. Howard Baker's unsuccessful presidential campaign in 1979 and 1980, he said. ``A significant number of people are urging him'' to get into the race, he added. Another senior Republican House source said Gingrich and his ally Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., already are heavily involved in the operations of the NRCC, which provides campaign cash, advice and technology to Republican candidates. Two sources suggested that Vander Jagt may be considering stepping down from the post which he has held for 15 years. Republicans have failed to make substantial gains in the House during that time, and have been slipping in recent years. There has not been a GOP majority in the House since the 1950s, and that is a source of tension for the party. If Vander Jagt does so, Weber may consider running against Sundquist for the campaign post, one source said.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Steam Plants Naturally Dangerous, Engineer Says
With AM-Gulf-Accidents, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boiler rooms that power the USS Iwo Jima and other Navy ships are potentially hazardous workplaces, but no more so than the factory floor of a foundry or a steel mill, an engineer said Tuesday. A boiler pipe ruptured Tuesday aboard the amphibious assault ship Iwo Jima, releasing super-heated steam that killed 10 sailors in the worst Navy accident during the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The steam plant, like any other mature technology, is dangerous for the operator,'' said A. Sydney Roberts, a professor of mechanical engineering at Old Dominion University. ``It's a common industrial hazard,'' he said. ``An industrial workplace is not safe in relative terms.'' Lt. Gordon Hume, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet in Norfolk, agreed that ``any time you are working around high temperatures and high pressures, you want to be very careful.'' Hume said the Iwo Jima would have been operating with steam temperatures of more than 800 degrees and pressure higher than 600 pounds per square inch. Hume, who is trained in engineering, said the Navy uses three basic methods to power its ships: steam, diesel and gas turbine. Diesel engines are used on the smallest naval vessels and many destroyers and cruisers are being built with gas turbine power plants much like jet engines, Hume said. Larger ships use steam. In the Iwo Jima, water is heated in two boilers to make the steam, which is piped through a turbine that turns the propeller. ``We certainly train our people extensively to combat the potential dangers of steam,'' Hume said. Because older technologies such as steam are well understood, the plants can be designed with safety in mind. But all the design in the world cannot protect the worker from human error or faulty equipment, Roberts said. ``With high temperatures and high pressures you have lots of problems, Roberts said. ``Seals can fail, bolts can fail. Several years ago at the nuclear power plant in Surry, they had a pipe fail.'' In December 1986, steam eroded and ruptured a section of an elbow joint at the plant, killing four workers. The accident occurred outside the plant's nuclear reactor and no radiation was released. ``You face many of the same hazards if you work on the floor of the foundry or at a steel mill,'' Roberts said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Interdiction Effort Expanding, Despite Persian Gulf, Budget
DOC.TEXT: The military is expanding its role in the drug war despite the drain of the Persian Gulf buildup and $500 billion in federal budget cuts, top interdiction officials said Tuesday. Army, Navy, and Coast Guard officers working with civilian agencies to stop drugs at borders said their effort has forced smugglers to change routes and methods. Smugglers are shifting operations away from sea routes through the Caribbean to overland routes through Mexico, said Customs Service Commissioner Carol Hallett, who heads the joint Border Interdiction Committee. ``We certainly believe that we have the drug traffickers on the run,'' she said. ``We know that we have made it more difficult for them to operate. We've made it more dangerous and certainly we've made it more expensive.'' A massive deficit-cutting bill aimed at reducing government spending by $500 billion over the next five years has left drug-fighting agencies untouched, Ms. Hallett said. The U.S. deployment to Saudi Arabia hasn't prevented the military from increasing its profile in the drug war, said Maj. Gen. Arnold Schlossberg Jr. ``The Department of Defense has a lot of assets, and in spite of the fact we're in Desert Shield, we've enhanced our operations here in this area and in the Eastern Pacific,'' he said. For example, the Navy sharply increased the number of ``aircraft days'' dedicated to spotting drug traffickers in the Atlantic and Caribbean region from 600 in September 1989 to 3,000 last month, said Rear Adm. Robert Spane. The amount of drugs seized in the Customs Service's southeast region, which includes Florida, was up this year by about 7 tons from last year - to 77,000 pounds as the interdiction effort goes farther into the Caribbean, Ms. Hallett said. The agency's southeast region also includes Georgia, the Carolinas, Virginia and Washington, D.C. Although the region including Florida continues to account for about half the nation's drug seizures, the joint interdiction effort helped force about 70 percent of drug trafficking onto overland Mexican routes, Ms. Hallett said. The Colombian drug cartels continue to operate, but the crackdown in that nation has shifted some coca-growing operations to Bolivia and other nations, others on the interdiction committee said. Schlossberg cautioned that none of the interdiction officials believe they have a ``silver bullet'' that will stop drug smuggling. The interdiction program is only one part of a larger drug strategy. ``Our job is to keep the pressure on'' until programs aimed at decreasing drug demand can take effect, said Rear Adm. Robert Kramek, commander of the Coast Guard's seventh district.

DOC.HEAD: Tourist Shot to Death, Wife Injured in Soweto Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with woman in satisfactory condition, CORRECTS that couple was not driving rental car, daughter confirms couple became lost.
DOC.TEXT: Assailants shot to death an elderly tourist and injured his wife Tuesday after the couple apparently became lost while driving and ended up in the black township of Soweto, police said. Police Lt. Col. Tienie Halgryn said the couple were visiting from New Zealand and came under fire while driving through Soweto on Tuesday afternoon. The couple's daughter, who lives in Johannesburg, said her parents had taken her car to go shopping and got lost. ``They had apparently taken a wrong turnoff, and when they saw a sign saying `Welcome to Soweto' they realized they were lost,'' the daughter, Georgie Braithwaite, told the South African Press Association. Someone shot at the car, hitting the woman in the arm and the man in the stomach, Halgryn said. The man, 74-year-old Alfred Francis Harrison, died at the scene, the spokesman said. His 69-year-old wife Phyllis was hospitalized in satisfactory condition. The couple's daughter said the couple had come to the country to celebrate their grandson's 21st birthday. Halgryn said police were searching for the attackers, who also stole the couple's watches.

DOC.HEAD: People in Liberia Are `Dying like Flies,' Doctor Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Official's name is pronounced RAKE-ul-AKE-hyzen.
DOC.TEXT: Liberians are ``dying like flies'' because rice shipments sent by the United States and France are being unloaded too slowly in Liberia's capital, a Belgian official said Tuesday. Hunger is acute, and ``people are so undernourished that rice is not enough. Milk, fish, meat and cooking oil are needed,'' said Dr. Pieter Rykelhykhuizen of the Belgian branch of Doctors without Borders. Rykelhykhuizen, who came to Freetown from Monrovia on Monday night aboard a U.S. Marine helicopter, said the security situation in Monrovia was good, but that remnants of Doe's army were harassing relief workers. He said Doctors without Borders is the only relief agency still operating in Liberia. But Karen Donovan, a spokeswoman for Catholic Relief Services, said the Baltimore-based agency also had people working there. Rykelykhuizen said other relief agencies had sent people only to assess the situation. ``Relief workers and not assessment teams are needed as people are dying like flies daily because of the food problem,'' he said in an interview. Donovan said her relief agency was helping to unload U.S. rice sent to the country. She said there were five members of the agency in Buchanan, Liberia's second biggest city, and one in Monrovia. The United States sent 1,930 tons of rice to Monrovia aboard a ship chartered by the French government. Rykelykhuizen said a barge hired by the U.N. World Food Program to carry 600 tons of rice also was there. They arrived on Thursday, but the food still was being unloaded, Rykelykhuizen said. The French Embassy in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, said ``technical problems are slowing down the offloading.'' Claude Demiautte, the embassy's shipping officer, said security precautions were partly to blame. Hungry people and soldiers have looted most food supplies in Monrovia. People are trying to survive eating leaves. Liberia has been devastated by a 10-month-old civil war in which three warring sides have killed more than 5,000 civilians. A breakaway rebel faction and soldiers loyal to slain President Samuel Doe have agreed to a cease-fire. A five-nation West African army sent to stop the killing is fighting outside the capital against another rebel faction, led by Charles Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Coin Shop Killer Charles Sinclair Dies in Jail
DOC.TEXT:
A man suspected in the killings of a dozen coin workers in the United States and Canada died in an Anchorage jail Tuesday of an apparent heart attack, authorities said. Charles T. Sinclair, 44, was fighting extradition to Montana to face murder charges in the slayings of two people in a coin shop in Billings, Mont., on July 31. He was arrested Aug. 13 near his home in Kenney Lake, 175 miles northeast of Anchorage. Authorities said Sinclair was being sought for questioning in at least 12 slayings, most of them in the western United States.
Sinclair suffered an apparent heart attack in a maximum-security cell at the jail, said state Corrections Commissioner Susan Humphrey-Barnett. Guards were unable to resuscitate him, she said. The Alaska State Troopers were asked to investigate and an autopsy would likely be performed, she said. It is the first time an inmate has died at the 8-year-old jail, she said. Sinclair had been taking medication for high blood pressure when he was admitted to the jail Aug. 15, as well as two narcotic-based drugs for pain and for a thyroid condition, Humphrey-Barnett said. Medical staff at the jail discontinued his pain medication and cut in half his daily dosage of Inderal for high blood pressure. After Sinclair complained on Sept. 24, the 80-milligram dosage was reinstated, she said. While at the jail, his blood-pressure readings hadn't changed significantly, she said. Sinclair also had been charged with wounding a coin shop owner in Murray, Utah, last May. Investigators wanted to question Sinclair in connection with killing coin shop workers in Everett, Wash., in January 1980; Vacaville, Calif., in November 1986; Spokane, Wash., in July 1987; Kansas City, Mo., in March 1988; Watertown, N.Y., in September 1989; and Vancouver, British Columbia, on June 19. Montana Gov. Stan Stephens requested Sinclair's extradition on Aug. 23, and Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper approved it on Sept. 11. Sinclair had delayed his return to Montana partly on grounds that the state's death penalty law is unconstitutional, Curtner said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Blasts Caribbean Government for Bleak Economy
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic bishops delivered an unusually strong attack Tuesday, saying the government needed to give Dominicans a ``little hope'' to help them through the economic crisis. Prices for food and gasoline have skyrocketed in recent months, leading to long lines and shortages. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, the government had to cut its oil imports and triple oil prices. Blackouts leave this island country without electricity for up to 18 hours a day. ``Precise, energetic and efficient'' measures are required to combat shortages of goods ``that should be accessible to common people but have disappeared from the shelves,'' the church communique said. ``The almost permanent darkness that covers the Dominican territory not only irritates, but turns gloomier our already desperate situation,'' the statement said. It implied that a lack of leadership was aggravating this Caribbean nation's ills. ``We believe the government should begin by offering an example of coordination, coherence, honesty and discipline that compels the citizenry to do its share,'' said the church communique. A few measures like this would give citizens a ``little hope, and return to the government its lost credibility,'' it said. The church has been generally supportive of President Joaquin Balaguer's conservative administration. The 84-year-old blind leader was narrowly re-elected to his second four-year term in May over leftist Juan Bosch. A majority of the country's 7 million Spanish-speaking people are Roman Catholic, and the church's word carries considerable weight in the population.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Brings Up Race During Campaigning
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jesse Helms accused Democrat Harvey Gantt on Tuesday of injecting race into the campaign, while Gantt said the comments were an insult to North Carolina voters. A Gantt ad being played on black radio stations says Gantt would be good for ``us'' on education and other issues. ``He is saying one thing to the black citizens of the state and he's saying another to all the rest of the citizens,'' the senator told about 60 people during a campaign stop. Helms says he does not object to the strategy, but does object to Gantt's claims that he is sending the same message to all people. ``Don't let Senator Helms tell you Harvey Gantt is doing something secret and sinister,'' Gantt told an enthusiastic crowd of about 500 people. ``I ask you, how can Harvey Gantt be running a secret campaign on black radio stations? This insults the voters of this state.'' During his Kinston appearance, Helms twice brought up his vote to sustain President Bush's veto of the Civil Rights Act, which he said included quotas that would require the hiring of certain proportions of minorities. ``If you want quotas to dominate and dictate whether you get a job or get a promotion, you vote for Mr. Gantt,'' he said. Helms peppered his speeches with other references to blacks. He said Gantt had disappointed some blacks by applying for a minority-owned television station while mayor of Charlotte, then selling it for a profit. ``No wonder he has a swimming pool in his backyard and a tennis court,'' Helms said. Asked about the Federal Communications Commission's findings that Gantt had done nothing wrong in the transaction, Helms said, ``They just didn't investigate it.'' Helms reasserted claims that Gantt's campaign is being bankrolled by Helms' enemies. ``It's being paid for by homosexuals and lesbians,'' he said. ``They don't care all that much for Harvey Gantt. They want to get this conservative voice out of the United States Senate. They do not like what I do.'' Helms tried to temper his opposition to homosexuality. ``People can do what they want to in the privacy of their own homes,'' he said, ``but when they start marching in the street and say that homosexuality should be given special privileges and be treated as a normal lifestyle, you bet I say no.'' Helms, who was unable to personally campaign in North Carolina for many weeks because of a long session of Congress, said he's found supporters enthusiastic since he returned. And he said with a good turnout next Tuesday, election day, Republicans will triumph.

DOC.HEAD: Kirkpatrick Says U.S. Cannot Allow Limited Iraqi Withdrawal from Kuwait
LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: The United States cannot allow Saddam Hussein to negotiate a limited withdrawal that would allow the Iraq to keep some Kuwaiti territory, Jeane Kirkpatrick, former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, said Tuesday. Speaking at the 56th annual convention of the Associated Press Managing Editors on the first day of a four-day meeting, Ms. Kirkpatrick said the Iraqi leader would interpret partial withdrawal as a victory. ``Saddam Hussein is an aggressive man who already has used force and the threat of force against every one of his neighbors,'' she said. ``If he had rewards from this aggression ... I have no doubt that he would move on.'' Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates would be especially vulnerable, said Ms. Kirkpatrick, a professor of political science at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. But President Bush is unlikely to accept a partial withdrawal, she said, noting, ``He has told us again and again and again he will not.'' The Persian Gulf crisis - precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and annexation of its gulf-rich neighbor and the mobilization of a U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia - is the first test of the post-Cold War era, Ms. Kirkpatrick said. Had the invasion taken place five years ago, she said, it would have been perceived as a Soviet bid for control of the Persian Gulf and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Superpower cooperation and the weakening of Communism have reduced it to a personal power grab, and the refusal of what used to be the Soviet bloc to support Iraq in the United Nations is a sign of the new world order, she said. Ms. Kirkpatrick said the end of the Cold War will allow the United States to turn its focus inward, devoting its attention and resources to ``some really aching domestic problems, frankly, which I think we have not attended to as well as we could have.'' Isolationism from world affairs will not work, she cautioned, but neither shuld the United States act as a ``global policeman.'' America's actions in the Persian Gulf go beyond self-interest, she said, because the invasion of Kuwait has global importance. ``We are not that energy-dependent on the Gulf ... Our domestic resources are in fact rich and our hemispheric energy resources are rich. We can provide our own needs,'' she said. She said the world is witnessing the death throes of communism, but is unsure what form of government will now emerge in Eastern Europe. Ms. Kirkpatrick said she doubts Communism can be revived. ``I think this is a Humpty Dumpty which will never be put back together again,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas' Top Legal Officer: `I Never Meant to Deceive'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with more testimony from attorney general. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Steve Clark testified Tuesday at his theft trial that he never meant to abuse a state-issued credit card and made honest mistakes when filling out expense forms. Clark appeared to choke back tears during his testimony, telling the jury: ``I never in my entire life meant to mislead or deceive or misrepresent.'' Clark faces one charge of felony theft by deception. He is accused of entertaining friends, girlfriends, relatives and political supporters on his state Visa card. He testified that he accidentally recorded as guests people who didn't eat meals with him when he itemized bills months later, but he said repeatedly he was given no restrictions on how to spend his $5 million budget. ``I have tried to pay all personal entertainment that is on the card,'' Clark said during 2{ hours of testimony. Clark, whose annual salary is $26,500, took the stand after a judge denied a defense motion to dismiss the charge. Circuit Judge Perry Whitmore said Clark didn't have authority to use the credit card how he wished. ``Any use of these funds, whether in Little Rock or in Memphis, was inappropriate for there were no appropriations by the Legislature for that purpose,'' Whitmore said. Prosecutor Chris Piazza accused Clark earlier in the trial of improperly billing taxpayers at least $8,448.27 on his credit card for the meals of personal guests on 56 occasions from 1986 to 1989. Clark could get up to 20 years in prison and a $15,000 fine if convicted. More than 100 of 141 witnesses who testified against Clark in the last week said they either didn't dine with Clark or didn't discuss state business, despite claims to the contrary that Clark made on his expense forms. The state rested its case Monday with the testimony of three women. The women said they didn't know the state paid for their dinners, which sometimes topped $300 a meal. Clark's former fiancee, Carrie Christie of Atlanta, testified that Clark dated her, popped the question and later got his engagement ring back during more than a dozen meals and trips paid for by the state in 1986 and 1987. She said they broke off their engagement during an Atlanta meal Clark's expense forms show was held to discuss ``low-level waste.'' She said the topic never came up. In some of her most damaging testimony, she said Clark often jotted down notes on the back of his Visa receipts. Clark has said his record-keeping was sloppy and that he reconstructed his expense forms up to three months after the fact. ``I could have spent more time. I could have done a better job'' with expense records, Clarks said. ``But if I had to do it again, I would do it much different and I would do it much better.'' Cheryl Pruett of Germantown, Tenn., testified she spent the night at a Memphis, Tenn., hotel with Clark that records show the state paid for. In honor of her birthday, Clark paid $245 with the Visa card at a Germantown restaurant, she said. Karen Aufdenberg of Little Rock testified she attended at least eight meals for which the state was billed, including four in New Orleans. ``There are times in my job, because I am divorced, I would think an escort was appropriate because the functions were for couples,'' Clark said. Clark, a Democrat, has been the Arkansas attorney general since 1979. He said he always paid for the women's airfare and routinely reimbursed the state for dozens of social meals that were originally charged to the credit card. Clark said it was difficult for him to determine when the state should pay for meals for others because he often mixed business with pleasure. ``I live, eat sleep and breath politics,'' he said. ``That is the truth. It's not necessarily good, but it's the truth.'' Clark said publicity surrounding his state expense reimbursements derailed his plans to run for governor. Piazza was to cross-examine Clark on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: PLO: Arabs Should Drop Objections to Israel's U.N. Membership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli reaction, minor editing to conform. Picks up graf 18th pvs, `Observers believed...'
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization on Tuesday asked Arab nations to drop longstanding objections to Israel's U.N. membership. In a private meeting of Arab ambassadors, Palestinian and other Arab diplomats said PLO head envoy Nasser al-Kidwa proposed the Arabs accept Israel's General Assembly credentials. However, the Arabs would propose an amendment to the official membership list that reminds Israel of its obligation to obey Security Council and General Assembly resolutions on the Middle East. Among these are Security Council resolutions attacking Israel's declaration of a unified Jerusalem as its capital. General Assembly resolutions call for separate homelands for Palestinian and Jews, and guarantee the right of Palestinian exiles to go home to the new Palestine. Israel's U.N. Mission was informed of the proposal. ``The issue is still being studied. Our first reaction is that any singling out of Israel is unacceptable,'' said Israeli sources, speaking on condition of not being further identified. The Arab ambassadors too were unable to agree immediately on the PLO proposal. One problem for them seemed to be whether voting for Israel's U.N. membership, even with those amendments, would constitute recognition of Israel. ``I think they are very concerned about the implications themselves,'' said one Western ambassador who is an expert on the Middle East. The chairman of the Arab group, Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan, said he would likely ask the General Assembly president to delay consideration of the membership issue rather than take it up Thursday, as scheduled. Since 1982, the Arabs have challenged Israel's right to sit in the General Assembly, claiming it is not a peace-loving state, as required by the U.N., Charter. The Arabs lost every year, and last year the Soviet Union abstained on the issue rather than voting with them. The socialist bloc of countries split three ways on the issue rather than backing the Arabs. In 1989, the Assembly voted 95-37 to seat Israel; in 1988, the vote was 85-39, with some nations absent or abstaining each year. The Arabs had been losing votes on the issue each year, and this year the Soviets were expected to vote in favor of Israel, some Arabs said. Al-Kidwa characterized the PLO's move as ``a more positive approach'' the Israel-Palestinian issue. This is the first major new diplomatic move by al-Kidwa, who is a nephew of PLO chairman Yasser Arafat. Veteran PLO Ambassadr Zuhdi Labib Terzi retired from his 16-year posting as head of the delegation last month to become an adviser to Arafat, and al-Kidwa took his place. Al-Kidwa said the amendment to the membership report he was proposing would make reference to about 20 Security Council resolutions on the status of Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza. Observers believed that hard-line Arab states such as Syria, Libya and Iraq would be unable to support the PLO proposal if it is viewed as amounting to some form of recognition of Israel. In 1948, the newly founded Israeli government was willing to accept the General Assembly resolutions setting up two states, but the Arab nations rejected the two-state idea and attacked Israel the day after it declared itself a nation. Israel captured about half the land that was supposed to become an Arab Palestinian state, and the other half was divided between Jordan and Egypt. The Israeli government has claimed since then that it needs to retain some of the occupied territory as a buffer against Arab attacks. In 1988, Arafat became the first Arab leader to endorse the two-state concept originally devised by the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Winery Worker Convicted of 7 Murder Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `Salcido also...,' to ADD that Butti was shot in shoulder.
DOC.TEXT: A former winery worker was convicted of six counts of first-degree murder Tuesday for a wine-country killing spree that left seven people dead, including his wife and two young daughters. Defendant Ramon Salcido was found guilty of second-degree murder in the seventh slaying. Salcido, 29, could be sentenced to die in the gas chamber at San Quentin Prison when the jury returns for the trial's penalty phase. Under California law, multiple murder is one of the ``special circumstances'' which can justify a death sentence. The panel apparently agreed with Sonoma County prosecutor Peter Bumerts that Salcido methodically criss-crossed the fertile Sonoma Valley north of San Francisco, stabbing and shooting his family and co-workers the morning of April 14, 1989. ``What this means for the families is perhaps one chapter of this horrible nightmare will be laid to rest,'' Bumerts after the verdicts were read. ``I can't say I was delighted by it, but I wasn't shocked,'' said defense attorney Marteen Miller. ``One way or another, I think this jury had its mind made up.'' Salcido sat quietly as the verdicts were read in San Mateo County Superior Court. He also was convicted of two counts of attempted murder and cleared of one count of attempted voluntary manslaughter. The jury received the case on Wednesday and deliberated Thursday, Monday and most of Tuesday. First-degree murder convictions require proof of premeditation and defense attorneys had urged jurors to opt for second-degree murder or manslaughter.
