DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - He was a farmer, storyteller and sometime oil field worker. More than that, Hugh McDaniel was an institution in the heart of Louisiana where Cajun French blends happily with Southern drawls. And when he died the high and the low turned out for a wake that lasted around the clock.

He was no mover or shaker. He never held public office and didn't have a lot of money. Yet, 400 people made their way to the deep woods of central Louisiana to attend the wake of the man they all knew as Mr. Hugh. They came to pay their respects to Hugh McDaniel, vegetable farmer and story teller, who died at age 73. News of the wake had been broadcast throughout the day on KVPI Radio in Ville Platte, in both French and English since this part of the country represents the marriage bed of the Catholic-Cajun and Protestant cultures. Illiterates mingled with university professors. Welfare recipients chatted easily with a couple of oil millionaires. All had been charmed by Hugh McDaniel, farmer and storyteller. Bo Goodman, for example. He doesn't own a car. He hitched a ride. And William Leece, owner of an oil field service company, a business in a frenzy due to the crisis in Iraq. He locked his office for the day to attend. Maude King came. She lives so far back in the woods that even in the 1960s some residents didn't have electricity. The wake lasted 24 hours with the kitchen of the Friendship Baptist Church working around the clock, concocting steamy gumbo, coffee thick enough to float a spoon and enough deserts to make a fat man weep. Plates of Cajun sausage - boudin - were complemented by the Protestants' traditional chicken and dumplings. As a drizzling rain fell constantly this autumn day, inside the church one pew was filled with the Naquin family, cousins of McDaniel, who conversed and prayed in French. A cousin from another branch of the family leaned over the pew to speak to the Naquins. ``How're y'all,'' he drawle. Many sat all night in the church. The later services were conducted by four ministers, including two Baptists, a Church of Christ lay preacher and a Catholic priest. Organized religion is casual here. Hugh McDaniel symbolized that casualness. The son of a French-speaking, Catholic mother, he went to the Baptist church as a youngster simply because that church was closest to the farm. Those were the days of mud roads and few autos. And time away from the farm could mean a lost crop and a bare cupboard. And, typical of the 1920s, he spoke mostly French until he went to school where teachers whipped those who didn't speak English. Such attitudes nearly killed the Cajun culture, which was revived in the 1960s. Now, French is taught in elementary school. Hugh McDaniel was not typical in other ways, this man who grew vegetables and fruit on a few acres along Dun Beef Creek just north of Pine Prairie. He was the kind of man that most of us, as youngsters, want to emulate, but wind up in middle-age realizing with some self-pity that we never made it. Mr. Hugh gloried in his God, his family, his fellow man and the soil - in that order. People were naturally drawn to the warmth of a man who never met a stranger. Over decades, word-of-mouth sent the message through several parishes. There was a man in the woods growing anything that could sprout. They came to buy. Discovering he was a storyteller, customers sat under the pecan trees and listened. They left as friends. He made the headlines of a local newspaper when he grafted a domestic peach tree with a wild tree, developing a new strain of the fruit. County agents and agriculture professors from the University of Southwestern Louisiana heard of his delicious peaches. They listened to accounts of how he grew crops that couldn't be sustained in that part of the country where the frost came early. The experts traveled to the farm to see for themselves, to see if he could grow satsuma oranges this far north. Could he really grow kiwis? That couldn't be done in this climate. Surely, he couldn't produce Vidalia onions which were grown successfully only in a few Georgia counties. Ah, but he did all that. The professors also sat under the trees, sipping iced tea and listening to Mr. Hugh's stories. He had little desire for material possessions but dutifully worked the oil fields at times for the money that would give his four children benefit of college educations. The farming wouldn't sustain those expenses because Mr. Hugh wouldn't charge enough. On top of that, he gave away as much as he sold, traveling the roads with food for the sick and the out-of-work. The millionaire Leece met the farmer in the oil fields, totally disarmed by a grimy, oil-spattered employee who treated the owner like a fellow employee, wanting to chat during breaks. Leece found that he missed those chats and was drawn to the farm once Mr. Hugh's college funding duties were over. With time on his hands, Mr. Hugh contributed columns to the Ville Platte Gazette, sometimes featuring Jean Pierre with a Cajun dialect. A simple man's view of the world, a bit of local history, a humorous account of a personal experience. So, he's gone, taking with him the well-chronicled stories of his wonder dogs, Revlon and Rich. We'll hear no more of friend, Calabas, or jokes about the ``ole woman,'' his cherished wife, Eudole, now 73. Spring won't bring another column of God's grace at planting time. But, not to mourn. Mr. Hugh would be the first to say that mankind is like the soil in a way, sprouting other storytellers. Maybe they are out there now. Maybe his columns have inspired other simple folk to take up the pen. As for the farm? Well, Jean Pierre said it all in one of his columns: ``I believe when God made the world, he paused here at Dun Beef Cove and gave it a few extra strokes just for me. I believe He expects me to dress and keep it and realize that I am only a tenant here for a short time and that I must pass this farm on to those who come after me, just a little better than I found it.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - He first took to the piano at the age of 2, started seriously studying at 6, and now this son of a piano teacher is the talk of the music world. Meet Evgeny Kissin, a young Russian on the move.

On the day he turned 19, pianist Evgeny Kissin listened to some tapes of his American recital debut, telephoned his father in Moscow, and sat down at a piano to happily rip out some ragtime. It was somewhat out of character for this serious young Russian who rarely smiles on stage, even while taking bows to thunderous applause. But he has reason to celebrate these days. Since he made his American debut with the New York Philharmonic on Sept. 20, critics have been raving, saying Kissin is the kind of exciting, expressive pianist who rarely comes along. That triumphant debut was followed with a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sept. 30 and another recital in Chicago on Oct. 7. The music cognoscenti were eager to hear Kissin live, knowing of him mainly through his recordings and word of mouth. The ``Live at Carnegie Hall'' record - Chopin, Liszt, Schumann and Prokofiev, plus four encores - was rushed into a Nov. 20 release as a two-CD set by RCA Victor. Kissin, whose nickname is Genya, has recital debuts early next year in Amsterdam, Paris and Milan. He will play with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood next summer and when he returns next fall he's scheduled in Toronto, Dallas, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Montreal, Boston and New York. He already is booked for spring 1992 by the Chicago Symphony and the Philadelphia Orchestra. It isn't always possible to tell whether a piano hotshot, playing partly by youthful instinct, will stay on top in adulthood or fade away. One knowledgeable, longtime observer of the classical music scene said that when one has as much talent as Kissin, a big career is confidently forecast. Harold Schonberg, writing in The New York Times, said, ``Musicians in general...tend to sound alike, products of an assembly line age, playing without charm or any apparent affection for the music under their fingers. Mr. Kissin has evolved his own style, and it is a style that looks back to a period when a controlled sonority, a singing line, power without banging, tempo modification and poetry were what the great Slavic Romantic pianists represented.'' ``I never tried to make a special style in my playing,'' Kissin says. ``I want to understand, what did the composer intend. ``Basically, my teacher's virtue is to develop what nature has given me and never to dictate or enforce her own stylistic views. She helps to guide and not let me go to extremes.'' He has had the same teacher, Anna Pavlovna Kantor, since he started at 6 at Moscow's Gnessin School for Gifted Children. Actually, he took his first shot at playing the piano at age 2. Kissin doesn't smile on stage, he says, ``because I am inside of the music. I am trying to be inside before I come on stage, because it is necessary. Sometimes, after, I still feel inside the music.'' Sometimes, on stage, he'll play something a bit differently than ever before. ``This is not really experimenting. This is an inspiration that comes,'' he says. ``If you really feel that you are totally in the music and the mood is right for that, it'll just come out naturally. If you're trying to do something different, very often it would come out artificially. ``It is like discovering something, like looking at a painting and all of a sudden seeing an aspect you never saw before and trying to bring out that beauty.'' As well as listening to recordings by Arthur Rubinstein and Soviet pianists, Kissin listened to Van Cliburn. In 1958, when Cliburn won the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, Kissin says, ``My mother was very young. Cliburn was really an idol for her and for people her age, so his records were in our house.'' Kissin hasn't needed to enter competitions. He made his debut at 10, gave his first solo recital at 11 and performed two Chopin concerti with the Moscow State Philharmonic at 12. He intends to add to the composers whose music he plays. ``I will play Beethoven, I hope Ravel and Debussy, Mussorgsky, more Schumann and Brahms.'' And Kissin's world contains more than piano. ``I'm interested in literature, history, politics, geography - Russian and the world. ``Glasnost should be good for artists. I think politics makes a difference. Some artists have got the possibility to return like Rostropovich and Kremer and Davidovich and Ashkenazy. Soviet artists can move freer. I think it is normal that artists need new impressions. And I think the feeling of freedom is in the playing.'' Kissin mentions seven gifted Soviet pianists about his age who probably will be able to play in America now that cultural relations have been re-established between the two countries. He was very nervous walking onto the Carnegie Hall stage, Kissin says, but not because of the recent Cold War. ``When I was a little boy, it was my dream to play in Carnegie Hall but I didn't think too much about politics. Carnegie was a special name for me, like a legend. ``It was for me a new step in my fortune. I was nervous like never before. He hadn't been as nervous before playing with the New York Philharmonic. ``It is easier when you have an orchestra.'' Success is not going to his head. ``Adulation is nice when it is from the heart,'' he says. ``Sometimes it is not very intelligent.'' Besides, not all his performances have been glamorous. ``I played in East Berlin when I was 13, on my first trip abroad. My first performance was in an opera house. The next morning I played an upright piano, very bad, at a shipyard, for the workers. ``They liked it. They gave me a beautiful chess set.'' He shakes his head no when asked whether he has a girlfriend. ``The art demands sacrifices,'' he says. Later he says he was kidding. ``I hope to have a normal life. I think for an artist it's necessary, to have somebody to help and share.''

DOC.TEXT: In her biography ``Call Me Anna,'' Patty Duke tells how John and Ethel Ross took over her career as a child, introduced her to alcohol and pills and subjected her to sexual and emotional abuse. Still, Duke says, they had good intentions. ``I can't look at these people and say they're black-hearted villains,'' says Duke, who plays herself as an adult in the film version of her biography to be shown on ABC on Sunday. ``Their intentions were good, but they got lost.'' Under the Rosses' tutelage, Duke became a star of ``The Miracle Worker'' on Broadway and at 14 became the youngest person to win an Oscar for the movie version of the story of Helen Keller. Duke went on to star in the television series ``The Patty Duke Show.'' In the movie and in her 1987 biography, Duke tells how she became manic-depressive after the Rosses separated her from her family as a child, changed her name to Patty and told her, ``Anna Marie is dead.'' ``Bizarre though it may be,'' Duke says, she included the Rosses in the dedication of the book, which she co-wrote with Kenneth Turan. Both of the Rosses died several years before the book was published. ``My intention in the book and the movie is to suggest very strongly that these people had disturbed psyches of their own rather than malicious intent,'' she says. ``I was abused by both of them. He drank and she drank and took pills. ``They never thought this kid would be on Broadway or win an Oscar. I think the fear of losing me affected them. I think because of that fear they ended up driving me away.'' Even after leaving the Rosses, Duke continued to suffer mood swings and depression until she was diagnosed as a manic-depressive and underwent treatment. The movie also stars Howard Hesseman as John Ross, Deborah May as Ethel Ross, Ari Meyers as Duke as a child, Jenny Robertson as Duke as a teen-ager and Millie Perkins as her mother, Frances Duke. Arthur Taxier plays John Astin, Duke's third husband, and Karl Malden is Dr. Harold Arlen, the psychiatrist who helped her bring her mental illness under control. Her brother, Ray Duke, plays their father. Duke is married to Michael Pearce, a former Army sergeant she met while filming ``A Time To Triumph.'' They divide their time between Los Angeles and a home in Idaho. She recently left for Canada to work in a new CBS movie ``To Cast a Shadow.'' Her son, Sean Astin, is in ``Memphis Belle'' and is working on ``The Toy Soldier.'' Another son, MacKenzie Astin, has been an actor and is now in school. Although she has won an Oscar and three Emmys, Duke says playing herself was awkward. ``I couldn't use my usual system of acting,'' she says. ``I had tremendous help from Gil Cates, the director and producer, who also had his problems directing me. He said, `How can I tell you I don't think she would have behaved that way?' What it all boiled down to was an exercise of just doing my job and not trying to monitor it all the time. I left that to Gil and all went well. ``Will people believe this outrageous behavior? It was very real, out-of-control behavior.'' Duke says re-creating the scenes was not painful because it had been eight years since she had been treated and even longer since some of the incidents happened. ``I think there was some embarrassment,'' she admits. ``I don't think any of us like people to see the uglier parts of us. But I never felt I was back there reliving any of it.'' Duke is writing a second book that deals more directly with depressive disorders. As with the first book, she is working with a professional writer. ``There are a lot of textbooks, but this is an attempt to reach a broader audience,'' she says. ``It allows me to talk about diagnosis and treatment.'' She says she did not know how people would react to publication of her biography in 1987. ``I mean when you say good morning, I had an illness, you don't know if you'll work again,'' she says. ``But it shows you can be cured. ``In the beginning I didn't think it could be transferred to the screen. Then I began to see a very important, very valuable avenue to reach people. I wouldn't be living up to my own goal of helping people if I didn't take advantage of television.'' The movie presented some legal problems for ABC, which had to decide who among the characters is and is not a public figure - and obtain clearances from those still alive.

DOC.TEXT: Despite its success in New York in 1928, ``Machinal,'' an expressionistic drama written by Sophie Treadwell, has been one of Broadway's lost plays. There were occasional productions over the years, including one off-Broadway in 1960, and a script published in an anthology by women playwrights in 1982. But the play and its feminist author remained unknown to most theatergoers for some 60 years. Unknown, that is, until Michael Greif, a quiet, bespectacled director with a shy smile and Harpo Marx hair, resurrected it this fall at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. He turned ``Machinal'' (pronounced mock-en-AHL) into a big hit with the Public extending the play's sold-out run until the end of November to accommodate the ticket demand. The play is based loosely on the sensational 1927 murder trial of Ruth Synder, the first woman executed in the electric chair. She and her lover were convicted of killing Synder's husband. Treadwell, a well-known journalist of her day who once obtained an exclusive interview with Pancho Villa, embellishes on the real-life story for theatrical effect. Her heroine, called Helen Jones, is dehumanized by a stifling job, a greedy, grasping mother, a loveless marriage and finally an ill-fated love affair. She is society's victim, trapped by a gritty, dark and oppressive environment. The 31-year-old Greif is part of a major change this season at the Public Theater, where producer Joseph Papp has staged his own in-house cultural revolution. JoAnne Akalaitis, earth mother of the avant-garde theater troupe Mabou Mines, was named his artistic associate. And Papp has allowed three young directors to produce their own programs of plays at Public this year on budgets of $300,000 for each director. Besides Greif, the directors chosen were George C. Wolfe, author of ``The Colored Museum'' and ``Spunk,'' and David Greenspan, who directed ``Kate's Diary'' at the Public last year. Greif first directed ``Machinal'' last year in an old framing warehouse on West 16th Street for a theater company called Naked Angels. Papp saw the production, liked it and wondered if Greif wanted to come to the Public Theater. ``He asked me what is a very often-asked question at a directing interview, which is, `If you could choose a season of plays, what would you choose?' '' Greif recalls. ``Machinal'' immediately came to mind. The other two took a little longer to find. ``I ended up choosing the two plays I was most burning to do - apart from `Machinal,' '' Greif says. He picked Tony Kushner's ``A Bright Room Called Day,'' which is set in Germany during the 1930s. The play, which already has been done in California, London and Chicago, is about a kind of heroism, Greif says. Performances begin in December. The third offering, ``Casanova,'' by Constance Congdon, was seen by Greif in a reading at New Dramatists. The playwright is still working on the play which naturally is about the world's most celebrated lover. It opens next spring. Having his own season of shows is quite a heady experience for a stage-struck kid from Brooklyn, Brighton Beach to be exact. Greif's father was an optician, his mother worked part-time as an auditor for a life insurance company. Their son went to the theater a lot. Instead of going to high school, he'd sneak off to matinees, usually musicals. ``The musical form was actually a form where American directors did the most interesting and experimental work,'' Greif says. He directed in high school, putting together what he calls ``very idealistic, very crude original musicals.'' He studied acting and directing at Northwestern University in Illinois, but ended up in California for more courses on directing with Beckett guru Alan Schneider at the University of California at San Diego. Greif also worked as an assistant to director Des McAnuff, who was just starting up a new theater program at the nearby La Jolla Playhouse. He assisted McAnuff on the director's regional theater productions of ``Big River,'' a musical version of ``The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' that eventually made it to Broadway. ``I supported myself for a couple of years directing `Big River' tours,'' Greif says, including the Japanese and Australian productions. ``Machinal'' was brought to Greif's attention three or four years ago by Jodie Markell, who plays the leading role. The two went to school together at Northwestern and always had talked of working together. ``The play requires an ensemble that is willing to really be a part of a fabric, a great whole, and be comfortable in working in a stylized way,'' Greif says. ``The production works because it keeps a fine line between a completely stylized approach and also a very human approach. It dances back and forth.'' Does he have any more lost plays waiting to be discovered? ``They are still lost,'' Greif laughs. ``I'd like to uncover more, but I'm too busy. That's the joy of being an unemployed director. You have more time to find them.''

DOC.TEXT:
``John Sheppard: Media Vita'' (Gimmell) - The Tallis Scholars, directed by Peter Phillips. ``John Sheppard: Church Music'' (Hyperion) - The Sixteen, directed by Harry Christophers. ``Orlando Gibbons: The Cries of London'' (ADDA) - The Ensemble William Byrd and the instruments of The Occasional Byrd, Graham O'Reilly conducting. ``The Golden Age of English Cathedral Music'' (ASV) - Winchester Cathedral Choir, Martin Neary conducting.
John Sheppard seems to have begun his musical career in Oxford in the 1540s and disappeared from the scene in London around 1560. The dates of his birth and death are unknown. ``It is always unfortunate when there are no firm dates of birth and death for a composer, since it is then impossible to have anniversary celebrations for him,'' Peter Phillips drily observes in the notes to the Tallis Scholars recording. Sheppard's music was a late addition to the early music revival simply because the tenor parts of most of his composition had been lost, and weren't restored until the 1970s. In any case, composers are less in need of contrived anniversary concerts than of decent performances of their music, and here Sheppard is well served. There is little to choose between the two recordings. Three cuts are duplicated, and four singers appear on both discs. The Tallis Scholars' sound is warmer and more intimate while the larger ensemble of The Sixteen sings with a churchly grandness. If one must choose, the nod goes to The Sixteen because of the inclusion of one of Sheppard's loveliest compositions, ``In pace in idipsum'' (``In very peace will I lie down''). The music blossoms confidently and gloriously from a bud of plainchant, a small masterpiece of simplicity. Unlike Sheppard, Orlando Gibbons was never forgotten in his native England. At least some of his music - notably the majestic ``See, See the Word is Incarnate'' - has been continuously in the English cathedrals' repertoire for more than three centuries. That anthem is among the high points of the new French recording by the Ensemble William Byrd and its viol consort, The Occasional Byrd. It's the best Gibbons recording now available - splendidly performed, generously annotated and spanning the range of the composer's output. Most striking is a puckish performance of ``The Cries of London,'' seven minutes of Elizabethan sales pitches such as ``will ye buy my dish of eels'' and ``hard onions, hard.'' The Winchester Cathedral Choir's 1983 collection, recently reissued on a compact disc, features a consort of viols and perhaps the best of the boy-choir recordings of Gibbons' much-loved ``This Is the Record of John.'' Gibbons' ``See, See,'' William Byrd's ``Laudibus in Sanctis,'' Thomas Tallis' ``Salvator Mundi'' and Thomas Weelkes' ``Hosanna to the Son of David'' round out the joyful noise. - By Robert Barr, Associated Press Writer. --- ``Music From Graffiti Bridge'' (Paisley Park-Warner Bros.) - Prince
The first four songs on Prince's new album sound like a dictionary of pop music. There's rollicking rock (``Can't Stop This Feeling I've Got''), a dance-floor anthem (``New Power Generation''), bawdy rap (``Release It'') and a grinding ballad (``The Question of U''). It's a record collection's worth of styles on one disc. All four tunes are terrific, and they make more disappointing what follows: funk. Technofunk. Lite funk. Teeny-bopper funk. Formula filler funk. Most of all, forgettable funk. Prince's mistake may have been to rely heavily on guest performers. Three of the weakest songs among the record's 17 cuts were performed by The Time; another features singer Mavis Staples, who sounds good but gets stuck with a numbing tune. ``Music From Graffiti Bridge'' is to accompany Prince's upcoming new movie, and the guest performances make it sound like a tepid soundtrack album. Prince saves his best compositions to sing himself, and there are a few gems down the stretch - the Broadway-tinged ``Graffiti Bridge,'' the steamy ``Joy in Repetition'' and the psychedelica-gospel hybrid ``Still Would Stand All Time.'' A parental advisory sticker adorns the cover, but most of the sexual references are pretty lame and tame by Prince's standards. He's actually more interesting when he turns pious on a couple of cuts. Prince fares best when he's taking chances by testing different genres. Safe in his funk rut, he's duller than a bass drum track. - By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer

DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. reported a $214 million third-quarter loss, a performance that would have been worse without record earnings at the company's financial subsidiary. The earnings report on Monday, which showed Chrysler did better by loaning money than by building and selling cars, underscored its difficulties as the No. 3 Detroit automaker negotiates with the United Auto Workers to reach a new contract. The UAW instructed members to report to work even though the contract expired at midnight. --- BOSTON (AP) - Tax initiatives in six states could result in reduced bond ratings at state and local levels if passed by voters in the Nov. 6 election, a major bond rating agency warned. Moody's Investors Service said tax initiatives in Colorado, Massachusetts, Montana, Nebraska, Oregon and Utah could, if approved, lower the confidence financial advisers have in those states. The report was released last week. --- TEMPLE, Texas (AP) - Texas Instruments Inc. has joined competitors who have unveiled lightweight laptop computers featuring an increasingly popular microprocessor. The new notebook-size computer announced Monday, called Travelmate 3000, costs less than one with a similar chip announced two weeks ago by Compaq Computer Corp. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Merrill Lynch & Co. announced a sweeping management overhaul that could lead to several hundred job cuts at the nation's biggest securities firm. The reorganization, announced Monday, replaces Merrill's separate consumer and capital markets groups with six business divisions, eliminating a structure in place since 1984. It also creates a mechanism for Merrill to replace company chairman and chief executive William A. Schreyer, who is to retire in 1993 at age 65. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Leaders of striking Daily News unions planned an advertiser boycott and management blamed its distribution problms on vandalism and theft. The News said it distributed 906,000 copies of Monday's paper. The paper's normal weekday circulation is 1.18 million. Vice President John T. Sloan accused strikers of threatening vendors and vandalizing newsstands. --- DALLAS (AP) - Deteriorating industry conditions, including a drop in housing starts, prompted Aancor Holdings Inc. and subsidiary National Gypsum Co., to seek protection from creditors, officials say. The privately held Aancor filed the voluntary petitions in U.S. Bankruptcy Court on Friday, officials said Monday. National Gypsum was acquired by Aancor Holdings through a leveraged buyout completed in April 1986. --- NEW YORK (AP) - American Express Co. has taken a swipe at AT&T's popular Universal credit card with a broad marketing strategy that enables customers to easily charge calls using the MCI and Sprint long-distance companies. The ``Connect Plus'' package of services, announced Monday, lets cardholders make long-distance calls by punching in their account number, and offers 10 percent discounts on most MCI and Sprint calls made using the American Express card. It's the latest response by a financial services firm to American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s unexpectedly successful entry into the credit card business last March. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Congress' refusal to provide more money for savings and loan bailouts will delay the closing of failed institutions for months and add millions, or even billions, of dollars to taxpayers' costs, analysts say. Legislators' election-year squeeze left the Resolution Trust Corp., the bailout agency created last year, without the funds needed to close more than 300 insolvent or near-insolvent thrift associations. --- GENEVA (AP) - The world's major airlines meet this week to discuss a likely round of international fare increases provoked by the Persian Gulf crisis. The International Air Transport Association's announcement Monday marked the second time since the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2 that airlines will talk about fare hikes, which must be approved by governments. The last meeting in late August set fare increases of up to 8 percent. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil prices moved above $34 per barrel in light trading on the futures market, amid concerns that a Soviet peace effort in the Persian Gulf had failed. Light sweet crude oil on Monday rose $1.67 to $34.68 per barrel for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for later months also settled higher. --- LONDON (AP) - Barclays Bank PLC, one of Britain's largest banks, plans to streamline domestic retail branch operations over the next five years by closing 110 offices and trimming 1,800 staff through attrition. The office cuts, mostly in urban centers, amount to slightly more than 4 percent of Barclays' network of 2,600 retail bank branches in Britain, while the staff cuts represent 1.5 percent of its total domestic workforce of 87,000, the bank announced Monday. ---

Stock prices fell Monday as traders found little inspiration in Congress's passage of a federal budget plan. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tell 5.94 to 2,430.20. Bond prices also fell for the same reason. The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond fell about $6.25 per $1,000 in face amount and its yield rose to 8.83 percent from 8.77 percent late Friday. Elsewhere, the dollar rose against most key currencies, gold rose after falling overseas, and other commodities were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Tells Mutual Funds to Change Misleading Names, Advertising
DOC.TEXT: A week after telling mutual funds to do a better job of explaining the risk in high risk junk bonds, federal regulators now want mutual funds to do whatever it takes to eliminate any suggestions they are insured by the government. In a letter to all 3,500 investment companies registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, SEC officials stated a new get-tough policy that calls on funds to change their names, if necessary, to protect investors from even inadvertent confusion. ``Funds that currently have names using such terms as `guaranteed' or `insured' in conjunction with words such as `United States' or `U.S. government,' should take immediate action to remove those words from their names,'' said the letter signed by SEC Enforcement Division Director William R. McLucas and Gene A. Gohlke, acting director of the investment management division. It was the second time this month the SEC has urged changes in the mutual fund industry. Last week the SEC asked junk bond mutual funds to better explain the risks involved in such investments. The latest letter said funds should refrain from using terms implying government protection in their titles and warned that sanctions might be imposed ``against any fund that continues to use terms in its name or that advertises its securities'' in such a way. The Oct. 25 letter, made public by the SEC Monday, stated that even mutual funds that invest a majority of their assets in U.S. government securities - which are guaranteed - are not themselves guaranteed or insured by the government. ``Recently there have been some advertisements that play up names of the funds with `government guaranteed' something or other,'' Gohlke said in a telephone interview. ``We're concerned the names of the funds may give the unsophisticated investor the idea that the U.S. government is guaranteeing the fund shares themselves, which is not the case.'' He said there were at least 20 or 30 funds using the offending terms in some form that the SEC considers possibly misleading, but he declined to identify any by name. L. Erick Kanter, a spokesman from the Investment Company Institute, a Washington-based trade association for 2,900 mutual funds, said the group had no immediate comment on the SEC letter. But a preliminary check of the ICI's rolls turned up only about 18 funds investing in Treasury bonds or other government securities that used the term ``guaranteed'' in their name, he said, adding that ammounted to ``well under 10 percent'' of the association's member funds. The letter warning about implied government protection said funds seeking to register with such titles could expect SEC roadblocks delaying or preventing their sale to the public. Asked if the letter stemmed from problems encountered in the savings and loan debacle, Gohlke replied ``I can't say `No,' but we've had this concern for some time.'' Some thrift customers lost their life savings when they bought securities such as junk bonds sold at savings and loans, which later failed. They wrongly assumed their investment was insured by the government like thrift deposits were. Gohlke said the SEC had set no deadline for compliance on the government protection, but warned ``that they should take immediate action.''

DOC.HEAD: American Express Announces Broad New Phone-Charge Service
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. faces a big new challenge to its popular Universal phone-credit card, but the long-distance giant immediately dismissed the entry from American Express as ``a repackaging of old ideas.'' American Express's new ``Connect Plus'' package of services, announced Monday, enables customers to easily charge calls using the MCI and Sprint long-distance companies. With it, cardholders can make long-distance calls by punching in their account number. Customers can get 10 percent discounts on most MCI and Sprint calls made using the American Express card. The program, fully available to Sprint users Thursday and MCI users Jan. 1, is the latest response by a financial services firm to American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s unexpectedly successful entry into the credit card business last March. Since AT&T began offering Visa and Mastercard services to customers - with a 10 percent discount on all charged long distance calls - the long distance phone giant says it has opened about 3.6 million Universal accounts and distributed about 6 million cards. With 70 million long-distance customers, AT&T's entry into the highly competitive and profitable credit card industry has raised fears among U.S. banks and financial companies that they could lose business. By adding the convenience of long-distance calling to existing services, these firms are hoping to simply retain customers, observers say. ``AT&T's the bogey man here for everyone,'' said David Robertson, vice president of The Nilson Report, a credit-card industry newsletter published in Santa Monica, Calif. New entries like American Express's are ``a way to increase value of existing cards and maintain customers.'' In June Citibank, the nation's largest credit-card issuer, enlisted MCI to help launch a competitor to AT&T's card. The cards allow users to charge long-distance telephone calls via Visa or Mastercard. American Express, trying to differentiate itself, said a key advantage of ``Connect Plus'' is that full details about MCI and Sprint long distance phone calls such as date and number called show up on the cardholder's monthly bill. Billings for Visa and MasterCard programs show total phone charges as a one-line item, but MCI subsequently sends callers separate bills that itemize calls. At-home calls that appear on AT&T's Universal card bill are charged at a calling card rate as opposed to lower direct-dial rates, although the 10 percent discount narrows the difference. An AT&T spokesman dismissed American Express' cost advantage, saying the card's annual fee swallows savings for calls made at home. Charter membership in the Universal card is free. ``We don't see what's being offered by MCI and Sprint as anything new,'' said the spokesman, Bruce Reid. ``This looks like a repackaging of old ideas.'' While American Express aides declined to discuss sales goals, industry expert Robertson said he expects that 20 percent to 25 percent of the company's 26 million subscribers will sign up as members of the new program. American Express is backing its new service with a direct mail campaign, via the monthly newsletter sent to all cardmembers. American Express also will make selective mailings to customers deemed likely to sign up. The company may consider broader advertising of Connect Plus later, said Norma Arnold, senior vice president of membership marketing at American Express Travel Related Services Co. Robertson said American Express is likely to woo cardholders to the service because of its success as a direct-mail marketer and its high percentage of corporate card customers, who make a disproportionately large number of the nation's long distance calls. However, the new entry should intensify overall competition in the card business. ``There's going to be a shakeout alright. You have consolidation going on even as we speak,'' said Bruce Brittain, president of Brittain Associates Inc., an Atlanta-based research and consulting firm specializing in financial services. ``Some of the regional and local issuers arund the country are getting out of business.''

DOC.HEAD: Worried Accountants Can Talk Ethics on Hotline
DOC.TEXT: An accountant pressured to give too rosy a picture of company finances or ignore the boss' big spending may feel there is nowhere to turn for advice. But there is, say counselors operating a nationwide ``ethics hotline'' for the National Association of Accountants. ``There is often a thin line between what's appropriate and what's inappropriate,'' said counselor Howard Siers. ``We don't tell them what to do. We talk through their problem. We are kind of a sounding board for them.'' Siers, a retired auditor from Tucson, Ariz., helps field phone calls to 1-800-6-ETHICS, which is intended for NAA members only. With 100,000 members nationwide, the group is a professional organization for corporate staff accountants. Robert Sweeney, an accounting professor at Memphis State University, said he fields 15 to 20 calls a month to the hotline. ``There are so many people out there who have these ethical problems and they don't have anyone to talk to,'' he said. ``Having someone to reason it out with you is such a relief.'' Hotline counselors keep no permanent records of the calls they handle nor do they ask a caller his name or the name of his company, Sweeney said Monday. The idea is to help accountants decide on their personal actions, not to report the questionable ethics of their companies. ``Sometimes people will say that it looks like the only recourse they have is resigning,'' Sweeney said. A common dilemma for accountants seeking advice is being pressured to ``smooth the books,'' thereby making the company appear more profitable than it really is, he said. ``The boss will want to delay recording expenses so the financial statement for a period looks better,'' Sweeney said. An accountant faced with breaking the law generally has little trouble figuring out his options, Siers said, but grey areas involving ethics can be tough. The boss' personal expense claims when apparently excessive can cause such problems. ``An accountant has an obligation to review (such claims) with the person he or she reports to. But do you take it to a higher level?'' said Siers, a retired general auditor for the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. Siers said he has handled some 40 calls since the hotline opened last spring. Many of those calls, he said, have come from employees of smaller companies who have no colleagues they can speak with openly. The callers are often upset when they phone but then calm down after talking for awhile, Siers said. ``You can sense that they know then what they're going to do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Urges Chrysler Workers Not To Strike; Talks Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with talks still under way after midnight. Picks up 3rd graf, ``Everything is ...' Version moving on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union, hoping to avoid wildcat strikes at Chrysler Corp. plants, told its members Monday to report to work as usual even if it cancels a once-extended contract. The union and the No. 3 automaker continued to bargain early Tuesday on a new national labor contract involving 63,000 hourly and salaried workers in eight states after a midnight contract extension cancellation had passed. ``Everything is under control at the present time,'' UAW Local 1183 President Richard McDonaugh Jr. at Chrysler's Newark, Del., assembly plant said Monday afternoon. ``They're dissatisfied with the lengthy period of time the extension has been.'' The current contract, negotiated in 1988, was extended past its original Sept. 14 expiration while the UAW bargained separately with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. New three-year contracts are in place at those companies. The union gave Chrysler notice Friday that the contract extension would expire at midnight Monday. During bargaining Sunday, UAW President Owen Bieber reportedly rose from his chair and shouted at Anthony St. John, Chrysler's vice president for employee relations. ``If you want a strike, you'll get it,'' Bieber reportedly told St. John, Chrysler's chief bargainer. The Detroit News reported the outburst in Monday editions attributed to an unidentified union negotiator. Chrysler, meanwhile, said it lost $214 million during the third quarter. Most of the loss was attributed to one-month retooling shutdowns at two minivan plants, which make some of the company's most profitable vehicles, and to cash rebates and low-interest financing deals used to attract buyers. The blow was softened by record profits reported by its financial subsidiary. Chrysler Financial Corp., which handles consumer car loans, earned $83 million in the third quarter. Despite the lifting of the contract extension, union leaders told members to report to work until notified otherwise. The UAW scheduled a meeting Thursday in Detroit of its 200-member national Chrysler bargaining council. ``At that time, a tentative agreement or a report on the status of the negotiations will be presented,'' a union statement said. However, the bargaining council also may discuss strike strategy, union spokesman Bob Barbee said. ``We'll back our international (officers) as long as we can, but if they don't give us something, we're out of here,'' said Phil Portwood, a UAW member at Local 110 in St. Louis, home of one of the two minivan plants. He said his local already had made strike signs and developed picket schedules. ``We're ready to go,'' Portwood said. The UAW last struck Chrysler in October 1985 for 12 days. Major provisions of a new contract remained unresolved Monday, including job security, health-care provisions and retiree benefits. The UAW is pressing Chrysler to sign a contract similar to the GM and Ford agreements. Chrysler officers have said the company may not be able to afford certain provisions of the pattern agrement. Last week in Canada, Chrysler's wholly owned subsidiary agreed to follow a pattern for Canadian Auto Workers that was set at Ford and GM subsidiaries. When bargaining began in mid-July, Chrysler also said it needed help from the UAW to cut health-care expenses, which cost the company about $684 million last year. The pattern agreement has no change in health-care provisions. In addition to Michigan, Missouri and Delaware, Chrysler has plants in Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, New York and Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Unocal to Drill 93 New Oil Wells in North America
DOC.TEXT: Unocal Corp. is taking advantage of higher oil prices caused by the Middle East crisis to drill new oil wells in the United States and Canada. Unocal will spend $33 million to drill 93 new oil wells this year in North America, including 20 in California, said John F. Imle, Jr., senior vice president for energy resources. ``These projects were in the inventory and had not been funded simply because we didn't have the cash,'' Imle said Monday. ``That cash is now available because of higher crude oil prices.'' The new drilling originally was set to begin next year. It will allow Unocal to increase net production of crude and other products by 5,700 barrels a day, or 2.4 percent above 1989 levels. Unocal joins a growing list of companies that have benefited from rising oil prices caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Chevron Corp., Conoco Inc., British Petroleum and Atlantic Richfield Co. also stepped up oil production in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Auto Exports Fall 4.9 Percent In September
DOC.TEXT: Japan's vehicle exports fell 4.9 percent in September from year-earlier levels and slipped 3.7 percent in the first six months of the fiscal year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported Tuesday. Japanese manufacturers exported 509,155 cars, trucks and buses in September, the association said. Exports to the U.S. and European Community fell in September while exports to most other areas, particularly Asia, were up. Over the last several years, Japanese auto makers have invested heavily in factories located in the large North American and European markets. As they have come on line in the U.S. and the U.K., exports to both regions have fallen. In addition, an association official said, weakness in the U.S. economy is depressing the market for automobiles and trucks in that country and holding exports down. In contrast, fast economic growth in Southeast Asia is multiplying exports to the region. Automakers shipped 134,827 units to Europe in September, up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. But exports to the 12 members of the European Community were down 7.4 percent to 88,392 units. Exports to the United States totaled 207,762 units in September, down 12.7 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Cigarettes To Be Exported To Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's Tobacco and Ginseng Corp. has concluded a deal to export 5 million packs of Korean-made cigarettes to the Soviet Union next month, officials of the state-run corporation said Tuesday. The officials said the deal was made in Moscow between Hong Doo-pyo, president of the Korean corporation, and Moscow Mayor Gavril Popov over the weekend. The officials declined to disclose further details, including price. The deal also calls for both sides to study ways to set up a joint venture cigarette factory in the Soviet Union, they said. Earlier this year, the U.S.-based tobacco makers Philip Morris International Inc. and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. announced separately they had concluded deals to send more than 34 billion cigarettes to the Soviet Union. At the time, the companies described the Soviet Union as the third largest cigarette market in the world. A shortage of cigarettes dreove unhappy smokers into the streets of many Soviet cities this past summer.

The stock market was little changed in early trading today as the market digested better-than-expected economic figures. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 4.70 to 2,434.90 as of 10 a.m. EST. Advancing issues were barely ahead of decliners in the early going, with 473 stocks up, 431 down and 427 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 18.95 million shares after the first half-hour of trading. Analysts said the market was searching for a direction following the release of third-quarter gross national product figures. The Commerce Department said the economy grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent during the July-September period, a stronger than expected showing. Much of the increase was due to consumer spending, which was boosted by higher sales of cars and trucks. Analysts said the stock market was trying to determine how the figures might affect interest rates. The Federal Reserve is less likely to nudge rates lower if the economy appears to be expanding. Among blue chip issues, Philip Morris rose { to 46], General Electric was unchanged at 50~, and General Motors was off \ to 36}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.20 to 165.44. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.19 to 288.60. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a 5.94 loss at 2,430.20. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 481 up, 1,030 down and 453 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 133.98 million shares, against 130.19 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Keeps Presses Rolling Despite Strike, Newsstand Intimidation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf, `About 200 ...' to UPDATE with report in today's edition about number of union workers who returned Monday. Picks up 7th graf, `The News distributed ...'. A version moved on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News is keeping the presses rolling despite a walkout by nearly all its union workers but says strikers are destroying newspapers on the street and threatening newsstand operators. Meanwhile, union leaders met with Mayor David Dinkins and other city officials Monday to complain the city is taking sides by deploying hundreds of police to protect replacement workers and equipment. ``Why are police helping the publisher? The News is our enemy and I resent the city helping our enemy,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group for the unions at the newspaper. ``Our position is that there are too many officers being deployed - you have five officers for every picket.'' Police Commissioner Lee Brown said earlier Monday, ``We're not going to take sides in any job action. Our job is to enforce the law.'' About 200 officers are assigned to strike-related duties during the day, Brown said. The News said in today's editions that 45 of the 350 Guild members in its editorial department returned to work on Monday. In all, the Guild represents about 750 reporters, editors, photographers, clerks and business department employees. Barry Lipton, president of The Newspaper Guild, said ``a few'' members had gone back to work Monday. The News also said hundreds of permanent replacements were hired throughout the paper and 24 temporary editorial staffers are on loan from the Tribune Co., the parent company, which also has papers in Chicago, Virginia and Florida. The News distributed 906,000 copies of its Monday edition, according to spokeswoman Lisa Robinson. But ``due to widespread vandalism to newspapers once they are delivered to newsstands, the Daily News may be unavailable at some locations,'' Daily News executive John Sloan said in a statement. Sloan said strikers were threatening vendors, messing up newsstands where the paper is sold and stealing bundled papers off the streets. ``I'm not aware of that,'' said Mike Alvino, head of the drivers' union. ``I myself have gone to dealers in my neighborhood and said to them in a nice way, `Please do not buy the News.' '' Workers at several newsstands said club-wielding strikers destroyed papers and threatened violence if they persisted in selling the tabloid, which before the strike was the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily. Strikers have vandalized delivery trucks and buses carrying replacements to work. About 20 strikers have been arrested since the strike began Thursday, most on disorderly conduct charges. Union leaders on Monday called for a boycott of Daily News advertisers. Circulation difficulties prompted the discount appliance chain Newmark & Lewis to cut some advertising. Alexander's, a department store company, promised to maintain its advertising level in support of management. Nonunion editors and reporters from other papers operated by the News' parent company began arriving for work Monday, helping the skeleton crew of management employees that produced the paper after the strike began. The Tribune Co. also operates newspapers in Chicago, Virginia and Florida. Nine of the 10 unions at the paper went on strike last week after 10 months of talks on contracts that expired in March. The 71-year-old tabloid lost about $115 million in the past decade and circulation has slipped by about 700,000 since 1980. The paper recently lost its standing as the nation's largest metropolitan daily to The Los Angeles Times.

DOC.HEAD: Third Quarter GNP Up 1.8 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts graf 5, In another, with home sales. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew at a stronger-than-expected 1.8 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the government said today, continuing the longest peacetime expansion in U.S. history. The Commerce Department said the growth in the gross national product - the nation's total output of goods and services - improved over a barely perceptible 0.4 percent annual rate during the second quarter. The figures indicate the economy evaded the beginning of a recession. But that isn't certain because the GNP report will be revised twice - in November and again in December - as more information becomes available. Nevertheless, Commerce Undersecretary Michael R. Darby told a news conference: ``This release contradicts those who believe we are in a recession or are about to enter one. We expect the economy to continue to expand at a modest pace for the remainder of the year and in 1991.'' In another report, the government said sales of new homes slumped 6 percent in September, the ninth decline in the past 12 months and the worst drop in half a year. Much of the improvement in the economy resulted from a 3.6 percent increase in consumer spending. Purchases of automobiles rose $3.4 billion, compared to a $6.1 billion decline in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said. In advance of the report, a consensus of economists had expected a growth rate of 0.8 percent from July through September. But many analysts believe the economy has weakened in recent weeks and is slipping into a recession, generally described as at least two quarters of negative growth. Some economists say a recession actually began in the third quarter, but others point to signs of continued growth from July through September. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Monday that while some parts of the economy are in ``bad shape ... we're in a period of slower growth'' but not a recession. The department also said that a GNP measure of inflation rose to 4.1 percent in the third quarter. It was the first GNP report since the Persian Gulf oil-price shock pushed up the price of many consumer goods. GNP inflation had slowed to 3.9 percent in the second quarter from 6.4 percent in the first. In addition to consumer spending, the department said third-quarter economic growth was fueled by a 7.4 percent increase in business investment. On the other hand, that activity was partially offset by a $1.7 billion decline in inventories and a $7.9 billion merchandise trade deficit. Housing construction was off 15.4 percent and federal government spending, was down 0.3 percent. Second-quarter growth originally was reported to have been 1.2 percent at an annual rate. It remained unchanged in the first revision but was revised sharply downward to just 0.4 percent in the second. First-quarter growth was 1.7 percent. The economy grew 2.5 percent for all of last year, although it slowed to a meager 0.3 percent rate in the fourth quarter. It had expanded 4.5 percent in 1988. The total GNP, the broadest measure of the nation's economic activity, was growing at an annual rate of $4.17 trillion in the third quarter,when adjusted for inflation. That was a gain of $18.5 billion over the second quarter. In this month's survey of 52 economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a consensus said the ``GNP is now expected to contract on an annualized basis in both the fourth quarter of 1990 and the first quarter of 1991, providing us with the generally accepted definition of a recession.'' ``Fourth quarter GNP is expected to fall at an annualized rate of 0.6 percent,'' wrote Robert J. Eggert, the Sedona, Ariz., publication's editor. ``The expected contraction in the first quarter of 1991 GNP is put at 0.1 percent.'' For all of 1990, the consensus forecast of the Blue Chip economists calls for growth of 1.0 percent. The economy grew 2.5 percent last year, slowing from a 4.5 percent pace in 1988. ``Higher oil prices resulting from fears of a military conflict in the Persian Gulf, the higher taxes and reduced spending that will come with adoption of a budget-deficit reduction plan and sharp declines in both consumer and business confidence were cited'' for the weakening economic forecast, Eggert said. The Conference Board, a New York research group, reported last Friday that consumer confidence in the economy plunged in October to the lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. It said its index tumbled more than 24 points, the biggest one-month drop in the 20-history of the survey. Since the last recession, the economy has grown for 95 months through September, surpassing the previous peacetime growth record of 58 months between 1975 and 1980. The current over all record was 106 months from 1961 to 1969, which included the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise in Modest Rebound
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade in a modest rebound from recent losses. Soybeans were leading the grain markets higher following an Agriculture Department announcement late Monday of a large sale of U.S. and foreign soybeans to unknown destinations. The announcement sparked speculation of renewed demand for U.S. grains, analysts said. The early gains were limited by perceptions that Indian summer weather in the nation's midsection is pushing the corn and soybean harvest along and helping the newly planted winter wheat crop. In a weekly report released late Monday, the USDA said 72 percent of the U.S. soybean crop and 64 percent of the corn crop had been harvested as of Sunday. The agency said 86 percent of the winter wheat crop was planted as of Sunday. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.29} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher with December at $1.20 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 3{ cents higher with November at $5.93{ a bushel. Cattle futures were higher and pork futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent to .17 cent higher with December at 77.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .25 cent higher with November at 87.32 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent to .23 cent lower with December at 51.22 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent to 1.17 cents lower with February at 59.90 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled lower on Monday. Pork futures fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Expect Continued Growth Next Year
DOC.TEXT: German businesses expect continued growth next year despite rising oil prices and pressure on exports, the national chamber of commerce said Tuesday. More than 90 percent of the 17,000 German businesses surveyed said they expect 1991 to be as good as this year, while 39 percent predicted business will be better. Only 9 percent expect the economy to be worse, the survey shows. Franz Schoser, managing director of Germany's association of chambers of commerce, predicted the country's growth rate next year will be between 2 and 3 percent. The chamber said businesses are optimistic about the expected benefits of removing European Community trade barriers in 1993, as well as greater access to Eastern Europe. The optimism persists despite less demand for exports in the United States and Japan, where prices for German products have risen along with the value of the German mark. That's because Germany exports about 70 percent of its products to other EC countries, where growth prospects for next year are positive. Higher interest rates on borrowed investment funds have also failed to dampen the projections, the survey says, despite the extra burden of revitalizing the economy of former East Germany. The survey, the first that includes responses from a majority of chambers in former East Germany, indicates that after several months of difficulty, ``many businesses in the new states expect tangible improvements by the second half of 1991,'' Schoser told reporters. About 85 percent of businesses surveyed plan investments equal to or greater than in 1990. Reasons for the higher investments include more stringent environmental requirements and the prospects of rebuilding former East Germany. Up to 27 percent of the businesses also plan to expand hiring as early as this fall.

DOC.HEAD: America West to Stop Hiring and Cut Flights
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines will freeze hiring and eliminate some flights after reporting a $22 million loss for the third quarter of 1990. The company is attempting to cut costs, which have escalated due to the crisis in the Middle East and the rise in the price of jet fuel, Al Frei, the airline's chief financial officer and vice president of finance, said Monday. The airline has put a freeze in non-essential hiring and will leave 200 to 300 vacant positions unfilled until the outlook improves, Frei said. It has 14,000 employees nationwide. ``We don't anticipate any layoffs. We're hoping we can do this without any of that,'' he said. However, he added, ``There isn't any way we can cover the impact of fuel prices. Fuel prices are going through the roof and affecting the entire industry.'' Before Iraq invaded Kuwait, airlines were paying 58 cents a gallon for jet fuel. The price hit a high of $1.43 a gallon earlier this month. Frei said the increase could cost America West an extra $51 million in the October-December quarter. Officials said the airline still plans to build a new maintenance hangar and move to a new terminal at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport and to offer flights between Nagoya, Japan, and Honolulu.

DOC.HEAD: Electronics, Defense Group Reports Losses
DOC.TEXT: The defense and electronics group Thompson SA reported a net loss of 270 million francs, or $53 million, for the first half of 1990, down from a profit of 71 million francs, or $13.7 million, a year ago. In a legal filing Monday, the state-owned group said the poor showing in its consolidated accounts partly reflected the weakness of the dollar and the soft North American market for its consumer electronics unit. Financial costs of recent acquisitions, a decline in income from minority-held units and stepped-up spending on research also contributed to the loss, Thompson said. First-half revenue was limited to 34.6 billion francs ($6.65 billion), up 3 percent from 33.6 billion francs ($6.46 billion) in the first six months of 1989. The group forecast that full-year net profits will fall from the 497 million francs, or $95.6 million, recorded for all of 1989. Thomson SA is not publicly traded, although it owns the listed defense and electronics group Thompson CSF. Thomson owns the RCA television business in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Czechoslovakia Work Out Oil Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union agreed Tuesday to provide Czechoslovakia 13 million tons of oil next year in a compromise worked out by Czechoslovak Premier Marian Calfa and his Soviet counterpart, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said Calfa worked out the deal in six hours of talks in Moscow with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Oil supplies have been of concern to the Czechoslovak government after Soviet authorities said this year's supply to Czechoslovakia will be about 2.6 million tons less than planned. The shortfall prompted the Czechoslovak government earlier this month to raise prices for fuel oil and gasoline by more than 30 percent. Czechoslovakia will pay for the oil with equipment and consumer goods to be chosen by Soviet oilmen, Tass said. Part of the supplies will be paid for in hard currency, the news agency reported. The Soviet Union has been the main supplier of oil to Eastern Europe for years, usually at prices far below the world market. However, beginning Jan. 1, the Soviet government is demanding payment at prices approaching the market level.

DOC.HEAD: Wrangler to Make Camouflage Pants
DOC.TEXT: Wrangler said Tuesday it will make one million pairs of camouflage trousers for American military troops in the Persian Gulf. The government has an option to request another million pairs in 1992, raising the potential value of the deal to almost $35 million. The first batch of fatigues has a value of more than $17 million. ``American soldiers assigned to Operation Desert Shield have had to endure very hot, oppressive climates,'' said Bill Koronis, senior merchandise manager for Wrangler. The company noted it was instructed to alter the pants to suit the requests of soldiers in the gulf. Wrangler is a voluntary participant in the Defense Department's Industrial Preparedness Program, which provides for rapid mobilization in the event of national need. The company, based in Greensboro, is a division of VF Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Serious Fraud Office Raids Polly Peck
DOC.TEXT: Investigators from Britain's Serious Fraud Office on Tuesday raided the offices of Polly Peck International PLC, the troubled British conglomerate. The raid was conducted with the knowledge of administrators appointed last week to help Polly Peck sort out its 1.3 billion pounds, or $2.5 billion, in debt, a Serious Fraud Office spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, who wasn't identified in accordance with office practice, said a number of documents would be examined at the London headquarters of Polly Peck, which owns the Del Monte fresh fruit and Sansui hi-fi equipment businesses. The raiding party included police officers and fraud office accountants, she said. The office has not released any details of its investigation. British newspaper reports said the office was looking into an alleged share support operation involving Polly Peck stock. Asil Nadir, Polly Peck's chairman, was interviewed by the fraud office on Sept. 20. Tuesday's raid also followed a search on Sept. 19 of South Audley Management Ltd., a company controlled by a Nadir family trust. The company and Nadir have denied knowledge of any wrongdoing. A spokeswoman for the accounting firm Coopers and Lybrand, which is an administrator to Polly Peck, said the company was made aware of the raid shortly before it occurred. The spokeswoman, also speaking anonymously, said it was ``difficult to say at this stage what the implications'' are for Polly Peck's bankruptcy proceedings. News of the South Audley management raid sent Polly Peck's stock plummeting on London's Stock Exchange on Sept. 20, prompting the company to ask for a suspension in trading in its stock. The company subsequently suffered a liquidity squeezed which forced it to turn to British courts last week to obtain protection from its creditors while it sorts out its debt. The company has been expected to sell off assets to reduce its outstanding loans.

Prices fell on Wall Street today as the stock market took a pessimistic view of the economy and the Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 12.13 to 2,418.07 as of 2 p.m. EST after fluctuating in earlier trading. Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of nearly 2 to 1, with 480 stocks up, 942 down and 484 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 103.36 million shares at mid-afternoon. Stocks first waffled and then fell following the release of third-quarter gross national product figures. The Commerce Department said the economy grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent during the July-September period, a stronger than expected showing. Analysts said Wall Street was not impressed by the figures, since much of the increase was due to consumer spending that was in turn boosted by higher sales of cars and trucks. Larry Wachtel, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the stock market still believes the economy was heading for a recession, especially since consumer spending is expected to decline. Analysts said there was growing uneasiness about the Middle East that made traders reluctant to buy. ``There's no reason to get too involved,'' said Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. Earnings reports continued to affect stocks. Ford Motor led the NYSE most active list, tumbling 2[ to 27{ after announcing a third-quarter earnings drop. But even companies with good earnings reports were suffering. Boeing, which announced a profit increase and positive outlook on Monday, was off 2\ to 43~ on concerns the aerospace firm might not be able to keep up its earnings pace. Among blue chip issues, Philip Morris rose \ to 46[, General Electric fell \ to 50|, and IBM was off \ to 105}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.89 to 164.35. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 1.62 to 287.17.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on Treasury Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes fell in Tuesday's auction to the lowest level since last December. The average yield was 7.84 percent, down from 8.18 percent at the last auction on Sept. 25. It was the lowest rate since two-year notes averaged 7.71 percent on Dec. 19, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 7} percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,983.60. A total of $12.11 billion in notes-bonds was sold out of bids totaling $42.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mostly Higher, Boosted by Corn Export Talk
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported in part by persistent rumors of a large sale of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union or an Eastern European country. The Agriculture Department has not confirmed any large export corn sales of corn. Nevertheless, the market was moved Tuesday, as it was Monday, by talk that about 500,000 metric tons of corn were sold. John Frazier, director of agricultural trading for Gerald Inc., discounted the rumors, however. ``Every time the market goes up, they always say it's Russia,'' he said. Soybeans for near-term delivery rose slightly but prices for delivery next fall fell following an American Soybean Assocition report that certain provisions in the 1990 farm bill would likely result in a 2 million-acre increase in soybean acreage next year. At the close, wheat futures were 2 cents to 3\ cens higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.61\ a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $1.20} a bushel; corn was } cent to 2} cents higher with December at $2.28{ a bushel; soybeans were 3\ cents lower to { cent higher with November at $5.91 a bushel.

Prices turned mixed on Wall Street today as blue chip stocks recovered from their economic doldrums but left the broader market behind. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 11.88 to 2,442.08 as of 3 p.m. EST after reversing course several times. Meanwhile, declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of about 7 to 5, with 601 stocks up, 856 down and 480 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 128.46 million shares with one hour of trading left. Stocks were down for much of the day following the release of third-quarter gross national product figures. The Commerce Department said the economy grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent during the July-September period, a stronger than expected showing. Analysts said Wall Street was not impressed by the figures, since much of the increase was due to consumer spending that was in turn boosted by higher sales of cars and trucks. Larry Wachtel, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the stock market still believes the economy was heading for a recession, especially since consumer spending is expected to decline. Analysts said there was also growing uneasiness about the Middle East. In late afternoon, analysts said sellers left the market and buyers moved back in. Earnings reports continued to affect stocks. Ford Motor led the NYSE most active list, tumbling 1~ to 27} after announcing a third-quarter earnings drop. But even companies with good earnings reports were suffering. Boeing, which announced a profit increase and positive outlook on Monday, was off 1| to 44{ on concerns the aerospace firm might not be able to keep up its earnings pace. Among blue chip issues, Philip Morris rose } to 46|, General Electric rose 1\ to 52[, and IBM was up ] to 106]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.56 to 165.80. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.90 to 287.89.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Aircraft President to Retire
DOC.TEXT: The president of McDonnell Aircraft Co., William S. Ross, on Tuesday announced he will retire after 35 years with the company. Ross, 64, will step down Dec. 31. Gerry Johnston, president of McDonnell Douglas Corp., will be temporarily assigned as the company's president until a permanent successor can be named. Johnston's assignment is expected to last from six to 12 months. He will also continue as president of McDonnell Douglas, although McDonnell Douglas Chairman John F. McDonnell said Johnston's first priority will be the aircraft division. Ross joined McDonnell Aircraft in 1955 after 11 years as an Air Force pilot. He became executive vice president in 1985 and was elected president a year later. Johnston, 59, has held a range of engineering and leadership positions during 34 years with McDonnell Douglas, including 12 years at Douglas Aircraft Co. in Long Beach, Calif. He was vice president-general manager of McDonnell Douglas of Huntington Beach before being elected president of McDonnell Douglas in March 1988.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Unveils High-End Personal Computers, Workstations, Operating System
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. on Tuesday unveiled several new high-end personal computers and workstations that indicate the computer giant intends to keep its machines in the performance lead. IBM also announced a new version of its operating system for personal computers, which could intensify IBM's tussle with software giant Microsoft Corp. over which system will take the lead. IBM says its two new high-end models of its Personal System-2 line are up to 2{ times faster than the previous top machine. Both new PS-2 models use Intel Corp.'s most powerful microprocessor, the 486. IBM already offered a PS-2 with the 486 chip, but it uses a less speedy version of the microprocessor than that offered as an option on the two new models. One of the new PS-2 models is designed to be used as a ``file server,'' or a central data base for a network of desktop computers. This machine, the model 95, will cost from $14,145 to $17,745, depending on the version. The computer, which sits on the floor rather than the desktop, is IBM's answer to a powerful file server introduced last year by Compaq Computer Corp., some industry analysts say. The IBM machine can link 25 to 35 desktop machines in a typical application, said spokesman Kevin Clark. The other new PS-2, the model 90, is aimed at applications that require a great deal of computing power, such as computer-aided design, financial modeling and graphics-intensive programs. The desktop machine will cost $12,495 to $16,695, depending on the version. The new PS-2s also include new graphics technology that IBM says provides sharper graphics and will make them appear on the screen much more quickly than the technology it replaces. Peter Burris, an analyst at the research firm International Data Corp., called the new PS-2s a ``solid product.'' But, he said, ``the pricing remains IBM-like, meaning not cheap.'' He said IBM, like several other computer makers, ``is interested in learning as much as it can about that area between high-end PCs and low-end midrange'' computers. As personal computers grow more powerful, they are blurring the line with midrange machines, or minicomputers. However, analysts say, minicomputers typically come with better support services from the maker and software more closely tied to the user's needs. IBM, based in suburban Armonk, also announced new workstations that offer better performance than the previous top-end models of its RISC System-6000 line, Burris said. IBM disclosed the new machines to customers and analysts but said it would not talk to reporters until a news conference Wednesday. Burris said the workstations, which are aimed primarily at scientific and engineering users, offer ``knockout performance.'' One of the new models, the PowerServer 550, is about 38 percent faster than the line's previous top-end file server, Burris said. Burris said the new models, which use IBM-developed microprocessors and are priced at $135,000 to $137,000, offer more performance for the money than competing workstations from Sun Microsystems Inc., the leading workstation seller. IBM also announced a new version of its operatng system for the PS-2s that takes up less computer memory. An operating system is the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. The new version of Operating System-2 should allow more computer users to convert to this operating system, which is more user-friendly than the DOS operating system it was designed to replace, IBM says. Previously, many computer users had to make costly upgrades to their machine's memory before they could use OS-2, which was designed in conjunction with Microsoft. The base version of the new operating system will cost $340. OS-2, introduced by IBM and Microsoft in 1987, has failed to gain widespread popularity, in part because it requires a greater level of memory than many computers have, analysts say. In addition, OS-2 competes with a software product called Windows developed by Microsoft, which provides many of the same ease-of-use features for the DOS operating system. The competition between OS-2 and Windows has caused friction between IBM and Microsoft, according to industry reports.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Earnings Much Lower Than Expected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock price in 5th graf.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
