DOC.TEXT: Losses in normally profitable overseas operations contributed largely Tuesday to a 78.7 percent drop in Ford Motor Co.'s third-quarter earnings. The decline at the No. 2 automaker was much steeper than Wall Street analysts had expected. Ford said it made $101.7 million, or 22 cents a share, during the July-September period this year. That's down from $477.1 million, or $1.03 a share, in the third quarter last year. The earnings decline would have been bigger without one-time accounting changes that boosted this year's figures by $86.9 million - $66.9 million in the United Stats and $20 million overseas. Ford stock finished down $2, at $27.62{ per share, on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. No. 3 Chrysler Corp. reported a $214 million loss Monday - the automaker's largest operational loss since the first quarter of 1981, when it was recovering from near bankruptcy. General Motors Corp., the nation's biggest automaker, planned to release third-quarter earnings Wednesday. Like Ford, GM's earnings were expected to be hurt by overseas profit declines. ``My impression in Europe is the whole European market turned down in the third quarter,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. of New York. ``Ford relies a lot on the United Kingdom (sales), which is down 12.5 percent for the first nine months.'' She said Ford held about 25 percent of the United Kingdom market, down from 30 percent a few years ago. Ford said it lost $89 million on its overseas automotive business, which in the past has helped carry less profitable North American operations. During the third quarter last year, Ford's overseas operations earned $324 million. The company said it made $50 million on its U.S. automotive operations, but that was offset by the accounting change for a net loss of $17 million. In the United States, Ford got a bit of a break from a reduction in its incentive costs - down to $975 per vehicle from $1,000 for each car and truck sold during the 1989 period. Ford's Financial Services Group, which includes consumer financing and other operations, earned $141 million during the third quarter of this year, down 25.8 percent from $190 million during the same period last year. The group's income was reduced by $69 million, or 15 cents a share, to boost loan reserves for its First Nationwide Bank subsidiary, based in San Francisco. Ford's earnings came on $23 billion in revenues, up 13.9 percent from revenues of $20.2 billion during the July-September period last year. For the first nine months of this year, Ford earned $1.4 billion, or $2.99 a share, down from $3.52 billion, or $7.51 a share, during the same period in 1989. Revenues for the period rose to $73.5 billion from $72 billion. ``We believe that financial results will remain weak in the near term, reflecting a continuation of the adverse factors affecting this quarter's results,'' said a statement by Ford Chairman Harold Poling and President Philip Benton. ``Despite the near-term pressure on profits, we at Ford remain committed to an aggressive capital-spending plan.'' That spending plan and pressure on profits prompted Moody's Investors Service Inc. of New York to downgrade securities of Ford and some of its subsidiaries by one notch last week. However, the ratings, which are used as a reflection of its credit worthiness, remained well within Moody's investment grade.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Grew Faster in 3rd Quarter; Analysts Still See Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Mosbacher comment, subbing grafs 3-4. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy grew at a faster-than-expected 1.8 percent rate in the third quarter, the government said Tuesday, but the report failed to dissuade many analysts who believe the economy is entering a recession. The Commerce Department report on the gross national product showed that consumers buying cars and other items had continued to drive the longest peacetime economic expansion in U.S. history through September. Whether the expansion reaches its eighth anniversary in November was a matter of debate. ``This release contradicts those who believe we are in a recession or are about to enter one,'' Commerce Undersecretary Michael R. Darby told reporters. His boss, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, added in San Antonio, ``I hope all the doom-sayers and nay-sayers and cluck-cluckers go back in their holes for a while.'' But economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York said, ``I believe we're in a recession. I think that most of the things showing strength in the third quarter will be weak in the fourth, particularly consumer spending.'' Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, also believes the economy is declining this quarter. He contended that much of the GNP strength ``was concentrated early in the quarter. It is by no means certain that it was growing 1.8 when the quarter ended.'' Indeed, Michael Boskin, chairman of Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said, ``While this is pleasant news about the third quarter, we are concerned about a sluggish fourth quarter and the early part of 1991.'' He added that he ``was certainly pleased'' with the Federal Reserve's action Monday in pushing down a key short-term interest rate, a move that might be expected to boost economic growth. The Commerce Department had continued bad news about the housing industry Tuesday. It reported that sales of new homes slumped 6 percent in September, the ninth decline in the past 12 months and the worst drop in half a year. Declining home sales suggest continued contraction in the industry since builders often put off new projects when inventories climb. The gross national product report will be revised twice in the next two months as more information is received. The final revision of the second-quarter GNP showed the economy grew just 0.4 percent rather than the 1.2 percent first reported. Consumer spending - two-thirds of the nation's economic activity - jumped 3.6 percent in the third quarter compared to a 0.2 percent gain in the second. Much of the advance was due to a $3.4 billion increase in automobile sales, which had declined $6.1 billion from April through June. But the Conference Board reported last Friday that consumer confidence in the economy plunged in October to the lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. The New York research group said its index tumbled more than 24 points, the biggest one-month drop in the 20-history of the survey. ``The fourth quarter is going to be sick,'' said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI-McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. ``The consumer is terrified about the future.'' In addition to consumer spending, the department said third-quarter economic growth was fueled by a 7.4 percent increase in business investment. That activity was partially offset by a $1.7 billion decline in inventories held by business and a $7.9 billion merchandise trade deficit. Housing construction was off 15.4 percent and federal government spending was down 0.3 percent. The Commerce Department also said that a GNP measure of inflation rose to 4.1 percent in the third quarter, up from 3.9 percent in the second. It was the first GNP report since the Persian Gulf oil-price shock pushed up the price of many consumer goods. The third-quarter growth was an improvement over the meager 0.4 percent gain during the second quarter when consumer spending inched up just 0.2 percent. Brinner said consumer spending was weak in the second quarter because it was stronger than normal during the first quarter due to unusually warm weather. ``If you take spending out of the second quarter and put it into the first, obviously it depresses second quarter and makes the third quarter look good,'' he said. The economy has grown for 95 months through September, far beyond the previous peacetime record of 58 months between 1975 and 1980. The economy expanded for 106 months from 1961 to 1969, including the Vietnam War. A survey this month of 52 economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators showed a consensus said the ``GNP is now expected to contract on an annualized basis in both the fourth quarter of 1990 and the first quarter of 1991, providing us with the generally accepted definition of a recession.'' For all of 1990, the consensus forecast of the Blue Chip economists calls for growth of 1.0 percent, just above the administration forecast of 0.7 percent. The economy grew 2.5 percent last year, slowing from a 4.5 percent pace in 1988. Total GNP, the broadest measure of the nation's economic activity, reached an annual rate of $4.17 trillion in the third quarter when adjusted for inflation. That was a gain of $18.5 billion over the second quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Units Report Profits Up a Combined 17.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s financing, computer services, and defense and electronics subsidiaries said Tuesday that their third-quarter profits rose by a combined 17.3 percent over the same period last year. General Motors Acceptance Corp. reported the largest jump, 24.7 percent, while Electronic Data Systems Corp. reported a 17 percent rise in net income and GM-Hughes Electronics Corp. said its earnings were up 7 percent. General Motors Corp. is expected to report earnings on Wednesday. GMAC said it earned $293 million during the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $235 million for the third quarter of 1989. Lower short-term borrowing costs in the United States helped increase net income from financing operations to $259 million from $170 million a year earlier, the company said. For the first nine months of the year, GMAC said its earnings rose to $931 million, compared with $860 million for the first nine months of 1989. EDS said it had net income of $128.4 million, or 54 cents a share, for the period, up from $110.9 million, or 46 cents a share, for July-September 1989. Total revenues for the quarter rose to $1.53 billion from $1.37 billion in the third quarter of 1989. EDS said it receive nearly $6 billion in new computer services contracts in the quarter, including a $450 million pact with First Fidelity Bancorporation of Lawrenceville, N.J., and a tentative agreement with Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., parent company of Continental and Eastern Airlines. For the first nine months, EDS said it had net income of $363.5 million, or $1.52 a share, on revenues of $4.4 billion, up from $315.8 million, or $1.31 a share, on revenues of $4.03 billion in the first nine months of 1989. GM Hughes Electronics credited increased sales of torpedoes, missiles and night vision systems for improving third-quarter net income to $158.1 million, or 40 cents a share, from $147.8 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $2.93 billion for the period from $2.58 billion in the third quarter of 1989, the company said. The increased sales in the third quarter represented orders from before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, company spokesman Bruce McCristal said. He said it wasn't known if Mideast tensions would affect orders for the current year. GM Hughes Electronics had reported profits for the first six months of 1990 trailing last year's, due to declines in military orders, costs associated with new spacecraft products, and tax credits recorded in the second quarter of last year. For the first nine months, the company said net income was $530.4 million, or $1.33 a share, on revenues of $8.79 billion, still 11.3 percent behind the net income of $598.2 million, or $1.48 a share, reported on revenues of $8.47 billion for the first nine months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Dips As Market Won't Even Budge on Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices slid back Tuesday in a market that was so sluggish traders wouldn't even jump at rumors as they have for weeks. Analysts who have witnessed numerous rumor-induced buying and selling binges compared the quiet session on the New York Mercantile Exchange to ``the little boy who cried `wolf.''' ``This war has started so many times on the floor of the Nymex that I think it's getting a little weary of starting there,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. Light sweet crude oil, the benchmark grade, was up a little more than $1 per barrel early in the day, before dipping to close at $34.54 per barrel, down 14 cents, for December delivery contracts. Later delivery contracts followed a similar pattern, opening up and closing down. During the light trading session, people on the exchange said the market refused to budge on rumors that in other recent sessions would likely have sent crude prices surging by a dollar or two. One of the rumors even had shots being fired in the Persian Gulf. ``As the day wore on, they became increasingly convinced that the general market was not behind them and we were not going to see any knee-jerk reaction to these rumors,'' Beutel said. ``I think the market is a little tired,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``It's just tired of reacting to these rumors. It's like crying wolf for something.'' Oil traders say they generally ``buy the rumor, sell the fact,'' but evidence of that strategy has been absent during the last two trading sessions. Oil's high opening prices had been based on harsh words from U.S. officials who warned Iraq that a military solution to the crisis was possible. Traders and analysts could not pinpoint anything that later pushed prices down, other than the market's apparent case of the doldrums. Futures for refined petroleum products also fluctuated aimlessly Tuesday. They opened higher, along with crude, and closed mixed. Wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 1.30 cents to 93.73 cents a gallon on November delivery contracts. Near-month contracts were also higher, but more distant months closed lower. Wholesale home heating oil moved in the opposite direction, closing with near months lower and distant months higher. November delivery contracts were down .19 cent at 91.17 cents per gallon. Natural gas futures were mixed. December delivery contracts fell 2.6 cents to $2.408 per 1,000 cubic feet. After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute released weekly figures showing the nation's supply of crude oil had fallen below 1989 levels for the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The U.S. stockpile of crude dropped to 339.5 million barrels last week, compared with 340.4 million barrels a week earlier and 345.4 million barrels a year earlier. It was the first time this year that the crude stockpile had fallen from the comparable week a year earlier, API said. The stockpile of distillates, which includes home heating oil, was up to 138.1 million barrels, from 136.9 million barrels a week earlier and 118.7 million barrels a year earlier. The gasoline stockpile was down to 220.4 million barrels, from 222.6 million barrels a week earlier and 223.2 million barrels a year earlier. The nation's refineries ran at 82.5 percent of capacity, compared with 83.3 percent a week earlier and 86.6 percent a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Dow Jones' Debt
DOC.TEXT: A major credit-rating agency Tuesday downgraded slightly its opinion of the debt of Dow Jones & Co. Inc., citing lower ad revenue at the company's publications, including The Wall Street Journal, and lower revenue from its electronic information services. Moody's Investors Service Inc. downgraded about $200 million of Dow Jones' long-term debt from Aa3 to Aa2. The numbers, from 1 to 3, indicate gradations within the Aa category, which Moody's uses to indicate high-grade investment bonds. ``Dow Jones' performance measures will not achieve historic levels as a result of intensifying competition in information services, lower advertising lineage in printed publications and the prolonged downturn in the financial services sector,'' Moody's said. Moody's said the company has been hurt by the continued downturn in the financial industry, a key customer for Dow Jones' information services. Dow Jones spokesman James Ambrosio said the company wasn't surprised by Moody's action and that the new, lower rating ``continues to reflect favorably on our financial condition.'' Earlier this month, Dow Jones announced a 17.5 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings and said it would launch a cost-cutting program that would include a freeze on spending and total salaries and other reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Company Unveils 3-D Technology for Personal Computers
DOC.TEXT: Silicon Graphics Corp. on Tuesday unveiled technology the company said will give personal computer users access to three-dimensional graphics previously available only on expensive computer workstations. The company announced circuit boards that fit inside International Business Machines Corp. and IBM-compatible personal computers that use Intel Corp.'s powerful 80386 and 80486 microprocessors. The boards, called Irisvision, allow users to move and alter 3-D color images on the screen and instantly see the changes they make, a feature important to scientists and engineers. ``Irisvision redefines and sets new standards for personal computer graphics,'' said Edward R. McCracken, Silicon Graphics' president and chief executive officer. ``(It) will change the way people use PCs for design and animation.'' Both the boards and about 15 software packages to take advantage of them will be available in January, the company said. More than 20 software developers are writing applications for Irisvision, it added. Silicon Graphics is known for its 3-D graphics computers, ranging from workstations starting at $10,000 to supercomputers costing $500,000. The boards are the first product the fast-growing 9-year-old Mountain View company has produced for the personal computer market. They also come as competitors, notably Sun Microsystems Inc., try to woo personal computer users with cheaper workstations. Irisvision boards will cost $3,500 to $5,000. The company hopes to sell 25,000 boards during the first year. ``They give you the same graphics performance as our Personal Iris product line (of workstations),'' said company spokeswoman Jill Grossman of computers that range from $10,000 to about $25,000. The boards allow personal computer users to put together a system to do sophisticated graphics for as little as $7,000, McCracken said. They should cut into Sun's strategy of offering workstations ranging from $5,000 to $9,000, he said. But a spokesman for Sun, also based in Mountain View, said his company's computers offer more than sophisticated graphics, including networking capability and data processing not available on personal computers. Robert Herwick, an analyst with the San Francisco brokerage Hambrecht & Quist Inc., said the development of software for the new boards would help ensure their success. He also said the boards should increase demand for Silicon Graphics' workstations, since those who like the new technology may want to move up to the company's low-end workstations. Silicon Graphics posted a $32 million profit on sales of $420 million in the fiscal year ended June 30. It had $11.5 in profit on $264 million in sales in the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Says Budget Plan Means Sacrifices
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski said Tuesday that public opposition to taxes and spending cuts - not partisan politics - was the driving force behind the budget deficit debacle. But he warned that the budget plan will require Americans to make sacrifices that will help put the country on sound economic footing into the 21st century. President Bush has blamed lawmakers for the political wrangling that finally ended with the budget deal reached over the weekend, and pundits ``will blame partisan politics for the breakdown,'' the Illinois Democrat told members of the National Soft Drink Association. ``I'm not going to say it wasn't our fault, but it wasn't all our fault,'' he told an audience of about 300 gathered for the group's annual meeting. Lawmakers were faced with an impossible plea from constituents who urged, ```Don't raise my taxes, don't cut spending, but get rid of the deficit,''' said Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. ``Those are tough orders to follow, especially in an election year,'' he said, adding, ``I'm not blaming the public, I'm simply stating a fact.'' Rostenkowski, who guided the budget plan through the House, said tax increases as well as spending cuts were the only way to cut the federal deficit. He blamed the budget crisis in part on years of ``greed and selfishness'' during the Reagan administration. ``This attitude has got to be reversed,'' Rostenkowski said. ``And above all we have got to act together. This means a renewed sense of patriotism.'' ``The deficit reduction agreement is only the first step toward regaining our economic barriers,'' he said. ``You will recognize in the next five years some tremendous cuts'' in programs and services as a result of the $492 billion deficit deal. ``There are cuts in the farm program, there are cuts in foreign aid, cuts in the health area,'' he said, noting that the deal involves $43 billion in Medicare cuts. ``That's a sizeable cut, services are going to be curtailed,'' Rostenkowski said. But he predicted voters will be willing to tighten their belts for the sake of the economy, and won't lash back at lawmakers in next week's election.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Mixed As Economic Blues Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS advance-decline figures in 3rd graf, UPDATES with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market turned in a mixed performance Tuesday as some late buying sent blue chips higher but the broader market was mired in Wall Street's economic doldrums. The Dow Jones industrial average, which reversed course several times during the day, ended up 17.82 at 2,448.02. Meanwhile, declining issues outpaced advancers by a margin of about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 685 up, 817 down and 471 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 153.45 million shares, up from 133.98 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 189.57 million shares. Stocks were lower for much of the day after the Commerce Department's release of third-quarter gross national product figures. The government said the economy grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate during the July-September period, a stronger than expected showing. But Wall Street was unimpressed by the figures, since much of the increase was due to consumer spending that was in turn boosted by higher sales of cars and trucks. Analysts said the stock market considered the figurse and aberration and still believes the economy is heading for a recession - especially since consumer spending is expected to decline. Analysts said there was also growing uneasiness about the Middle East that made many traders wary. Saddam Hussein said Tuesday Iraq was making final preparations for war, while Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, described President Bush's patience with the Persian Gulf situation as ``wearing thin.'' Sellers left Wall Street late in the session, but the buyers who moved in were interested only in some of the blue chip stocks. General Electric, which been down earlier in the day, jumped 1~ to 52}; Philip Morris rose ~ to 46}; Exxon picked up 1\ to close at 48~; and Chevron gained 1\ to 68]. Analysts said the market lacked the conviction necessary to make a broad move up or down. ``Not with the kind of mixed (economic) signals that we're seeing today,'' commented Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. Earnings reports continued to dictate the performance of some stocks. Ford Motor tumbled 2 to 27| after announcing a third-quarter earnings drop. But even companies with good earnings reports were suffering. Boeing, which announced a profit increase and positive outlook on Monday, was off 1| to 44{ on concerns the aerospace firm might not be able to keep up its earnings pace. USX rose [ to 31 after announcing it would transfer its steel business to a wholly-owned subsidiary. The company also announced a 6.8 percent drop in third-quarter earnings. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $10.391 billion, or 0.37 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.84 to 166.08. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 2.18 to 357.63, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 2.18 to 304.06. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.97 to 329.83. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 288.07, off 0.72.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Expands Language Interpretation Service
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. on Tuesday expanded its telephone interpretation service to the consumer market, giving customers 24-hour-a-day access to expert translators in virtually any language or dialect. The per-call service is similar to one available since last year to business, police departments and other emergency agencies on a subscription-only basis, the company said. Around-the-world access to translators is provided by the AT&T Language Line Services, a Monterey, Calif.-based unit of the communications company. The service costs $3.50 a minute for the time a translator is on the line.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Surge on GNP Report
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices posted their strongest gains in 10 months Tuesday, rebounding from depressed levels after a government report indicated the U.S. economy had a stronger third quarter than most economists thought. Gold and silver futures turned in their best performances in more than a month. On other commodity markets, petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Platinum futures settled $18.40 to $18.70 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the contract for delivery in January up $18.70 at $437 an ounce. It was platinum's strongest day since Jan. 4, when the near-term contract surged $18.90 an ounce. Tuesday's rally marked a significant recovery for platinum, which traded at a 4{-year low of $387.50 on Oct. 16 amid fears that the economy was sliding into a recession. Those fears were eased at least temporarily by Tuesday's Commerce Department report that the economy expanded at a 1.8 percent rate in the third quarter, more than twice as fast as most economists had thought. The platinum market is sensitive to economic signals because the metal has many industrial uses. Thirty-seven percent of the platinum consumed last year went into automobile pollution-control systems and another 17 percent was used in petroleum, glass, electrical and chemical manufacturing. The market also tends to be volatile because platinum is more thinly traded than the other precious metals. Analysts said all the precious metals were oversold and due for a correction after at least four straight weeks of declines. They said the initial surge prompted by the GNP report triggered waves of buying by players who had sold precious metals earlier in the belief that prices were headed lower still. Bette Raptopolous, senior metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, said more economic data due out later in the week might determine whether the gains would hold. Commerce Department reports on factory orders and personal income are scheduled for release Wednesday followed by the monthly employment statistics on Friday. ``If those support the thesis that we've bottomed out, you could see platinum recover quite well and silver also, because they were declining on this recession picture,'' Raptopolous said. Gold futures settled $5.60 to $6 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the November contract at $379.70 a troy ounce; silver was 8.8 cents to 9.3 cents higher with December at $4.245 a troy ounce. Crude oil futures ended lower, and heating oil and gasoline futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid conflicting factors. Escalating war rhetoric from Iraq's Saddam Hussein provided support for the oil markets, but the strength was offset by President Bush's assurances that U.S. consumers could count on adequate supplies of petroleum products. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 8 cents to 36 cents lower with December at $34.54 a barrel; heating oil was .85 cent lower to .64 cent higher with November at 91.17 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.2 cents lower to 1.32 cents higher with November at 93.73 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported in part by persistent rumors of a large sale of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union or an Eastern European country. The Agriculture Department has not confirmed any large export corn sales of corn. Nevertheless, the market was moved Tuesday, as it was Monday, by talk that about 500,000 metric tons of corn were sold. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 3{ cents higher with December at $2.64\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.31 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2 cents higher with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to \ cent higher with November at $5.90{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures settled .03 cent to .27 cent lower with December at 77.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .20 cent higher with November at 87.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .27 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 51.42 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent to .97 cent lower with February at 60.30 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Company Pleads Guilty to Out-of-State Obscenity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, Home Dish, to ADD that company pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors. Pick up 4th graf, New York. Note language in 16th graf may offend some readers. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A now-defunct satellite TV company indicted in Alabama for beaming adult films outside its home state pleaded guilty to obscenity charges and paid a $150,000 penalty to charity. The charges against the New York company were sharply criticized Tuesday by the American Civil Liberties Union and the plea praised by pornogrpahy opponents who contend damage done to Alabama youngsters cannot be reversed. Home Dish Only Satellite Network Inc. entered the plea Monday in state court to two misdemeanor charges of distributing obscene materials. It was the first satellite company in the nation to be indicted outside its home state on obscenity charges for sending adult films to another state. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo refused in June to extradite four executives of Home Dish indicted last year by a grand jury in Montgomery, saying the charges were not punishable under New York law. District Attorney Jimmy Evans, who is running for state attorney general, said the plea was an admission by the company that it ``invaded the territorial boundaries of a state with hard-core obscenity.'' Martin McCaffery, vice president of the Civil Liberties Union of Alabama, said the indictment lacked constitutional grounds and set a dangerous precedent. ``If he (Evans) is really out to protect 12-year-olds, he should be going after tobacco companies,'' McCaffery said. The indictment stemmed from an obscenity law enacted in Alabama last year. Evans said his office began to investigate after complaints from parents whose children bought copies of adult movies that had been videotaped from television by schoolmates. The indictment led to Home Dish's American Exxxstasy Channel and Tuxxedo channel being pulled off the air. Home Dish went out of business after satellite owners refused to transmit its hard-core and R-rated movies. Home Dish was charged for broadcasting the movies ``Santa Comes Twice'' and ``Young Girls Do.'' Ron Wise, a lawyer for the company, declined to say why it pleaded guilty since Cuomo blocked extradition of the four executives: board Chairman Paul Klein; his wife, Janet Klein, the company's vice president; President Jeffrey Younger and Treasurer Robert Kramer. Jean Faucett, executive director of Citizens Against Pornography of Alabama, commended Evans for securing the guilty plea, but said it won't erase images placed in the minds of youngsters by the movies. ``We have a lot of studies that deal with the harmful effects of pornography ... that the violent sexual images if they are received at a young enough age will fuse with the normal sexual appetite,'' she said. ``The damage done to those children can never be undone. There is no amount of money that can pay for that.'' The plea signals to prosecutors nationwide that local obscenity standards can be enforced against offenders based outside their areas, Evans said. Evans said the films ``depict graphic scenes of sadomasochism, incest, oral and anal intercourse and multiple vaginal intercourse.'' At its height, Home Dish had 1.2 million cable TV customers and 80,000 satellite subscribers. Home Dish was fined $5,000 and paid $75,000 each to two children's homes as part of the penalty. Evans said his office selected the charities, Father Purcell Exceptional Children Center and Brantwood Children's Home. Obscenity charges against U.S. Satellite Corp. of Murray, Utah, were dismissed. Charges are still pending against GTE Spacenet, which owns the satellite used to broadcast the now-defunct American Exxxstasy Channel.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Developer Pleads Guilty, Agrees to Cooperate in Keating Case
DOC.TEXT: An Arizona developer pleaded guilty Tuesday to one count of bank fraud and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors investigating the collapse of Lincoln Savings & Loan. Ernest C. Garcia II of Tucson told the court he planned a secret land deal with ``certain officers and directors'' of Lincoln, an Irvine-based savings and loan owned by American Continental Corp. of Phoenix. Garcia was accused of participating in fraudulent transactions that inflated the income of the now-failed Lincoln thrift. In one of those transactions, the sale of 1,000 acres near Phoenix by a Lincoln subsidiary, he reportedly received a $30 million line of credit from Lincoln Savings. That deal was one of three cited in a $40.9 million civil action filed by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision against Charles Keating Jr., the one-time chief of American Continental, and five others connected with the financial institution. Keating has been charged in state court in California with 42 counts of fraud unrelated to the Garcia case. He is free on bail pending the outcome of that case. Garcia's cooperation agreement signed in federal court was placed under seal. Assistant U.S. Attorney Alice Hill refused to describe how Garcia had agreed to help the prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers' Group Asks Ban on Over-the-Counter Sales of Asthma Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf: ``The lawyers''' to CORRECT date to 1975 sted 1985. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyers' group and medical experts joined Tuesday to urge the government to strengthen safeguards for people with asthma who use an effective but potentially dangerous drug. They said that over-the-counter asthma medications containing the drug theophylline should be banned, and that prescribing physicians and their patients should be aware of the potential hazards associated with it. ``Our message about theophylline is that this medication can be a life-saver or a life-taker,'' said Michael Maher, president of the Trial Lawyers of America. Schering-Plough, the leading manufacturer of theophylline products, called the lawyers' action a ``self-serving publicity campaign'' that will unduly alarm asthma patients and interfere with doctor-patient relationships ``by overstating ad overdramatizing the known risks of theophylline.'' Company officials said their theophylline products have had a good safety record. With more than 60 million prescriptions written in the past five years, adverse reactions amounted to 1.3 per 100,000 prescriptions, said David Pernock, a company marketing executive. Schering-Plough, however, does not make any nonprescription theophylline products because ``we feel it is a drug that should be monitored,'' he said. The Food and Drug Administration banned over-the-counter sales of theophylline as a single-ingredient product in 1986. Two years ago, the agency proposed a ban on other nonprescription uses of the drug. The lawyers' group last week sent a letter to the Food and Drug Administration saying it knew of 26 preventable theophylline-related incidents of death or serious injury since 1975. About 10 million Americans, most of them children, suffer from asthma, which causes about 5,000 deaths a year. Though not a cure, theophylline, a chemical cousin of caffeine, is the most widely prescribed remedy to ease breathing and has been on the market for more than 40 years. But, said the lawyers and medical critics of over-the-counter sales of the chemical, theophylline is also one of the most difficult drugs to administer and control in patients. It can be tricky to find an effective dose without letting the drug reach toxic levels. A safe dose can quickly become toxic if certain other drugs are also taken with it or if the patient has taken over-the-counter remedies containing theophylline. Also, the flu can turn a safe dose toxic because the illness slows the body's elimination of the drug. And the symptoms of toxicity are the same as for the flu: nausea, vomiting, irritability and fever. Jeffry Pollock of Everett, Wash., said he wished he had known that when a pediatrician increased the dose of theophylline prescribed for his daughter Jennifer in 1986 when she had the flu. Within 48 hours, she began having convulsions and suffered brain damage, he said. Now 7, Jennifer functions at the level of a 6- to 8-month-old, he said. ``Theophylline was a big help to Jennifer when she needed it to help her breathing, but it also caused severe brain damage that Jennifer will never be able to fully recover,'' Pollock said. The lawyers and medical critics said patients should not discontinue their medication without consulting doctors. But they also said theophylline should not be available in nonprescription medications. In addition, they recommended that potential hazards be more clearly outlined in warnings given to physicians and that simplified warnings in monmedical language also be given to patients. And they said doctors should monitor the drug levels in their patients with regular blood tests. ``Theophylline is an important and useful medication and it needs to be made available,'' said Theodore Rall, a pharmacology professor at the University of Virginia Medical School, who said he has used theophylline. ``But I would urge that great caution be used.'' Allan Weinstein, an asthma expert at Georgetown University Hospital, said that as with other drugs, physicians should not prescribe theophylline unless they are comfortable with it. ``Theophylline is a product that requires close supervision by a physician'' who is aware of its side effects and possible hazards, said Weinstein, who appeared at a briefing with Pernock but said he had no ties to Schering-Plough.

DOC.HEAD: General Cinema Announces Agreement To Buy Outstanding Neiman Marcus Shares
DOC.TEXT: General Cinema Corp., taking advantage of its large pool of available cash, said Tuesday it would acquire from the public the 40 percent stake in Neiman Marcus Group it does not already own. The company said it would pay $14.40 per share for the stock in the specialty retailer. But investors apparently were looking for a higher price. They bid Neiman Marcus stock $3.37{ a share higher to $14.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange. General Cinema, which also owns movie theatres, holds 60 percent, or 16.3 million shares, of Neiman Marcus. The company said it expects to pay $240 million in cash to purchase the remaining 40 percent stake. Peter Farwell, a vice president at General Cinema, said the company has between $1.5 billion and $1.6 billion in cash, thanks to the sale of its bottling business in March and the sale of its shares in Cadbury Schweppes PLC last month. Those sales ``put them in the unusually good position to make acquisitions when a business is selling for cheap,'' said David Jackson, an analyst with the Western Group in New York. Although the retailing field is sluggish now, Jackson said Neiman Marcus is a good long-term investment for General Cinema. ``Specialty retailing has grown much faster than department stores,'' he said. ``They key in on items customers want rather than try to sell them the world.'' Neiman Marcus Group consists of Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Contempo Casuals stores. The group, once part of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., became 60-percent owned by General Cinema and 40-percent owned by the public in a 1987 restructuring. Farwell said General Cinema is also lookng for a third market to break into with some of its remaining cash. ``We're looking for something outside retailing, for diversity,'' he said. Farwell would not speculate on what type of company General Cinema might try to buy next. For the year ending Aug. 4, 1990, Neiman Marcus Group had revenue of $1.69 billion and earnings of $28.2 million. General Cinema owns 1,450 movie screens nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: DeSoto Declares Special $24 Dividend from Sale of Paint Business
DOC.TEXT: Directors of DeSoto Inc. on Tuesday declared a special dividend of $24 a share from the proceeds of the sale of its paint and industrial coatings business. The company sold the operations to thwart a takeover attempt by Sutton Holdings Corp. of New York. Sherwin-Williams Co. paid $80 million for DeSota's paint business and Courtaulds PLC of London bought the industrial coatings operations for $135 million. DeSoto also has agreed to sell its surfactant and emulsifier businesses to Witco Corp. of New York. It said it will consider another special dividend upon completion of the sale of that business. DeSoto will be left with a household detergent business that supplies detergents to Sears, Roebuck & Co., Lever Brothers and others.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Signs Accord Restructuring $62.4 Million Debt With Belgium
DOC.TEXT: Mexico signed an accord Tuesday restructuring $62.4 million of its foreign debt with Belgium, all of it in government securities repayable over a 10 years with a 6-year grace period, the Treasury Department said. Belgian Ambassador Willy Verriest and Treasury Under Secretary Angel Gurria signed the documents during a brief ceremony here. The accord is part of an overall agreement that Mexico reached last year with foreign creditor banks restructuring its estimated $90 billion debt, the second largest in the Third World after Brazil. Office Nationale Du Ducroire of Belgium and Nacional Financiera, S.N.C. of Mexico will act as financial agents in implementing Tuesday's accord, the Treasury Department said in a news release. Similar agreements have already been signed with France, Spain, Germany, Canada, the United States, Sweden and Norway.

DOC.HEAD: British, French Link Up Under Channel Tunnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs `The threading' to explain where two sides connected. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `French workers...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Britain and France were linked beneath the English Channel on Tuesday when workers used a two-inch probe to connect two halves of a 31-mile undersea rail tunnel, officials reported. Management sources at TransManche Link, the construction consortium building the ``Chunnel'' - the Channel Tunnel - confirmed the historic linkup occurred about 8:25 p.m. when British workers sent the probe through to French colleagues. ``It is an example of what Europe is about,'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in London. ``This is Europe in practice.'' The linkup fulfills a dream by Napoleon in 1802, who thought he could defeat the English by connecting Britain to Europe with a land passage. The Chunnel is scheduled for completion in June 1993. ``This is a hugely historic moment because it means, in effect, that Britain is no longer an island,'' said a construction union official. Eight workers suffered injuries, two seriously, about 90 minutes later when a tractor towing supplies rolled over on them in a service gallery, authorities in nearby Sangatte reported. The basic goal of the Channel Tunnel project is to enable passengers to travel between London and Paris in about three hours. That time is comparable to flying, if transport to and from airports is included, and is half the time of a car-ferry journey. The conservative Daily Express newspaper noted in its Wednesday editions that Britons would theoretically be able to walk to France for the first time since the last Ice Age. The cost of the project has soared from an initial estimate of $9.4 billion to $16.7 billion, including an extra $1.97 billion for unforeseen cost overruns. The threading of the probes through 100 yards of chalk under the English Channel marks a major turning point in three years of drilling on the world's costliest tunnel. The meeting point was just over 13{ miles southeast of Shakespeare Cliff, the British terminus near the town of Dover, and 10 miles northwest of the French town of Sangatte, near Calais. The tunnel starts a few miles inland on each side, accounting for its total length of 31 miles. Geological conditions account for the different progress on each side. French workers reaching the tiny hole telephoned their British counterparts and relayed the news to TransManche officials. The first champagne corks popped minutes later. ``It's an exciting moment. It's the first time we have air passing between the two tunnels,'' said Gordon Crighton, tunnel engineering manager. ``We see it as just another exercise, but I'm sure there will be a lot of parties going on,'' he said. Preliminary tests indicated the two halves were 20 inches out of alignment. Another day will be needed to be certain, technicians said, but they called the line-up ``exceptional,'' considering the massive boring machines are drilling holes about three stories high. The workers will now bore out a one-yard hole to permit passage from one half to the other. They are expected to greet each other with handshakes in a few weeks. Two Japanese-designed boring machines are drilling the tunnel. After it is finished, one will be dismantled and hauled out in pieces. The other will drill its own grave and be buried in cement because French officials said it will be too costly to extricate it. A work slowdown since last week by militant tunnelers demanding more pay on the French side appeared likely Monday to stall the linkup until the weekend or beyond. But TransManche officials said earlier Tuesday that the meeting in the middle would occur on schedule. The Chunnel actually consists of three tunnels - two for railway trains and a smaller maintenance tunnel between them. Taking into account all the tunnels, 80 percent of the drilling has been completed by giant, Japanese-built boring machines working from Calais and Folkstone, England. Tuesday's linkup in the service tunnel is described by the French as a ``mouse ole'' - a bore only two inches in diameter. President Francois Mitterrand and Mrs. Thatcher are expected to meet each other in the tunnel Jan. 26, after the digging for much of the tunnel is finished. The first coupling of the two rail tunnels is scheduled for mid-1991. Eurotunnel PLC, the world's largest engineering project, announced Oct. 8 that it had reached an agreement with its banks on $3.5 billion in new credit. More than 200 banks are involved in the financing. The Chunnel's scheduled debut in mid-1993 would come six months after the 12-nation European Community formally drops remaining trade barriers, becoming a unified marketplace of 320 million consumers. Officials estimate the tunnel may carry 28 million passengers in the first year of operation, although Eurotunnel doesn't expect a profit until the end of the century. A study released last Friday in Paris by transportation experts said the tunnel's completion will aggravate traffic congestion in a wide area of continental Europe. Some Britons have worries of a different sort, fearing an influx of ills from the continent ranging from terrorism to rabid animals. Since construction began in late 1987, there have been seven deaths on the British side and two on the French. Five British firms were ordered last Wednesday to stand trial on charges related to the death of a construction worker last year. The undersea bond between the two hereditary enemies was envisioned nearly 200 years ago by a French engineer called Albert Mathieu. Napoleon wanted to build it, but Britain warned him off. DOC.HEAD: MGM-Pathe Deal Delayed Again
DOC.TEXT: For the third time in a week, the $1.36 billion merger between Pathe Communications Corp. and MGM-UA Communications Co. was postponed Tuesday, but officials said the deal would close Thursday. In a joint statement, the companies said the closing was delayed by accounting procedures, incomplete closing documentation and the transfer of certain funds from MGM-UA to Pathe. Those funds, totalling some $700 million, are to be used by Pathe to acquire MGM-UA in the complicated deal. After a four-month extension, the original closing date was Oct. 23. That deadline was not met, nor was another Friday. A spokesman for Pathe said the delays did not mean the deal was imperiled. ``The fundamentals are still in place,'' Craig Parsons said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves $22 Million Settlement Against SmithKline
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday approved a $22 million settlement of a class action suit filed in 1988 by stockholders of what was then SmithKline Beckman Co., according to attorneys for the shareholders. Preliminary approval of the settlement was given in August. The shareholders accused the pharmaceutical company of misleading investors and not disclosing information that would have hurt the price of its stock. The suit alleges Smithkline knew that sales of its major products were on their way down and the company would not meet its promised growth rate of 10 percent in 1988. U.S. District Court Judge Raymond Broderick made no decision on the validity of the investors' claims. The company, now SmithKline Beecham, has denied any liability or violation of the law. Richard D. Greenfield, an attorney representing the plaintiffs, said it was not yet determined how much each investor would receive on the claims.
